title: The Making of Modern Africa
professor: Beverly Val Addo beverly.val-addo@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 221 1) (The media has often depicted Africa as a continent in turmoil, underlining military coups, war, famine, and disease. Yet those portrayals overlook the historical complexities that have led to current events. In this course, we aim to challenge limited narratives of Africa's contemporary realities by delving into the people, events, and processes that have shaped the continent. Given the vast size of Africa, the course will focus on specific themes and cases. These will include the end of the Atlantic slave trade and the transition to "legitimate" commerce; the motivations for and establishment of colonial rule; economic, social, and cultural transformations; African resistance to colonialism and decolonization; and post-colonial political trajectories. Altogether, this course examines the internal and external dynamics of change in Africa.)

title: Topics in Somatic Practices: Contact Improvisation
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) We recommend completing one semester of DANC 150 Movement Improvisation prior to taking this course. Contact Improvisation, an improvised duet form, explores partnering through many techniques including weight-sharing, counter balancing, momentum and stillness. We focus on bodily awareness and physical reflexes rather than consciously controlled movements. Movers shift direction, velocity, momentum and the quality of touch as they explore dancing together. In this course, dancers concentrate on how partnering with others enables them to feel sensations in their own body more acutely. All levels of movement experience--from none to some--can come experience the joy of improvising through contact! Please email Greg Catellier for a permission number and let him know if you've taken DANC 150: gcatell@emory.edu.

title: Intro to African Studies
requirement_sentence: Introduction to African Studies is a course that will provide an in-depth study of the African continent through an interdisciplinary methodology. Drawing from history, literature, oral tradition, gender studies, religious studies, film, art, sociology, anthropology, philosophy, and political theory, this course will provide knowledge and insight into how African peoples have conceptualized themselves, the world, and their place in it over time. This course is primarily concerned with the realities "historic and contemporary" of life on the African continent and who Africans are to themselves.

title: Intermediate Spanish II
requirement_sentence: SPAN 201 or SPAN_OX 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Spanish 202 is a continuation of Spanish 201 and is designed to further develop students' Spanish skills. Students refine their grammar usage through continued review of basic structures and study of complex structures, and they expand their spoken Spanish skills through discussion and analysis of cultural topics, personal experiences, and literary and journalistic texts. Students are provided ample opportunity for focused listening through use of recorded texts (conversations, music, video) and for oral expression through general classroom and small-group discussions and oral reports. Readings in the course focus on both historical and current cultural and social issues in the Hispanic World, and writing is also developed as a communicative endeavor, with emphasis on the preparation of written compositions/reports based on the cultural components of the course. Prerequisite: successful completion of Spanish 201 at Emory, at Emory at Oxford, transfer credit for Span 201 from another institution, or permission of the Director of Placement.

title: Topic Seminar: African Hist: African Writings
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 241 1) (Complete topic is African History through African Writings) (The earliest histories of Africa were written from a Eurocentric perspective, privileging external interpretations over indigenous voices. This course challenges those dominant narratives by introducing students to the History of Sub-Saharan Africa through African literature. We will use African writings as a mirror through which we can examine the historical trajectory of Africa. At the heart of this course lies a central question: How did Africans make sense of their world? We will explore this by examining how Africans understood broader historical events such as Islamic and Atlantic slavery, colonialism, and decolonization and specific events such as the Biafran War and the independence of Ghana. We will take a chronological and thematic survey of African history considering issues such as racism, gender, war, and resistance, moving from the period before colonial incursion to the colonial and postcolonial periods. We will explore fiction and non-fiction works, including oral traditions put to text like the Epic of Sunjata and the works of colonial and postcolonial African writers such as Chinua Achebe, Ayi Kwei Armah, Wole Soyinka, Ngugi wa Thiong'o, Chimamanda Adichie, Camara Laye, Buchi Emecheta, among others. These texts will serve not only as literary artifacts but also as historical documents that illuminate African perspectives, epistemologies, and modes of resistance.)

title: Intro to Hisp Texts & Contexts
professor: Diana Duarte Salinas diana.duarte.salinas@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: This course focuses on developing both cultural understanding and linguistic skills. It explores cultural issues in the Hispanic world, such as diversity, gender roles and power structures through writing about and discussion of written texts and films. These texts also serve as the basis for practicing Spanish vocabulary and grammar in context, as well as honing listening, speaking, and particularly, reading and writing skills. By the end of the course, students should be able to use critical thinking skills in Spanish to interpret and discuss literature and film in Spanish, gain advanced proficiency in reading and writing the language, and gain knowledge of significant historical events. REQUIRED TEXT: Coutard, James, Evelyn, Katryn, Gaspar, Martin. Intrigas, 3rd ed. VHL, 2021. PARTICULARS: Movie screenings will be required outside of class. EVALUATION: Class participation, chapter quizzes, weekly homework, presentations, unit lesson essays. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 202 or Official Spanish Placement for SPAN 212. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at https://spanport.emory.edu/undergraduate/placement/index.html SPAN 212 may be combined with a Spanish Foundational Course (300-318) or PORT 110 to satisfy both the HAL or Intercultural Communication requirement and major/minor requirements or electives. See https://spanport.emory.edu for details.

title: Spanish for the Professions: Spanish for Health Care
requirement_sentence: Intended as a basis for further study, this edition of SPAN 217 helps intermediate and advanced Spanish speakers communicate effectively around illness, bodies, treatment, and public health. It includes grammar and vocabulary frequently used in interactions between healthcare professionals and patients. Its emphasis on oral and written narratives cultivates the skills of reading, listening, analysis, and reflection as well as speaking and writing. Cultural topics include the history of medicine, health narratives, and bioethics. Required textbook: Spanish for Health Care and Human Services: An Interdisciplinary Approach for Intermediate and Advanced Speakers by Alicia Muñoz Sánchez and Natalia Santamaría Laorden, print or digital edition, published by Cognella. PREREQUISITE: Spanish 212 or Official Spanish Placement for a Foundational Spanish Course. Take the Spanish Placement Exam at https://spanport.emory.edu/undergraduate/placement/placement-exam.html

title: Special Topics: Building a Satisfying Life
requirement_sentence: This section is reserved for students in the BBA program. While most people list happiness as one of their central life goals, people are surprisingly bad at knowing what will make them happy. In this course, we will explore what science can tell us about what actually makes people happy both personally and professionally. We will begin by examining how scientists define and measure happiness and some of the benefits of happiness for individuals and organizations. Next, we will examine the features of our minds that often make us less happy and how to combat them. We will then turn to what science can teach us about how to be happier, less stressed, and more fulfilled in our personal and professional lives. Students will have multiple opportunities to put these practices into action and will be encouraged to develop ways to build them into their current and future lives.

title: Special Topics:African Studies: The Black Atlantic
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 385 1 and ANT 385 6) (This class will explore and engage the histories, experiences, and political movements that have shaped the Black Atlantic world. Over the course of the semester, we will examine the origins of anti-Black racism and injustice in the Atlantic slave trade and African colonization. We will then interrogate more recent structures and experiences of racial oppression and inequality as well as the struggles for justice within Black communities that have emerged in response. Case studies will be drawn from Africa, the Americas, and Europe.)

title: Introduction to Hispanic Cultural History
requirement_sentence: The primary objective of this Foundational Course is to provide students with the historical, political, geographic, and aesthetic background relevant to the study of Hispanic culture, that is, to develop a student's cultural literacy with regards to the Spanish-speaking world. This course also stresses the techniques of historical/textual criticism and their relationship to the cultural history of the Spanish- speaking world. The immediate pedagogical aim of Spanish 300 is to prepare students intellectually and linguistically to undertake advanced work in Spanish both at Emory and abroad. More generally, the course will help prepare students to engage more thoughtfully in acts of communication that cross cultural borders with and within the Spanish-speaking world. Spanish 300 satisfies the Emory College GER in "Intercultural Communication." PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212 or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html.

title: Phonetics: How Spanish Sounds
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 303 1) In this course (taught in Spanish), we will explore how diverse pronunciations are produced and organized by Spanish-speakers (including native/heritage and second-language speakers). As part of this, we will compare typical pronunciations of Spanish with those of English, and we will examine how different communities assign different social meanings and values to different pronunciations (for instance, why and in what circumstances do people value positively or negatively pronunciations such as "ello están contento" as opposed to "ellos están contentos"). This semester, we will include a component focusing on how different pronunciations and intonation can contribute to the performance of literary, theatrical and other spoken-language texts/events. TEXT: Tuten, D. N., Tejedo-Herrero, L. F., R. Rao, & H. R. Clarke. 2022. Pronunciaciones del español (Routledge). PARTICULARS: This course is designed for a wide variety of students, including those for whom Spanish is a primary/native or heritage language as well as for those who are learning Spanish as a second language. This is an introductory course in Hispanic Linguistics and therefore no background in Linguistics is required. Span/Ling 303 is a core course for the Spanish and Linguistics Joint Major and a Foundational Course for the Spanish Major and Minor. It counts as an elective or IC/HAL course for other Linguistics majors and minors. ***If SPAN 303 is at full capacity, please consider enrolling in LING 304, which will satisfy the same major requirements and the IC requirement.*** EVALUATION is based on attendance/participation, homework assignments, exams, and performance projects. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212, permission of instructor or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). For more information on Foundational Courses, please go to www.spanport.emory.edu. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html.

title: Linguistics: How Spanish Works
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 304 1) Dr. Deborah Tannen, a Distinguished University Professor of Linguistics at Georgetown, was once asked the following question: "Deborah, do you like your hair like that?" 1. Why don't we ask, "Your hair do like you like that?" 2. Does like have the same meaning in both uses? 3. Are the r's in "Deborah" and "hair" pronounced the same? 4. Who asked the question, and does it matter? Is the utterance really even a question? 5. How does our interpretation change if we know more about the tone of the utterance? The answers to these questions and others similar are what we'll explore in Span/ Ling 304, starting with a general history of the field of linguistics and what human communication entails before moving into detailed discussions of the production and organization of the sounds of Spanish (fonética y fonología); the formation, structure, and meanings of words (morfología); the structure and organization of sentences (sintaxis); analyses of meaning of words, sentences and conversations (semántica y pragmática); and examples of linguistic variation. TEXT: Hualde, José Ignacio, et. al. Introducción a la lingüística hispánica (2da edición). New York: Cambridge University Press, 2013. PARTICULARS: Because this is an introductory course to Hispanic linguistics, no previous study of Linguistics is required, but the course is taught in Spanish. Span/ Ling 304 is a core course of the Spanish & Linguistics Joint Major and a foundational course for the Spanish Major and Minor and the Major in Spanish and Portuguese. ***If SPAN 304 is at full capacity, please consider enrolling in LING 304, which will satisfy the same major requirements and the IC requirement.*** EVALUATION is based on active class participation, homework assignments, exams (two midterms and a final) and a project/ presentation due at the end of the semester. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212, permission of instructor, or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). For more information on Foundational Courses, please go to www.spanport.emory.edu. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html

title: Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
ger: Humanities and Arts with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 268 1, HIST 268 1, MESAS 268 1) The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Political Struggles, Personal Histories gives students an overview of Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the 1880s on through today. It introduces students to early Zionist debates and the late Ottoman context before moving on to discuss violence during the British Mandate period, the rise of the State of Israel, and the reappearance of the Palestinian cause on the world stage after the 1967 war. The course will include sessions that examine previous bouts of armed conflict as well as various attempts at peace, but war and politics will not be the course's only foci; the lived experiences of Palestinians and Israelis will also receive significant attention, from historical times through the present day. These voices include a young Jewish female spy who helped the British defeat the Ottoman Empire; an Islamist rebel whose death inspired the Great Arab Revolt of the 1930s; a Holocaust survivor who fought in the 1948 war before becoming Israel's leading poet; girls whose families fled from Jerusalem and Libya, and grew up amidst poverty and war; a U.S.-trained heart surgeon-turned-PLO militant who was assassinated in his quest for peace, and many others.

title: Critical Writing in Hispanic Topics: Span for Int'l Business & Econ
requirement_sentence: This 300-level course is designed to equip advanced Spanish learners with the practical language skills and cultural understanding necessary to thrive in the global business environment and workplace. Moving beyond traditional textbook exercises, this course centers on experiential and project-based and practicum-based learning. Students will participate in mock simulations, conduct in-depth research on the economies and business practices of Spanish-speaking countries, and also develop their own professional portfolios relevant to their own fields. Through a comprehensive exploration of business practices, cultures, and the global economy, students will gain a robust foundation in the vocabulary and communication skills necessary for success in international business and cultural economics. This hands-on approach will provide tangible outcomes, preparing students for real-world professional scenarios. Course topics: International Markets, Real Estate, Business Management, Human Resources, International Cultural Economics & More. Prerequisite: SPAN 212 or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html.

title: Fresh Sem: Music: Music and Democracy
Introduction to American Studies
requirement_sentence: This class introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of American Studies by way of contemporary issues--including immigration, social and racial justice, and consumerism--examined within their historical context. We will draw connections between past events and the debates they provoked about the idea of "America" to events happening today. For example, how does the Black Lives Matter movement grow out of and build upon the Civil Rights movement of the 1950s and 60s? Or, How do current debates on immigration echo those of a century ago? Throughout, we will interrogate how people experience disruptive cultural events through the lens of their own identities and roles in American society. We will consider how media narratives and cultural discourses shape our public understanding of these events and in turn encourage (or inhibit) social change. Atlanta, with its rich and complex historical legacy and rapid contemporary transformations, will serve as our primary site of engagement for these questions. The city will be woven into the curriculum through the engagement with historical texts, visual archives, guest lectures with local scholars, artists, and activists, and a field trip.

title: Theater Workshop in Spanish
requirement_sentence: (Same as THEA 363 1) The objective of this course is the development of linguistic and cultural understanding in the context of theatrical performance. The course is both critical and experiential. Through close readings of texts, script analysis, memorization, development of character, writing assignments, and theatrical performance, students will develop a deeper understanding of Spanish language and Hispanic cultures through the perspectives of both disciplines, Hispanism and Theater Studies. This critical/interpretive dimension will be enriched at all stages of the course by the experiential dimension: the physical and vocal embodiment/performance of the target language and texts. Course taught in Spanish. Texts: readings will be made available on Canvas. Particulars: Class exercises will involve physical and vocal warm-ups and improvisation; assignments, including writing essays and reading plays, will include individual activities as well as activities requiring outside class preparation with partners. Prerequisite: SPAN 212 Interested students must contact Prof. Elva Gonzalez at egonza3@emory.edu or Prof. Mary Lynn Owen at mowen3@emory.edu.

title: Peer Health Training
requirement_sentence: This course will train students to be peer health partners for the Health 100 course (taught during fall semesters). Students will be provided an opportunity to become involved in a personalized approach to health and well-being by offering the tools to discover their own health and to develop healthy lifestyle behaviors. During the semester, we will cover problems and issues relevant to Emory students, evidence-based approaches to health and wellness, and information on the resources and tools available at Emory for all students. Though designed to prepare students to facilitate and present to freshmen in Health 100, not all students who successfully complete this course will go on to do so. This course will benefit any student with an interest in health who also has the aim of broader intellectual development.

title: Special Topics: American Questions: Making of Mod Am:US Since 1877
schedule_location: TTh 10am-11:15am in Math & Science Center - N302
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 232 1) (Between the end of Reconstruction and the early twenty-first century the United States became a great power and developed the strongest and wealthiest economy in the history of the world. This course will follow the nation's transformation from a farmers' republic to an industrial giant, demonstrating the interplay between its democratic institutions, its dynamic capitalist economy, and its diverse population. Themes include immigration, transport, political reform, changing ideas about gender and sexuality, the two world wars, the "rights" revolution of the 1950s and 1960s, the Cold War, and the United States' emergence as the sole post-Cold War superpower. Classes will be a mixture of lecture and discussion of assigned readings, with an emphasis on student participation. There will be two papers, a midterm, and a final exam.)

title: Special Projects: Performance
requirement_sentence: This repertory course will be an opportunity for students to dive into the choreographic process, exploring tools for researching and making dances. Drawing from methods derived from post-modern dance and improvisation, and utilizing movement material borrowed from butoh, contemporary dance, and the individual movement lineages of participants, we as a class will create a repertory piece that will be performed at the Emory Dance Concert in April. (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Email Anne Walker, awalker@emory.edu, for a permission number. Students must have completed at least one semester of a level II dance technique class to enroll in this course.

title: Topics in Language and Culture: Maternidades
requirement_sentence: This course listens to stories of pregnancy, birth, and abortion from contemporary Latin America. How do women negotiate cultural norms, legal structures, poverty, discrimination, and other barriers to make decisions for their lives, families, and health? How are these struggles depicted in novels, documentary films, journalism, activist publications, and other forms? Prerequisites: a Foundational Spanish Course or SPAN 217 (Spanish for Health Care).

title: Research: Statistical Modeling
requirement_sentence: POLS 310W: This course is an AI intensive introduction to using statistics to study social and political phenomena. Students will learn how to leverage AI to assist in the use and presentation of statistics, from project creation to the finished presentation of results, all while maintaining the highest ethical standards. The R programming language is used in the course. Students can choose which AI they want to work with. There are no prerequisites for this course.

title: Health, Wellbeing & Humanities
requirement_sentence: This class explores the role of the Humanities in broadening our perspectives on the meaning of Health. We examine how narratives and metaphors can shape our bodily experience and why certain illnesses are either stigmatized or romanticized. We also study various philosophical accounts of embodiment, along with recent critiques of the expanding medicalization of everyday life.

title: Spanish in the US
professor: Jose Luis Boigues Lopez jboigue@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 413W 1) This course provides a descriptive and critical overview of the linguistic practices of different Spanish-speaking communities in the United States, as well as a methodology for the study of these practices. Students will learn about the linguistics characteristics of the different Spanish varieties spoken by these communities, including phonetic, morphological, syntactic and lexical aspects. Special attention is given to the relationship between language and society, particularly on topics such as ethnic and cultural identity, multilingualism and language policy. The course also presents a theoretical and practical approach to the ethnographic research method. Students will read and analyze studies carried out by different scholars and will design their own research project on the topic of their preference. Special attention is given to ethical principles, for this reason students will need to complete the web-based Collaborative IRB Training Initiative (CITI) Program in the Protection of Human Subjects in Research. Background on general Linguistics is recommended, such as the one provided in Span/Ling 303, Span/Ling 304 or Ling 201.This course meets the sociocultural requirement of the Linguistics Major and can be used as one of the required 400-level courses for the Joint Major in Spanish & Linguistics or for the Major/Minor in Spanish. TEXTS: - El español de los Estados Unidos. Escobar, Anna María and Kim Potowski. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. - Selection of articles available in Canvas. EVALUATION: Evaluation will be based in class participation, weekly assignments, one exam, one research project and five written practices. PRE-REQUISITES: One foundational course, preferably SPAN/LING 303 or SPAN/LING 304.

title: Foundations of Global Health
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 205 1 and SOC 250 1) (This interdisciplinary course explores the complex causes of serious health problems in both low-income and rich countries throughout the world, as well as strategies of health programs aimed at their solution. Global Health refers not only to the health problems of "others" living in far corners of the world but also to our own health problems as citizens of a very rich nation; most importantly it is about how those health problems are the result of global, social, economic and political interactions.)

title: Mexican National Cinema
professor: Laura Torres Rodriguez laura.juliana.torres-rodriguez@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as LACS 421W 1) Once the world's leading producer of Spanish-language motion pictures and a competing alternative to Hollywood in Latin America, the Mexican film industry has undergone major transformations in distribution and exhibition networks, as well as in the regimes of film production and consumption, since the mid-1980s. This course will examine the evolving perceptions of the social function of film and shifting spectatorship practices from the Mexican Golden Age of Cinema (1930-1950) to the screen-viewing practices of our streaming age. PREREQUISITES: At least one Foundational Course (SPAN 300-318W)

requirement_sentence: In Critical Evaluation of Epi, we will explore peer-reviewed epidemiological studies. Through discussions, we will have the opportunity to evaluate the strengths and limitations of the studies. We will gain insights into the journey from results to real-world impact, learning how research shapes public health knowledge and practice, while honing the critical skill of critical thinking. title: Culture of Human Rights
requirement_sentence: Description: With the return to democracy in 1975, Spaniards gained the freedom to debate human rights questions in the press, television, literature, film, and the public sphere of digital social media. How is human rights discourse represented in Spanish culture? Conversely, how can this cultural production impact human rights policy? In exploring Spain's standing within the framework of European and international human rights theory and law, this course focuses on issues in the human rights arena that have gained prominence in contemporary Spanish society, including immigration and race; gender and sexuality; domestic and global terrorism. In their final projects students may explore these topics or pursue additional avenues of interest (for instance, language rights; children's rights; environmental rights, etc.). The course will feature guest speakers and a visit to Atlanta's National Center for Civil and Human Rights. Texts: Will include examples of numerous genres, including journalism, literature (novels, short stories, poetry, memoirs), film, popular music, and social media. Background readings will provide an overview of the polemics surrounding humanitarian ethics in the age of globalization. Evaluation: Active participation in class discussions; short written assignments; film review; final research project. Prerequisites: At least one foundational course for the Spanish major or minor (SPAN 300-318); or one 400-level Spanish course. There may be exceptions to this. Students without these prerequisites should consult with the instructor.

title: Topics in Hispanic Culture: Latin American Film
requirement_sentence: (Same as LACS 490R 1) This course explores the intersection of patriarchy, racism, and violence in 21st-century Latin American film. Students will examine how various family formats are portrayed on film, and to what extent they construe, challenge, and/or otherwise reproduce influential concepts (such as care, work, motherhood, childhood, decency, masculinity, or promiscuity) across gender, racial, and/or class-based lines. In examining these issues, we will look at how People of Color, Women, Children, and members of the LGBTQ+ collective bear the brunt of abuse and generalized violence brought against them due to the sheer fact that they dare to exist. We will also explore the concept of patriarchy paying attention to the many traits that turn masculinity in particular, and cisheteronormativity in general, (as well as subtle forms of white supremacy-ism) into vigilance vectors bent on building "the normal". In analyzing narrative depictions that address the aforementioned forms of inequality, the class will discuss to what extent State-sponsored forms of violence manufacture hegemony, neutralizing and destroying any detectable "deviance" from a desideratum for docile and malleable citizens that remains under constant (de)construction. EVALUATION: Participation in class, written critical responses, an oral presentation, and a final research essay. PREREQUISITE: At least one foundational course (SPAN 300-318W) or permission from the instructor.

title: Special Topics: American Studies: Italian American Experience
requirement_sentence: (Same as ITAL 375W 1) Content: Do you want to know more about the Mafia and the Godfather? This is an offer you can't refuse. Touching on witchcraft, the evil eye, and life in Little Italy, you will learn whether Alfredo Sauce is authentically Italian and what it meant to be an Italian immigrant at the turn of the 20th century. Several millions of Italian immigrants came to the United States to work for the industrial development of the county's economy at the end of the 19th century. This course aims at introducing you to the fascinating study of the Italian American presence in the United States and its impact. Through movies, articles and primary sources we will look at the historical, political, literary and artistic achievements of Italian immigrants in the United States to understand what it means to be an American of Italian descent in the 21st century. This course is taught in English and does not require any knowledge of Italian. It fulfills Continuing Communication and Race & Ethnicity Requirements) Text: Connell, W. J., & Pugliese, S. G. (Eds.). (2017). The Routledge History of Italian Americans. Routledge.

title: Topics in Hispanic Culture: US Frontera and Other Border
ger: Continuing Comm.& Writing with Race & Ethnicity(*)
professor: Vialla Hartfield Mendez vhartfi@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as LACS 490RW 1) In this class we ask: what exactly are "borders," "borderlands," and "border spaces"? How do they function? How can we understand the Mexico-U.S. frontera/border within both historical and contemporary contexts? How does that border inflect other "border spaces" far away from its geography, including spaces in Atlanta? The course looks at how the stories of these borders are shaped and then re-told, in written and visual texts. The course is taught primarily in Spanish while also integrating the multi-lingual nature of border stories. We will partner with the Latin American Association, whose building on Buford Highway can be described as a border space, and we will engage with a visiting artist, Yehimi Cambrón. You will complete a collaborative project that supports the Latin American Association's work and provides a framework for you to actively reflect on the integration of the humanistic inquiry (like this course) in your own future work. PREREQUISITES: At least one Foundational Course (SPAN 300 - 318W), or one 400-level Spanish course, or permission from the instructor.

title: Designing Health Research
requirement_sentence: ECON 220 or ECON_OX 220 or HLTH 207 or MATH_OX 117Q or QTM 100 or QTM_OX 100 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This course introduces students to key concepts in health research. It uses didactic and applied training to develop competency in research methods, both quantitative and qualitative. The course introduces the basic steps, methods and strategies of the research process; problem identification, hypothesis development, literature review, research design and methodology, data management, data analysis, and scientific communication. Its aim is to help students design and develop a thoughtful, persuasive, and potentially fundable scientific research proposal that addresses a health concern. Students begin with a broad health topic that they would like to investigate and learn how to narrow it down into a specific and feasible research question; then they learn how to design a methodology to address the question. In addition to comprehending and developing the elements of a research project, students also learn the principles of ethical conduct of research, essentials of scientific writing, as well as presentation skills. Students also learn how to conduct a literature review, how to evaluate the literature, and how to use a reference management software. (Prerequisites can be any one of the following: HLTH 207, OR QTM100, OR MATH_OX 117Q, OR ECON 220 - If any issues enrolling with one of these prerequisites, please contact Savvy.Mcleod@emory.edu)

title: Special Topics in Music: Bach and His World
professor: Stephen A Crist scrist@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: MUS 270: Bach and His World Stephen Crist This course explores the life, music, and influence of Johann Sebastian Bach (1685 - 1750), one of the most significant figures in the history of European classical music. We will examine and discuss representative musical compositions of all genres and from all chronological periods of his career, selected documents concerning Bach's biography and aesthetic views, and some of the most recent and important writings in Bach research. We will also consider the social, political, and religious contexts within which Bach worked. Activities include weekly discussion posts, several short reaction/summary papers, and a final course synthesis. In addition, each student will do a project that They'll present in class and submit as a paper. The course is open to all students, both musicians and non-musicians.

title: Advanced Special Topics in American Studies: Slavery & the Archive
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 488RW 2) (In Dispossessed Lives: Enslaved Women, Violence, and the Archive (2016), Marisa J. Fuentes asks how scholars can "narrate fleeting glimpses of enslaved subjects in the archives and meet the disciplinary demands of history that require us to construct unbiased accounts from these very documents?" Fuentes's question is at the heart of "U.S. Slavery and the Archive," a seminar that centers on the history of enslaved people as well as the methodological and archival problems that scholars encounter when attempting to historicize them. Throughout the semester, we will develop the research, critical thinking, and written and oral communication skills necessary to produce an original research paper.)

title: Freshman Seminar:English: Dual Dystopias
professor: Martine W Brownley mbrownl@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: In recent fiction, dystopic novels have been so prominent that critics have described our time as a golden age for the genre. The result has been that, as one writer puts it, "there's a book for every type of modern dread." Particularly notable in this current dystopic outpouring has been the influence of women writers. This course juxtaposes the most famous dystopia written in English, George Orwell's 1984, with novels by contemporary women writers (Ling Ma, Octavia Butler, Margaret Atwood, and one TBA) to explore how their works are reshaping the genre. The imaginative societies envisioned by these writers pose crucial questions about where the real dangers lie for our future and our present through their groundbreaking dystopic novels. Requirements are active & informed class participation; occasional response paragraphs; 2 short papers. (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only)

title: Nutrition Across Life Cycle
professor: Myra Woodworth Hobbs mewoodw@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: HLTH 220 or HLTH 221 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. An individual's nutrient and energy requirements change over the life span. This course will explore the nutritional foundations of growth, development, and normal functioning in each stage of the life span, from pre-pregnancy to older age. We will examine the physiological and developmental basis for changing nutrient requirements over each stage and consider evidence-based age- and life stage-specific dietary recommendations to prevent nutrient deficiencies, promote health, and prevent disease. Sociological influences across the lifespan will also be considered. (Prerequisite: HLTH 220)

title: Ecology
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. (Same as ENVS 247 1) (This course provides a broad overview of ecology, ranging from evolutionary ecology to ecosystems ecology. The emphasis of the course is on data interpretation and experimental design in the context of the ecological concepts we are discussing. Students will work in small groups on applying basic ecological principles to data interpretation and experimental design. This course will fulfill the Column C requirement (or elective credit) for the Biology major. There will be three exams plus a cumulative final exam. Students will also be evaluated on class discussions. A separate, optional, 3 credit hour laboratory (Biology 247LW/ENVS 247LW) is associated with this course (in fall semester). (The lab is not required)

title: Intro To African American Studies
requirement_sentence: This course is an interdisciplinary examination of African American cultures and societies since the Atlantic Slave Trade. Actively combining historical, literary, sociological, and anthropological theories and understandings, this course will be an in-depth analysis of the origins of the field of African American Studies and the many dimensions of black life in the United States. A broad range of audio-visual materials and cultural artifacts will be utilized throughout the semester.

requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. title: Genetics: A Human Perspective
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. (Students must also register for a BIOL 264-1 Discussion Section. This course will provide a fundamental understanding of human genetics and builds on the concepts of genetics developed in Biology 142. Topics include modern analysis of the human genome, epigenetics, and cancer. This course is designed to provide a deep understanding of modern genetics as well as to foster critical thinking and analytical skills through problem solving and analysis of the primary scientific literature. The main focus of the course will be on molecular genetics, but we will also cover fundamental principles of classical genetics and population genetics. Course topics will be explored with special emphasis on how modern genetic research is changing the face of both medicine and agriculture. There will be three in-class exams and a final project. Discussion section grades will be based on student participation. This course fulfills the Column A (or elective) requirement for the Biology major.) Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L.

title: Special Topics in Biology
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. Full Title: Phage Genomics + Intro to Bioinformatics LAB. Permission of instructor is required. Students currently enrolled in BIOL 386W (Phage Discovery LAB) in Fall 2025 have priority for this course and should contact Tonya Woolcock at tdavis6@emory.edu to request a permission number. This course is based on the SEA-PHAGES curriculum. Prior participation in the Phage Discovery wet lab is encouraged but not required. Students who have taken both semesters of the course will have the option to present their results at the SEA-PHAGES annual student symposium. In the SEA-PHAGES bioinformatics semester (GENOMES), students will learn basic principles of genomics and bioinformatics through exploration of bacteriophage genomes. Our first goal as a class (first half of the semester) is to produce the highest possible quality bacteriophage genome annotation for a phage using DNA MASTER, then contribute the final annotated genome sequence to a global database. The second half of the semester will introduce the basics of coding and sequence analysis in Python. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L.

title: Biochemistry I
requirement_sentence: [(BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or (BIOL_OX 142)] and (CHEM 203 or CHEM 203Z or CHEM_OX 203 or CHEM 221 or CHEM_OX 221 or CHEM 221Z) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. The cell is an amazing network of self-organizing machinery that drives life in all its forms. This course begins by defining the molecular wheels and cogs of the cell's machines and how their capabilities are defined by their chemistries. The chemistries of each component are then explored to understand how they contribute to the operation and control of the cellular machinery. We will further explore how all of the cellular components are governed, by kinetic and non-kinetic controls, to produce a coherent and responsive metabolism that efficiently creates and utilizes the energy stored in chemical compounds, such as glucose and fats. Human metabolic disorders such as diabetes will provide models of how metabolism is controlled at the systematic level in complex organisms using biochemical signaling pathways to coordinate metabolic pathways in different tissues. This course will fulfill elective credit for the Biology major and should provide students with a firm foundation in Biochemistry.

title: Rhetorical Composition/Critical Reading
professor: Sofia Di Gironimo sofia.di.gironimo@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Topic: What Happens to the Self at the End of the World?) (In times of political upheaval, boundaries are both erected and eroded. Borders, identity categories, properties, alliances: these all enter a period of change or upheaval. These boundaries organise the social world, and their erosion signals periods of change, when things get weird. In this course, we will explore the weird as it impacts the political, social, psychological, and ecological, asking, "What happens to the Self at the End of the World?" We will move through psychoanalytic theory as well as affect theory to gain perspective on this question-others have asked it before and we will read while coming to our own answers, together. No prior knowledge of psychoanalysis or affect theory is needed. Readings and assignments will aim to be exploratory and generative. Ephemera such as zines, political pamphlets, and social media posts receive the same seriousness of attention as peer-reviewed articles and 17th century source texts. We will read excerpts from Freud's Civilisation and its Discontents, Spinoza's Ethics, and Raymond Williams's Marxism and Literature, alongside action reports from Stop Cop City activists, and blog posts from Ismatu Gwendolin, cultural worker and activist known for her teatime TikTok lectures.) (Show-and-tell, zine-making, and video projects will join with your written work; each student will bring their own respective style and medium to assignments in this course. We each have our own expert knowledge on the subject of what it means to be a Self. We will each bring this to the table as we discuss together, the Self, the World, and the End.)

We each have our own expert knowledge on the subject of what it means to be a Self. We will each bring this to the table as we discuss together, the Self, the World, and the End.)

title: Rhetorical Composition/Critical Reading
requirement_sentence: (Topic: What Happens to the Self at the End of the World?) (In times of political upheaval, boundaries are both erected and eroded. Borders, identity categories, properties, alliances: these all enter a period of change or upheaval. These boundaries organise the social world, and their erosion signals periods of change, when things get weird. In this course, we will explore the weird as it impacts the political, social, psychological, and ecological, asking, "What happens to the Self at the End of the World?" We will move through psychoanalytic theory as well as affect theory to gain perspective on this question-others have asked it before and we will read while coming to our own answers, together. No prior knowledge of psychoanalysis or affect theory is needed. Readings and assignments will aim to be exploratory and generative. Ephemera such as zines, political pamphlets, and social media posts receive the same seriousness of attention as peer-reviewed articles and 17th century source texts. We will read excerpts from Freud's Civilisation and its Discontents, Spinoza's Ethics, and Raymond Williams's Marxism and Literature, alongside action reports from Stop Cop City activists, and blog posts from Ismatu Gwendolin, cultural worker and activist known for her teatime TikTok lectures.) (Show-and-tell, zine-making, and video projects will join with your written work; each student will bring their own respective style and medium to assignments in this course. We each have our own expert knowledge on the subject of what it means to be a Self. We will each bring this to the table as we discuss together, the Self, the World, and the End.)

title: Modern Jpn Lit in Engl Translation
Reading Comparatively
requirement_sentence: (Topic: Gender-Based Violence in Anglophone and Francophone Caribbean Women's Literature) (Discussions of gender-based violence are rarely present in theoretical works by Black studies scholars and decolonial thinkers. This course aims to address this issue. We will open this course with Myriam Chancy's Framing Silence, which highlights how Haitian women writers are able to supplement the absence of women in traditional historical narratives through literary means. This phenomenon was not only seen among Haitian women writers, but among Anglophone and Francophone Caribbean women writers in general. Building from this work, this course will explore how Anglophone and Francophone Caribbean women writers such as Sylvia Wynter, Gisèle Pineau, Shani Mootoo, Nalo Hopkinson, Fabienne Kanor, and Edwidge Danticat include portrayals of gender-based violence in their works to theorize racism, sexism, and coloniality. We will also read theoretical works that address the relationship between gender-based violence and coloniality by Achille Mbembe, María Lugones, and Malcolm Ferdinand. Assignments for this course will include short response papers, a midterm paper, and a final essay.)

title: Literatures, Genres, Media
requirement_sentence: (Same as AMST 285 3) (Topic - Genius! From Sappho to Taylor Swift) (The aim of this course is to consider how we might be thinking the concept and figure of the genius differently today. As compared to the image of the brooding, melancholic, male figures of old, how do today's geniuses look like? Who are the geniuses of our contemporary world? How do their linguistic, musical, or visual crafts look like? What are their major preoccupations? What defines them as geniuses? Who decides whether one is a genius or not? These are some of the questions that will be pursued in this course across literary and philosophical/theoretical texts, musical examples, and film. Materials covered in this course will include Aristotle's Problemata XXX, Freud's Leonardo da Vinci, Susan Sontag Under the Sign of Saturn, Ali Smith's How to Be Both, Sally Rooney's Normal People, Ocean Vuong's On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous, Jericho Brown's The New Testament, Sally Wen Mao's Kingdom of Surfaces, the filmic works of Jordan Peele, the music of Taylor Swift and of SZA, and the performance practices of the violinist Hilary Hahn and other classical musicians.)

title: Literatures, Genres, Media
requirement_sentence: (Topic - Surrealism: Theatre, Painting, Poetry) (Following World War I, "surrealism" emerged alongside several avant-garde art movements in Europe. While hugely inspired by Dada, surrealism's revolutionary attitude came from combining avant-garde sensibilities with the insights of Freudian psychoanalysis. Artistic creation would be informed by theories of the unconscious and the strange world of meaning that we encounter in dreams. The ideas of surrealism were applied in literature, painting, photography, architecture, theatre, etc., and also went beyond art into a major critique of politics. In this course, we will read, analyze, and discuss works from the founding generation of surrealists and the intellectual circle surrounding André Breton. Our focus will be to examine and compare works from three components of the surrealist movement: theatre, poetry, and painting. We will begin with the formal and linguistic innovations of surrealist poetry, then move to depictions of the work of desire in painting, and conclude with the radically improvisational Theatre of Cruelty. Key writers and artists will include Paul Éluard, Georges Bataille, Antonin Artaud, Salvador Dalí, and Frida Kahlo. Some of the larger questions we will address are: - How are the theoretical ideas of surrealism affirmed and contested by different artistic media? - How do surrealists respond to the traditional values of "high art"? - How can we cultivate the "wild eye" when viewing visual art and hear the "surrealist voice" in poetry? - What do surrealists mean when they speak of new forms of life? - How does surrealism relate to revolutionary politics? Assignments will include reflections on writing produced using surrealist methods (automatic writing, the "cut-up method"), a set of "close readings" of paintings, and a research paper discussing class-relevant topics.)

requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 110 1 and ANCMED 101 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Region.) (Topic: People and Their Gods) (This course provides a survey introduction to the study of the distinctive and interrelated cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the Bronze Age until the Christianization of the Roman Empire (ca. 3300 BCE to ca. 400 CE). Under the subtitle, "People and Their Gods," the course gives special attention to cultural phenomena identified with the category of "religion." Drawing on a range of evidence, both material and literary, we will explore how ancient Mediterranean people understood and interpreted stories about gods and other powerful beings ("myths"); polytheism and monotheism; veneration of images ("idolatry"); tradition and innovation in religious beliefs and practices; the sexualities of gods and human beings; the significance of sacrifice (including human sacrifice); how Jews and Christians viewed so-called "pagans" and how "pagans" viewed Jews and Christians; the ancient Mediterranean roots and sources of present-day religious traditions.)

title: Methods of Literary Interpretation
requirement_sentence: (Same as ENG 345W 2 and MESAS 370W 1) (Topic - Global Rhymes: Poetry and/as World Literature) (What happens when a sonnet travels across centuries and continents? How does a ghazal resonate in a new language, or an elegy mourn across cultures? From ancient epics to TikTok poetry, what makes poetry travel? And what does it carry with it? While world literature courses often revolve around the novel as the form closely associated with modernity, nationhood, and global circulation, poetry predates the novel, has long and rich histories in many languages and cultures, and continues to shape global consciousness in ways both intimate and political.) Shifting the focus to poetry, this course explores how poetic forms, such as the ghazal, sonnet, elegy, and lyric, travel across time and language. We will take up the debates around translation and untranslatability, consider how poetry responds to global forces like colonialism, transnational movements, globalization, and climate crisis, and examine how poetics intersects with politics. We'll also discuss how poetry circulates in today's digital world, whether on the page, the stage, or the screen. Ultimately, this course invites students to rethink what "world literature" means when we center poetry, its forms, its politics, and its planetary reach, in our discussions. Accompanied by critical and theoretical texts on world literature, translation, multilingualism, cosmopolitanism, transnational poetics, and migrant writing, we will engage with poetry written in various languages, mostly modern and contemporary poems, from around the world.

title: Special Topics: Literature: Women and the Law
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 358 1, AAS 385 3, and PHIL 385 2) (Women and the Law: historically, politically, and socio-culturally, these two terms have a long-standing relationship with one another. They shape one another inasmuch the latter has also historically enervated the former's rights and possibilities. Similarly, the two terms, "woman" and "law," are often contested terrains in regards to their respective meaning, interpreting the ways in which they have been constructed, and their roles in culture, society, and the unconscious. These moments are even more intensified in the ways they have been racialized and stand within a longer racial history of terror. To this extent, the course begins by examining the racial construction of gender and how the law becomes a tool of racial, ethnic, sexual, and gender repression. It will explore cases in slave law to broaden its view on constitutional and statute law as well as other concepts of laws (e.g. psychic, notions of sexual difference, aesthetic). Throughout, attention will be given to film and media representations of law, gender, and race to consider our course explorations. The course centers black feminist thought and critical race theory as its main analytic lens, and will examine how these two intellectual and political traditions remain critical in our contemporary landscape.)

title: Special Topics in African American Studies: Black Culture and Capitalism
professor: Jessica Lynn Stewart jessica.lynn.stewart@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as SOC 289 1) (This course examines the theory of Black capitalism within a wide range of American contexts, varied by place and time. First, students are exposed to a tradition of radical scholarship that analyzes the intersections - or articulations - between racism and capitalism. We will explore some seminal texts by WEB DuBois, Manning Marable, and Cedrick Robinson, among others. Then students will also gain an understanding of how local economic development works to support or obstruct Black capitalism. Particular attention will be paid to how growth versus redistribution strategies impact Black communities. It will end by considering the intersection of race and class in struggles for economic and social justice - from Black celebrities to voters, to activists and politicians.)

title: Anthropology of the Jews
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 258 1, REL 258 1) This is a fascinating time to be - or just learn about - Judaism and Jewishness. We are less than a century out from the genocidal devastation of the Holocaust, the birth of the State of Israel as the first independent Jewish commonwealth in almost two millennia, unprecedented freedom for Jews in many (but not all) parts of the world, and vast migrations by almost every historical Jewish community to a different part of the world than it lived in a century ago. Surely, these are features of the modern Jewish condition we will need to discuss anthropologically. We also live in an age of unprecedented technology and shifts in worldview. Can a genetic profile "prove" Jewishness? In what special ways are some women using assisted reproductive technology or "reproductive tourism" to fulfill Jewish kinship or social and religious expectations? Some of the most interesting anthropological research on Jewish communities today centers on these issues. This class takes place at a moment of increasing political polarization, including confrontations with legacies of (and contested definitions of) race, gender, and antisemitism. Do the new discussions of race and gender, as well as the politics of "diversity, equity and inclusion" make it harder or easier to identify and respond to key elements of the modern Jewish condition, individually or collectively? Has it grown easier or harder to answer the old question whether "Jewishness" is primarily a religious, ethnic, racial or national designation [spoiler: these are not the only options]? Does it matter? To whom? What is actually at stake in these conversations? Finally, we may be at something of a crossroads for the history of anthropology as a research discipline. Along with reading about the sheer diversity of ways of being, thinking, or living Jewishly, we will acknowledge the fraught Jewish history of the anthropological discipline, and ask some critical questions about its future. Is anthropology today capable, given the tools at its disposal, of rendering an adequate account of modern Jewish life? Why, for the most part, has it failed to do so (ok, that's another spoiler alert)? How has the modern Jewish condition impacted the anthropological project from its beginnings, and how might clearer thinking about Jews, Jewishness and Judaism contribute to new forms of anthropological thought? How can we read current ethnographies of Jews and Judaism critically to better understand what they tell us about the Jewish world, how they do it, and what they can learn to do better?

title: Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
ger: Humanities and Arts with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 268 1, POLS 268 1, MESAS 268 1) The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Political Struggles, Personal Histories gives students an overview of Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the 1880s on through today. It introduces students to early Zionist debates and the late Ottoman context before moving on to discuss violence during the British Mandate period, the rise of the State of Israel, and the reappearance of the Palestinian cause on the world stage after the 1967 war. The course will include sessions that examine previous bouts of armed conflict as well as various attempts at peace, but war and politics will not be the course's only foci; the lived experiences of Palestinians and Israelis will also receive significant attention, from historical times through the present day. These voices include a young Jewish female spy who helped the British defeat the Ottoman Empire; an Islamist rebel whose death inspired the Great Arab Revolt of the 1930s; a Holocaust survivor who fought in the 1948 war before becoming Israel's leading poet; girls whose families fled from Jerusalem and Libya, and grew up amidst poverty and war; a U.S.-trained heart surgeon-turned-PLO militant who was assassinated in his quest for peace, and many others.

title: Neurobiology Data Lab
ger: Science, Nature and Technology with Lab
professor: Samuel J Sober samuel.j.sober@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: [(BIOL 142 and BIOl 142L) or BIOL_OX142] and (BIOL 360 or NBB 301) or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. (Same as NBB 301L 1) (Topic: Neural Data Simulation & Analysis Lab). Students who were on the BIOL 360L/NBB 301 wait list in Fall 2025 AND Spring 2026 graduating senior Biology majors who need to fulfill their upper-level lab requirement have priority for this class. Contact Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu for permission. Through this course, you will learn basic computational and programming skills and apply them to the simulation and analysis of neural data. Course instructors will provide introductory lessons on basic coding in Python, which will be used throughout the course through collaborative, group-based lab tutorials. The focus of this course will be to use these in-lab tutorials to understand how neuroscience data is structured, analyzed, simulated, and interpreted. The course will be divided into 2 portions: (1) coding, running, and interpreting simulations of neural activity, and (2) understanding the analysis of neural data. The course consists of lectures, group lab tutorials, and individual homework assignments for each module. This course originates in the Biology Department, and it will count as an elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the Biology major. (This course does NOT COUNT as elective credit for the NBB major; the catalog description is incorrect.) Prerequisites: Biology 142/142L and Chemistry 202; pre- or co-requisite: Biology 360/NBB 301).

title: Black Music
requirement_sentence: (Same as MUS 303 1) (Music and Performance in the African Diaspora is an interdisciplinary course exploring critical perspectives on Black music, dance, and culture in the US and abroad. We will build a critique of cultural production emphasizing an intersectional framework and critique of oppression via black studies, black feminisms, and sound studies. This class will bring together various media, social science, film, and art as we discuss legacies of blues, jazz, funk, hip hop, and techno. We will work toward a broad definition of black music to consider its history and global circulation.)

title: Survey of Jewish History
schedule_location: MW 1pm-2:15pm in Math & Science Center - E208
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 270 1, MESAS 275 1) This course is a survey of Jewish history from antiquity to the present. It presumes no prior knowledge of Jewish history, religion or culture. We will examine how Jews have defined themselves socially and politically in a number of historical and geographical settings, how Jewish theology and religious practice have been shaped and transformed, and how Jews have interacted with and responded to the societies in which they have lived. A central question during the ancient period will be, what was "Judaism" and how did it emerge out of the diverse religious landscape of antiquity? The medieval period will focus on the interface between Jewish communities and the states or empires in which they lived. Particular attention will be paid to the interactions between Jews, Christians, and Muslim peoples and cultures. In the modern period, we will analyze the processes by which governments, politicians and some segments of Jews attempted to incorporate the Jews and Judaism into European society and the various problems and reactions engendered by the quest for Jewish emancipation and social integration.

title: Topics in Jewish History: Global History of Antisemitism
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 296 4) This course will explore the global history of antisemitism from antiquity to the present. Antisemitism is a modern term, but it has been used to describe a centuries-old fear that Jews somehow pose a threat to an existing social order. It constitutes the oldest continuous global tradition of prejudice towards any single group defined as the "Other." We will examine anti-Jewish prejudice in the realm of ideas and behaviors, attuned to changes in quality and intensity over time, and Jewish responses to violence and discrimination. We will explore the current rise of antisemitism, legal and definitional attempts to combat it, and the relationship of antisemitism to other forms of racism and anti-Zionism.

title: African American Religion: Psych.of the Black Church Exp.
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 320R 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (In this exciting new course called Psychology of the Black Church Experience, we will explore the intersection of Black psychology and African American Christianity through the lens of the Black Church. From a critical psychological approach, we will examine how the Black Church functions as a social, spiritual, and psychological support system in historical and contemporary racial experiences for Black people in America. Aspects of the Black Church experience that this course will examine include its historical relevance in America, racial identity and empowerment, gender socialization, spiritual experiences, the Black family, and mental health and healing. We will delve into topics like communal identity, leadership dynamics, coping mechanisms, and the Black Church's role in social activism, community development, and mental health within Black communities.)

title: Biotechnology & Molecular Biology Lab
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites. Complete Topic: Foundational Techniques in Molecular Biology & Biotechnology Laboratory. In this LAB course you will learn techniques with practical applications in biotechnology related to gene cloning, protein expression in prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, and recombinant protein purification. You will also express your engineered gene in mammalian cells and learn cell culture and fluorescent imaging techniques, gaining hands on experience with the same approaches used in drug discovery and vaccine development. Throughout the semester, you will construct and then carry out your own research question related to the effects of small molecules on calcium signaling. This course will fulfill elective and upper-level lab credit for the Biology major. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L.

Special Topics in Jewish Studies: Outsiders in Nazi Germany
professor: Astrid M. Eckert aeckert@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 241W 1) (This course analyses German society under Nazism, especially Nazi efforts to establish the utopia of a racially, socially, and physically homogenous society. The creation of this "people's community" was to be achieved by violently excluding people who were deemed "deviant" from the norms the Nazi Party was propagating. The class examines the interplay between inclusion and exclusion and hence the production of "outsiders". Topics in this class include the biologization of politics; the application and radicalization of "racial hygiene" (eugenics); the history of the autism diagnosis; the regime's ableism; the persecution of homosexuals; and the centrality of antisemitism to all social and political Nazi projects. These topics will be introduced by an overview of the political history and ideology of German culture from the 1920s to 1945. We will analyze written primary sources, film propaganda, and present-day reverberations of this history. This course fulfills the Emory College Continuing Communication and Writing Requirement.)

title: African American Language
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 347 1, ANT 347 1) African American Language (AAL) is by far the most researched, the most publicly recognized, and most controversial language variety in the United States. AAL has long been a central object of study in North American sociolinguistics, where researchers have investigated its structure, its origins, and its current trajectories of change relative to Mainstream American English, and have simultaneously sought to combat misunderstandings about AAL (and all language differences) held by the public and the press. This course will be broken into four major sections: 1) Present-Day Features of AAL, with a focus on its vocabulary (lexicon), pronunciation features (phonetics and phonology) and grammar (morphology and syntax); 2) The History of AAL and its ongoing trajectory of change, focusing on earlier examples of AAL, its possible origins and whether or not AAL is diverging from Mainstream American English (MAE) and other varieties of English; 3) AAL as a Living Art will discuss AAL as it is employed as an expression of art by writers, musicians, as well as its use in African American speech events, and avenues for outreach; 4) AAL, Education and Society will examine issues related to AAL and education, the justice system, linguistic profiling and discrimination in other areas of society such as housing and employment.

title: Introduction to History & Law in the World
requirement_sentence: When we think about "the law," we tend to think about legal doctrine: written and somewhat rigid sets of procedures through which legal judgments are made. But when we approach the law historically, we see it as a process that changed over time under pressure from a range of forces: political, economic, social, and cultural; national, regional, and global; and driven by elites and people on the ground. The course is structured into three distinct units. Unit 1 addresses foundational inquiries pertaining to legal history. The objective of this unit is to establish a conceptual framework for analyzing law and legal orders in global perspective. Unit 2 investigates the interactions of law, society, and economy in a particular place and time, with emphasis on specific themes. Students will work with secondary literature, case studies, and primary sources. The content of Unit 2 varies, according to the research specialization and interests of the faculty member teaching the course. Unit 3 requires students to apply what they learned in Units 1 and 2 in a hands-on group project. In this iteration of HIST 210, taught by Professor Chris Suh, Unit 2 will focus on the topics of citizenship, civil rights, and precarity in the United States from the late 19th century to the present. Case studies will focus on Asian Americans' experiences with the law.

title: American Jewish History
professor: Eric L Goldstein egoldst@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 329 1) This course is a survey of the Jewish experience in America, examining the religious, cultural, political, and economic activities of American Jews from the colonial period to the present. Students will explore the ways Jewish tradition has adapted to America, how patterns of communal life have been transformed, what the relationship of American Jews has been to other Americans and to the international Jewish community, and how American Jewish identities have been created from Jews' dual impulses for integration and distinctiveness. We will also use the Jewish experience as a means of evaluating different definitions of American national identity.

title: The Making of Modern Africa
professor: Beverly Val Addo beverly.val-addo@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 221 1) (The media has often depicted Africa as a continent in turmoil, underlining military coups, war, famine, and disease. Yet those portrayals overlook the historical complexities that have led to current events. In this course, we aim to challenge limited narratives of Africa's contemporary realities by delving into the people, events, and processes that have shaped the continent. Given the vast size of Africa, the course will focus on specific themes and cases. These will include the end of the Atlantic slave trade and the transition to "legitimate" commerce; the motivations for and establishment of colonial rule; economic, social, and cultural transformations; African resistance to colonialism and decolonization; and post-colonial political trajectories. Altogether, this course examines the internal and external dynamics of change in Africa.)

title: Jews of Eastern Europe
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 338 1) (On the eve of the Holocaust, a majority of world Jewry lived in Eastern Europe, especially Poland and the USSR. This course explores the origins, dynamic growth, and near destruction of East European Jewry from the Middle Ages to the Holocaust and the challenges to Jewish life in this region in the post-WWII era. Many of the signature features of modern Jewish life - Hasidism, modern Jewish literature, Yiddish, Zionism, revolutionary socialism - derive from the centuries-long robust Jewish civilization in Eastern Europe.) (This course will make extensive use of primary documents - legal charters, memoirs, Hasidic tales, short stories, war reportage - to give us the tools to reconstruct this history together. We will also watch films and critically assess the recent Broadway versions of Fiddler on the Roof. As an add-on to this course, there is an optional 1-credit, twelve-day travel course to Poland, "Jews of Poland: History and Memory", which will be offered in May 2026.)

title: Making of Modern America: U.S. Since 1877
schedule_location: TTh 10am-11:15am in Math & Science Center - N302
requirement_sentence: (Same as AMST 285 1) (Between the end of Reconstruction and the early twenty-first century the United States became a great power and developed the strongest and wealthiest economy in the history of the world. This course will follow the nation's transformation from a farmers' republic to an industrial giant, demonstrating the interplay between its democratic institutions, its dynamic capitalist economy, and its diverse population. Themes include immigration, transport, political reform, changing ideas about gender and sexuality, the two world wars, the "rights" revolution of the 1950s and 1960s, the Cold War, and the United States' emergence as the sole post-Cold War superpower. Classes will be a mixture of lecture and discussion of assigned readings, with an emphasis on student participation. There will be two papers, a midterm, and a final exam.)

title: Topics: Black Cultural Movements: Black Renaissances
requirement_sentence: Same as ENG 389 1 Complete Title: Black Renaissances This course examines 2 of the most significant African American cultural movements of the 20th century - the New Negro Renaissance (aka the Harlem Renaissance, c. 1912-1932) and the Black Arts Movement (c. 1965-1979). While placing a primary emphasis on literary arts and authors, we will approach both movements as complex interdisciplinary, multi-generic phenomena concerned with Black freedom struggles. As we "map" the histories of these two major movements, we will consider the ways artists and critics alike have constructed these movements, the relationships of these movements to each other and to Black Studies, and the processes and politics that shape notions of literary history, race, gender, sexuality, and culture in American society.

title: Topics in Jewish Religion & Culture: Sacred Bioethics:Reprod.Tech.
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 358R 1, ANT 385 7, and HLTH 385 13) (Complete Topic: Sacred Bioethics: Ethnography, Religion and Assisted Reproductive Technology.) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Theme.) (We live in a world of increasing biotechnology. Surrogacy, IVF and the potential for cloning are just a few of the technologies that have raised important questions about how human beings reproduce as well as the costs and responsibilities associated with any creation of new life. Who should be considered the mother of a child born through gestational surrogacy? Is reproductive cloning a potentially exciting new technology or a nightmarish assault on what it means to be human? What, if any, limits should be placed on "reproductive tourism" in which women from poor countries bear children for women from rich ones? These are not simple questions.) (We also live in a world of deep religious and cultural diversity, in which biotechnology is used, interpreted and developed with the needs, concerns or values of different communities in mind. Though often portrayed as value-neutral, the science of reproduction cannot help but raise questions of value that cannot, by their nature, be adjudicated by science or medicine alone.)
