title: Topics in History and Text: African Hist: African Writings
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 270 1) (Complete topic is African History through African Writings) (The earliest histories of Africa were written from a Eurocentric perspective, privileging external interpretations over indigenous voices. This course challenges those dominant narratives by introducing students to the History of Sub-Saharan Africa through African literature. We will use African writings as a mirror through which we can examine the historical trajectory of Africa. At the heart of this course lies a central question: How did Africans make sense of their world? We will explore this by examining how Africans understood broader historical events such as Islamic and Atlantic slavery, colonialism, and decolonization and specific events such as the Biafran War and the independence of Ghana. We will take a chronological and thematic survey of African history considering issues such as racism, gender, war, and resistance, moving from the period before colonial incursion to the colonial and postcolonial periods. We will explore fiction and non-fiction works, including oral traditions put to text like the Epic of Sunjata and the works of colonial and postcolonial African writers such as Chinua Achebe, Ayi Kwei Armah, Wole Soyinka, Ngugi wa Thiong'o, Chimamanda Adichie, Camara Laye, Buchi Emecheta, among others. These texts will serve not only as literary artifacts but also as historical documents that illuminate African perspectives, epistemologies, and modes of resistance.)

title: Ecology of the Tropics Field Course
requirement_sentence: This course requires ENVS 371 or BIOL 371 as a prerequisite OR permission of instructor. (Same as ENVS 372 1) This 2-credit hour field course is part of the Office of International and Summer Programs (OISP) and will be taught during Spring Break week (March 6-15, 2026) in the Amazon River lowland rainforests of southern Peru (Tambopata Research Station), famous for its huge flocks of colorful Macaws. This field course will give the student a real hands-on rainforest experience, complete with bromeliads, toucans, sloths, and the sounds of the night. Graduating Seniors and students who have previously completed BIOL 371/ENVS 371 have priority for this course. Cost for the trip is approximately $3200 (depending on airfare prices). Permission of instructor is required. This course is taught by Dr. Lawrence Wilson (lwilso3@emory.edu; adjunct faculty), is SHARED by the Biology and Environmental Science Departments, and may be taken as elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the biology major. Biology majors may submit an application to Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu (and Leah Thomas in ENVS at leah.thomas@emory.edu for ENVS 372). Selected students will be notified and will have additional requirements by OISP. See the OISP website for additional information. Financial Aid scholarships from the Biology Department are available to eligible Biology majors who submit an application for the aid.

title: Topics in Afr American Studies: The Black Atlantic
requirement_sentence: Same as AFS 389 1 and ANT 385 6 Complete Title: Black Atlantic This class will explore and engage the histories, experiences, and political movements that have shaped the Black Atlantic world. Over the course of the semester, we will examine the origins of anti-Black racism and injustice in the Atlantic slave trade and African colonization. We will then interrogate more recent structures and experiences of racial oppression and inequality as well as the struggles for justice within Black communities that have emerged in response. Case studies will be drawn from Africa, the Americas, and Europe.

title: Special Topics in Biology: Marine Biology
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. In this course, students examine the physical and chemical aspects of the marine environment, with a heavy emphasis on ecology, biodiversity, evolution, conservation, and utilization of marine resources. Furthermore, students learn about human interaction with the oceans and the current threats faced by the distinct marine ecosystems. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L.

title: Topics in History and Text: Outsiders in Nazi Germany
professor: Astrid M. Eckert aeckert@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 280W 1) (This course analyses German society under Nazism, especially Nazi efforts to establish the utopia of a racially, socially, and physically homogenous society. The creation of this "people's community" was to be achieved by violently excluding people who were deemed "deviant" from the norms the Nazi Party was propagating. The class examines the interplay between inclusion and exclusion and hence the production of "outsiders". Topics in this class include the biologization of politics; the application and radicalization of "racial hygiene" (eugenics); the history of the autism diagnosis; the regime's ableism; the persecution of homosexuals; and the centrality of antisemitism to all social and political Nazi projects. These topics will be introduced by an overview of the political history and ideology of German culture from the 1920s to 1945. We will analyze written primary sources, film propaganda, and present-day reverberations of this history. This course fulfills the Emory College Continuing Communication and Writing Requirement.)

title: Topics in Jewish History: Women & Law, 1200-1800
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 385 1 and WGS 385 2) What forms did the relationship between gender and law take between 1200 and 1800? In this class, students explore this and related questions, assessing Christian and Jewish women¿s access to the law, their agency within legal processes, and their marginalization. Students engage with historical sources and draw on gender and legal studies, alongside various fields of history, to examine these questions as a lens into power relations and broader legal, religious, and social developments during this diverse period. We will also probe societies and communities and their evolution over time, tracing continuity and change in women¿s legal standing, and reflecting on women and the law in modern and contemporary societies. Some of the questions we will ask include: What is the relationship between law and lived legal experiences? What strategies did women develop to navigate legal situations that affected themselves, their families, and their communities? How did they engage with marriage and divorce laws, as well as matters related to family law and inheritance? Were women involved in crime, and were there particular crimes associated with women? Did the law hinder women¿s roles in business? While this class primarily focuses on Europe, we will also examine the diverse legal standings and lived experiences of Muslim women, drawing comparisons between Europe and the Middle East, including the Ottoman Empire.

title: Tropical Encounters
requirement_sentence: Complete topic: Tropical Encounters: World Travel & European Identities, 1750 to the Present. Innocent sexuality, savage violence, pure humanity? What did European travelers seek "and find" among the peoples of the South Pacific, South America, and Africa? Through lecture and discussion, original sources and works by historians, this course examines both the encounters with other peoples and cultures in parts of the world previously little known to Europeans, and the uses to which the resultant travel accounts were put in disputes surrounding notions of race, the nature of humankind, and the practice of politics back in Europe. It traces the connections between journeys of scientific exploration, European imperialism, and the emerging disciplines of ethnography and anthropology from the eighteenth century through the twentieth. In this Continuing Writing course, you will build up to analyzing a travel account yourself in a final research paper (10-12 pp.) and presentation; a short essay, two short reading analyses, and active participation round out the graded assessments.

title: Botanical Medicine & Health
requirement_sentence: (Same as HLTH 440 1 and ANT 440 1) (Mankind has long recognized that plants are extremely useful as a source of medicine. Medical traditions based on botanical drug sources can be found in all human cultures and date back to prehistory. In this course, both ancient and modern day botanical traditions across many cultures will be discussed as they pertain to medicine. The pathways through which natural drugs are made by plants and how they affect humans will be the focus of this class. Some examples include botanical drugs for infectious disease, cancer, cardiovascular health, dental health, central nervous system function, and much more. By the end of this course, you will have a solid understanding of the major botanical drugs, including their sources, applications, and cultural relevance.)

title: Computational Neuroscience
requirement_sentence: This course requires BIOL 360 or NBB 301 or IBS 514 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. The goal of this course is to provide students with a broad outline of ideas and current research areas in computational neuroscience, ranging from ion channels up to organismal behavior. Class meetings will consist of a combination of lectures and in-class computational exercises. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L. Although the class will be largely self-contained, a working knowledge of introductory calculus, statistics, linear algebra, and some exposure to differential equations will be helpful (although a mathematical review will be provided). Knowing some neuroscience may also be helpful, but it is not required. Although most of the course will be taught in Matlab, only a working knowledge of basic programming control structures (e.g., for/while loops & if/then structures, etc.) is necessary, as we will devote time to coding tutorials at the beginning of the semester. If you have some coding experience but have learned R or C or Java or python, you should be fine. (This course is also taught as IBS 534.)

title: Topics in Jewish History: European Jews, 1492-1800
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 496W 1) How did an ethnic and religious minority in Europe experience the tumultuous years between 1492 and 1800, known as the early modern period? In this research seminar, students will take a deep dive into the history of European Jews, their relationships and interactions with majority societies, and the profound cultural, geopolitical, legal, religious, and scientific transformations that shaped this remarkable era in European and global history. We will therefore also use Jewish history to illuminate the histories of majority Christian societies. Students will explore themes such as expulsions, mass conversions, persecution, the print and scientific revolutions, the development of Jewish legal systems and Jewish engagement with non-Jewish law, conceptions of self and communal identity, messianism, the Reformations and the Thirty Years' War, mercantilism, and Jewish encounters with the Americas. The course compares Ashkenazi and Sephardi histories while rethinking the complex questions of minority belonging and exclusion. Students will strengthen their ability to analyze a variety of historical sources, including those produced by Jews as well as Christian sources that discuss Jewish life and culture. Students will apply their skills to write a 15-20-page research paper.

title: Topics in Afr American Studies: Black Feminist Geographies
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 385W 4) (Spatial matters are integral to racial, gendered, and sexual politics. How black peoples move through, encounter, and experience space is directly connected to imperial and colonial logics at play. This course will explore how socio-spatial relations of power function on the gendered racial body, connecting the relationship between everyday spaces and distant, but interconnected places across the African America(s). Across multiple modes of analysis, visual, poetic, textual, and archival, we will examine how power simultaneously functions on the site of the body or self, and in race, gender, class, and sexual meanings and collective struggles. This course traces the conversations and dialogues on the ways race, gender, sexuality, and other axis of difference scaffold the everyday world, how belonging is intimately connected to an investigation of the Human, and how these spatial mechanisms of captivity also form the grounds for fugitive acts, (il)legible space and land relations, and refusals in which Black peoples (de)construct and imagine. We will also draw from interdisciplinary feminist perspectives that examine the ways the axis of power operates at multiple levels, across the boundaries of the body, the "home" , the borders of the nation, and undergird settler colonial and imperial formations. These "demonic grounds" (McKittrick 2006) also form the terrain for new coordinates of being in the world.)

title: Pop Biology & Evolution Of Disease
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. (Same as DATASCI 463 1) (Students must also register for the Biology 463 Discussion Section. This course will look at infectious disease spread and evolution from a population perspective at various biological scales. The following scales will be considered: (1) the population biology of infectious disease transmission, its control by vaccination, and evolution of disease at the population level; (2) impact of pathogen interactions and multiple hosts on infectious disease circulation; (3) population dynamics and pathogen evolution at the transmission event; (4) within-host population dynamics of infectious diseases; (5) replication dynamics of pathogens within cells. The class will focus on the design, simulation, and application of quantitative models to understand these infectious disease population dynamics and evolutionary dynamics. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L.)

title: Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
ger: Humanities and Arts with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 268 1, POLS 268 1, MESAS 268 1) The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Political Struggles, Personal Histories gives students an overview of Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the 1880s on through today. It introduces students to early Zionist debates and the late Ottoman context before moving on to discuss violence during the British Mandate period, the rise of the State of Israel, and the reappearance of the Palestinian cause on the world stage after the 1967 war. The course will include sessions that examine previous bouts of armed conflict as well as various attempts at peace, but war and politics will not be the course's only foci; the lived experiences of Palestinians and Israelis will also receive significant attention, from historical times through the present day. These voices include a young Jewish female spy who helped the British defeat the Ottoman Empire; an Islamist rebel whose death inspired the Great Arab Revolt of the 1930s; a Holocaust survivor who fought in the 1948 war before becoming Israel's leading poet; girls whose families fled from Jerusalem and Libya, and grew up amidst poverty and war; a U.S.-trained heart surgeon-turned-PLO militant who was assassinated in his quest for peace, and many others.

title: Personality Theories
requirement_sentence: (OPUS waitlist activates at the beginning of add/drop/swap.) (Prior completion of Psyc 110, 111, or AP/IB credit in Psychology.) (This is a survey course covering psychological theory, history, and research in the area of personality. Topics such as controversies in the field of personality assessment, cognitive and biological influences on personality, genetics and personality and gender differences in personality will be covered.)

title: Gender, Science and Health
requirement_sentence: The science of gender slowly and unevenly moves from the lab to the clinic. Healthcare access, effective diagnosis, and treatment depend on clinicians, use of masculinity, femininity, and forms of non-binary gender identity. This class examines the experiences of patients as they navigate illness and health. By studying how healthcare providers and researchers seek to understand gender and deploy gender identity in delivering care, students explore the life-and-death stakes of cultural investments in gender and health. Readings and course material will juxtapose health systems across a range of historical periods and geographic settings so that students may compare and contrast gender normalization from one setting to the next.

title: Psychology of Prejudice
requirement_sentence: PSYC 110 or PSYC_OX 110 or PSYC 111 or PSYC_OX 111 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Prior completion of PSYC 110 or PSYC 111 or AP/IB credit in psychology. PSYC333 is a LINC class; we will be collaborating with Dr. Susan Tamasi's Language Prejudice course (LING342).

title: Women and the Law
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 385 3, CPLT 389 2, and PHIL 385 2) (Women and the Law: historically, politically, and socio-culturally, these two terms have a long-standing relationship with one another. They shape one another inasmuch the latter has also historically enervated the former's rights and possibilities. Similarly, the two terms, "woman" and "law," are often contested terrains in regards to their respective meaning, interpreting the ways in which they have been constructed, and their roles in culture, society, and the unconscious. These moments are even more intensified in the ways they have been racialized and stand within a longer racial history of terror. To this extent, the course begins by examining the racial construction of gender and how the law becomes a tool of racial, ethnic, sexual, and gender repression. It will explore cases in slave law to broaden its view on constitutional and statute law as well as other concepts of laws (e.g. psychic, notions of sexual difference, aesthetic). Throughout, attention will be given to film and media representations of law, gender, and race to consider our course explorations. The course centers black feminist thought and critical race theory as its main analytic lens, and will examine how these two intellectual and political traditions remain critical in our contemporary landscape.)

Students will complete at-home practice with the required online textbook and platform: Atelier-MindTap. Please note: FREN 102 is open to students who have had some French (FREN 101 or up to two years in high school). Language placement results must be provided to the instructor. Waitlists will open for the course during the add/drop period at the beginning of the semester.

title: The Genetics of Human Behavior
requirement_sentence: QTM 100 or QTM_OX 100 or ECON 220 or ECON_OX 220 or ISOM 350 or POLS 310 or POLS 310W or MATH_OX 117 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (In this course we will examine the underlying causes of human behavior and traits, focusing particularly on the use of quantitative genetic methods (i.e, twin and adoption studies) to disentangle genetic and environmental influences. We also will review molecular genetic methods for finding specific genes that underlie behavior. We will begin by reviewing the historical backdrop to behavior genetics, including a focus on Charles Darwin, Francis Galton, and Gregor Mendel. We will proceed to examine the use of twin and adoption studies to disentangle genetic and environmental influences, and the advantages of these methods over family studies. We will then review various molecular genetic methods for finding specific genes. We will end by exploring the results of quantitative and molecular genetic studies of various forms of psychopathology, personality, and behavior. Textbook: Behavioral Genetics / Edition 7; Publication Date:10/02/2016; Publisher: Worth by Valerie S. Knopik, Jenae M. Neiderhiser, John C. DeFries, Robert Plomin, Charles Darwin. On the Origin of Species; either hard copy or pdf posted to Canvas.)

title: Encounters with Art & Arch II
requirement_sentence: One hundred compelling works of art form the nucleus of "Encounters with Art & Architecture II," an innovative course addressing key issues in the history of art and architecture. Why is a picture worth a thousand words? What makes a building political? How does a statue represent cultural ideals? What is art, anyway? Encounters encourages us to look both at and beneath the surface to question appearances, challenge preconceptions, and seize the significance of the smallest detail when engaging with art and architecture. In Encounters with Art & Architecture, every member of the Art History faculty lectures in their area of expertise on several of their favorite things. By hearing so many voices, you'll gain an appreciation for the variety of approaches we take to understand human creativity in visual and spatial form. In weekly discussion sections, you'll talk about what you've learned and encounter works of art in person during visits to the Carlos Museum and the Rose Library. "Encounters Part II" introduces images, objects, and buildings produced from the seventeenth century to the present day, in Europe, Africa, and North America. Art History major/minor: core requirement

title: Spec Topics: Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies: Trans Cultures in the US
requirement_sentence: Trans Cultures in the US: We often hear talk of "trans community," "trans culture," and "trans people" today; yet, before the late 1990s, there was no concept of a shared trans community, culture, or politics in the US. Instead, what we might retrospectively identify as trans cultures were dramatically divided along lines of sexuality, gender, class, and race. Pre-1990s trans cultures differed in their understandings of what it meant to be trans, interactions with trans medicine, and political interests. Today, a discourse of shared trans community, culture, and politics tends to obfuscate the persistence of divisions of race, class, gender, and sexuality between trans people and trans cultures. This course will introduce students to the pre-1990s cultures of working-class transfeminine street queens and drag queens, working-class Black and Latina ballroom femme queens, white, upper-middle class heterosexual cross-dressers, transsexual women desperately trying to stave off downward mobility, working-class butches, and passing men. We will analyze what happened during the 1990s to create a shared "trans community," and whose class and race interests won out in this process. We explore a wide genre of artifacts to get to know these trans cultures including oral histories, autobiographies, magazines, documentaries, ethnographies, sociological reports, and medical texts.

title: Intermediate French I
schedule_location: TTh 10am-11:15am in Candler Library 123 F 10am-10:50am in ONLINE
requirement_sentence: FREN 201 Intermediate French I (Prof. Vincent Bornert / TTh 10:00-11:15am; F 10:00-10:50am online synchronous). Content: The course seeks to expand upon previous French courses by introducing students to new vocabulary, new grammar structures, and more challenging cultural material that will provide a better sense of the diversity of the Francophone world. In the context of the manual « Imaginez, 5th edition », and its fully integrated accompanying literary and cultural texts, audio recordings and songs, videos and short films, students get an in-depth review of the basic patterns and structures of French. During this journey to different parts of the French-speaking world, students have the opportunity to reactivate their previous knowledge of the language and to expand upon that base so that they can communicate with confidence. Required Textbooks, Articles, and Resources: Champeny, Séverine, "IMAGINEZ: le français sans frontières, 5th Edition". Vista Higher Learning, 2020. ISBN: 978-1-54330-546-3. Students will need the supersite access code. May be purchased via the VHL website or Emory bookstore. Additional Resources: 'IMAGINEZ' Supersite, vhlcentral.com, and Student Activities Manual Course Requisites FREN 102 as prerequisite, or by placement exam.)

title: Great Buildings
professor: Sarah C. McPhee smcphee@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (This course is part of Emory's Voluntary Core Curriculum program) Much of our life experience is shaped by buildings. The greatest of them stand as icons of their respective cultures, embodying religious, social, and political ideals; economic and technological realities; and aesthetic aspirations. In this course we explore some of the greatest buildings of world architecture from ancient Egypt to the twentieth century. With a single building, or group of buildings, as the focal point of each lecture, we will move through time considering issues such as: materials, massing, and monumentality; the Vitruvian triad of firmitas, utilitas et venustas (strength, utility, and delight); gravity-defying Gothic structures; domes and their reinvention; the aesthetics of technological innovation; the myriad directions of contemporary design. The subject is vast. Rather than trace a linear history we have selected major monuments that drive the development of architecture. These are the buildings you know by sight but will come to understand in depth. Architectural Studies minor: core requirement or elective Art History major/minor: makers & materials course

title: Spec Topics: Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies: Queer Asian American Studies
requirement_sentence: (Same as EAS 385W 1) (Studies of queer Asian America span an immense diversity of histories and lived experiences and reflect the vast interdisciplinarity of their practitioners. They often combine political, artistic, and/or cultural work with more conventional modes of academic production. This course will engage a broad range of genres that shape, express, and analyze queer life in Asian America (including drag, poetry, ethnography, film, and theory). It will also consider how transnational lives involve processes of translation and layered identification that complicate queerness itself, questioning the adequacy of globalized terms for genders and sexualities.)

title: Freshman Seminar:Art History: Maps: Finding Our Place...
professor: Susan Elizabeth Gagliardi susan.e.gagliardi@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Maps: Finding Our Place in the World (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) In this first-year seminar, we will investigate maps and mapmaking in order to think about what maps are, how they are made, and how they operate in different times and places. We will study histories of cartography as well as reflect on the role of art and science in cartographic practice. We will also consider how maps, other images, and texts convey understandings about and claims to spaces and places. We will look closely at, read about, discuss, and write about maps, other images, and texts linked to different parts of the world. Through class discussions and activities, we will examine how maps can reflect, produce, and reinforce unequal power relations yet also envision better futures. The seminar requires curiosity, a willingness to be creative, an eagerness to exchange and discuss informed ideas with respect, and careful attention to assignments. The seminar is not a lecture course, and it requires no previous study of art history, history, or geography.

title: Intermediate French II
schedule_location: MW 1pm-2:15pm in Candler Library 123 F 1pm-1:50pm in ONLINE
requirement_sentence: FREN 203 Intermediate French II (Prof. Vincent Bornert / MW 1:00-2:15PM; F 1:00-1:50PM online synchronous). Content: In French 203, students develop interpretive strategies and review and practice grammatical forms in the context of authentic literary and cultural texts. Class activities are designed to improve students' abilities in the communicative and presentational modes. There will be frequent written reactions to authentic materials. Viewing of French films will provide the opportunity for extended oral analysis and discussion. French 203 counts towards the minor in French but not the major. Assessment: Grading will be based on written unit tests, compositions, oral presentations, class participation. Required Textbooks, Articles, and Resources: Required: Dãfi Francophone 2: 6 month My French H (ISBN 9788419072733); Optional: Dãfi Francophone 2: Student Bundle 12 month (ISBN 9788419072764. Course Requisites FREN 201 as prerequisite, or by placement exam.

title: Rhetorical Composition/Critical Reading
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Only) Writing in the City From graffiti scrawled on highway overpasses, advertisements on buses, op-eds in local papers, to books on urban theory, the city is a locus of writing. In this course, students will learn key components of composition by exploring writing of and about city environments, with a focus on our city, Atlanta, in particular. Students will learn about Atlanta in the post-Reconstruction era up to the present as well as the history of select places within the city. By reading diverse modes of writing of and about urban environments, students will be invited to reflect upon their embodied relationship to writing, place, and the connection between the two. Major assignments include weekly short writing assignments, a personal narrative, an inquiry-based research paper, a multimodal remix, paper revisions, and reflections.

Students will learn about Atlanta in the post-Reconstruction era up to the present as well as the history of select places within the city. By reading diverse modes of writing of and about urban environments, students will be invited to reflect upon their embodied relationship to writing, place, and the connection between the two. Major assignments include weekly short writing assignments, a personal narrative, an inquiry-based research paper, a multimodal remix, paper revisions, and reflections.

title: Architectural Design Studio
schedule_location: Th 1pm-5pm in VISUAL ARTS BUILIDING TBA
requirement_sentence: Architectural Design Studio: Visionary Architecture Some of the most extraordinary designs in architecture are not made to be built. Because they can only exist in drawings, they are often referred to as "paper architecture." But these unbuildable designs perform important roles that built ones cannot. Because they see beyond the limits of their time and circumstances, they are also known as ¿visionary architecture¿. They are free experiments, speculations, statements, illustrations, and critiques in the form of imaginary spaces. They transform design tools into unique means of analysis, thought, and representation. They explore different cultural, historical, socio-political, aesthetic, and critical dimensions of the built environment. They create unreal worlds that defy the limits of what ours can become. In this advanced studio, we will explore centuries of such incredible designs, and you will have the opportunity to create a visionary architecture of your own. For permission contact instructor: andre.patrao@emory.edu Architectural Studies minor: elective or makers Art History major/minor: makers & materials course

title: Rhetorical Studies
requirement_sentence: The Rhetoric of Greece and Rome Have you ever imagined yourself giving eloquent speeches? Or writing elegant and moving prose encouraging others to action? Have you ever wished your social media posts got more engagement, or that you could persuade your relatives to reconsider their political beliefs? If so, the study of rhetoric (historically understood as the art of persuasion) can help! In this writing course, students will deepen their understanding of the art of persuasion by exploring the history of rhetoric in the ancient Greco-Roman tradition. Studying the theory and practice of rhetoric performed in that place and time will give students insight into how rhetoric is practiced today, in everything from political speeches to memes. They will learn what impact the theory and practice of rhetoric might have on their own lives, becoming savvy about their own attempts to inform, impress, persuade, and enact purposes and values within their own rhetorical situations. Assignments include including written reflections on ancient texts, giving persuasive speeches, and a portfolio accompanied by a summative letter.

title: Art & Architecture of Ancient Rome
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 222 1) Roman civilization, from the Republican through the Imperial periods, transformed the art and architecture of the ancient Mediterranean. Innovations in engineering and technique, the introduction of new materials (like concrete), and the Roman genius for cultural assimilation all combined to create an art which was exciting as well as eclectic. Indeed, Roman art has often been characterized as the first truly modern art. The course will investigate the ways in which major achievements in sculpture, painting, numismatic and glyptic art, as well as architecture often reflected contemporary developments in Roman politics, society and religion. In addition the course will explore the relationship of works of art and architecture erected in the city of Rome to those in the provinces, the interaction of public and official art to domestic art, as well as the impact of art commissioned by imperial and elite patrons on that commissioned by non-elite patrons. Art History major/minor: Division I Architectural Studies minor: elective

title: Intersections
requirement_sentence: FREN 341/AFS 312. Intersections: "Women and War" (Prof. Xavier / Tuesdays/Thursdays 1:00-2:15pm). Content: This course will consider and analyze women's roles in resistance, collaboration, witness and testimony during major conflicts of the last century: WWII, the Sino-Japanese War, the Algerian War, the American-Vietnam War, the Rwandan Genocide. Working through historical fiction written and/or directed by women, students will study the ways in which gender, memory, trauma, and political agency are represented and redrawn in times of war. Through close readings of novels, films, and memoirs, students will explore how women's voices not only refuse dominant historical narratives, but confront the brutality of violence to demand justice and repair. This course is taught in English, but students will have the option to read works in their original French or in English translation. Books: Marguerite Duras, The War: A Memoir (1985) Assia Djebar, Children of the New World: A Novel of the Algerian War (1962) Véronique Tadjo, The Shadow of Imana: Travels in the Heart of Rwanda (2000) Scholastique Mukasonga, Igifu (2020) Shan Sa, The Girl Who Played Go (2001) Kim Thuy, Em (2020) Films: Marguerite Duras, Hiroshima mon amour (1959) Assia Djebar, La Nouba des Femmes du Mont Chenoua (1977) Kimberlee Acquaro and Stacy Sherman, God Sleeps in Rwanda (2005) Trinh T. Minh-ha, Forgetting Vietnam (2015) Tiffany Hsiung, Within Every Woman (2012)

title: Sem: Personality & Social Psych: American Film in 1970s -Indiv vs Col. Ident
requirement_sentence: Important psychological characteristics of individuals, and of the time and place that they live, are often reflected in and inspired by media such as literature, art, and film. In this course we will examine the tension between Individualist versus Collectivist identities in American films of the 1970s. This was a particularly fruitful period for such exploration given the vast societal changes and social upheaval that took place in American society at the time and the ways in which it motivated individuals to rethink the possibilities for the various aspects of their identities. Together we will view a selection of films that illustrate the tension between these aspects of individuals' identities, with a particular focus on Individualist versus Collectivist identities. In addition to looking back on the 1970s we will discuss the applicability of this tension to present-day American society and current events.

title: Northern Renaissance Art
professor: Walter S Melion wsmelio@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: The course examines innovations in painting, sculpture, and printmaking of the Low Countries and Southern Germany between 1400 and 1600, focusing on masters such as Jan van Eyck, Rogier van der Weyden, Dieric Bouts, Hugo van der Goes, Gerard David, Albrecht Dürer, Matthias Grünewald, Hans Holbein, Hieronymus Bosch, Joachim Patinir, Jan Gossaert, Joos van Cleve, Pieter Aertsen, and Pieter Bruegel. We shall address the following topics: the development of canons of verisimilar imitation, and specifically of the notion that painting as a mirror of nature, in the new medium of oil-based pigment; the devotional functions of pictorial images, in particular their use as instruments of soul formation and as meditators between corporeal and spiritual sight; the hermeneutics of viewing, that is, the ways in which pictures structure processes of interpretation - heuristic, exegetical, paraphrastic, etc.; the rise of new pictorial genres, such as the so-called world landscape, the market scene, and the peasant festivity; and differences in the manner and meaning of art in the Low Countries and Germany before and after the Reformation. Art History major/minor: Division II

title: Rhetorics of Resistance
requirement_sentence: This is an English Language Learner (ELL) course. Contact Jane O'Connor (jcoconn@emory.edu) for permission to enroll. Language, Land, & Place This course offers an introduction to various nonfiction genres (including flash nonfiction, photo-essay, and personal essay) and approaches to writing that destabilize standard academic English (including Indigenous language reclamation, multilingualism, and translingualism). We will read and discuss a range of scholarship in Black, Indigenous, Asian/American, and Latinx/Latine rhetoric, writing, and literacy; ground ourselves in our shared contexts of Atlanta and the larger Southeast; and develop shared practices of land- and place-based writing.

title: Science & the Nature of Evidence
requirement_sentence: We live in an era where data is one of the most valuable currencies. It shapes how companies see us, what they predict we'll buy, and even what keeps us scrolling. Big Data is at the core of many digital experiences, especially through recommendation systems, whether it's Netflix suggesting your next binge, Amazon curating your shopping list, or TikTok tailoring your For You page. But while these algorithms make life convenient, they also raise major ethical concerns around privacy, bias, and digital autonomy. This course will explore both the technical foundations of algorithms and their broader social implications. We'll break down how these systems work while also looking at how business incentives shape what gets recommended. While technical expertise isn't required, students who want to dive deeper into the computational or mathematical aspects can do so through projects and assignments.

title: Media and Genres
requirement_sentence: FREN 310 or FREN_OX 310 and FREN 314 or FREN_OX 314 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. FREN 351: Media and Genres: Autofiction / Vivre l'autofiction (Prof. Giguere / Mondays/Wednesdays 11:30am-12:45pm). Content: While personal narratives that blend fact and fiction existed well before the term autofiction was coined in 1977, in this course we will consider the reasons why this genre has become ubiquitous in French and Francophone cultural and literary spheres of the 20th and 21st centuries. We will focus on the genre's flexibility and capacity to 1) communicate individual experiences as they relate to powerful, painful, and liberating social, political, and historical events and 2) communicate the complexity of these experiences not just through writing but across different media including graphic novels, photography, film, music, interviews, and social media. Primary Works; Perec, W ou le souvenir denfance Ernaux, Lévénement Faye, Petit pays Varda, Les plages dAgnès Supplementary texts may include excerpts/ short works by Barthes, Duras, Doubrovsky, Calle, Guibert, Satrapi, Darrieussecq (among others). Course Expectations and Assignments: - Active participation - Readings and collaborative [student and instructor generated] study guides for most sessions - One presentation - 2 short papers with drafts (4-5 pages) - 3 in-class responses (1-2 pages) - Final collaborative, multi-media class project

requirement_sentence: CHEM 141 or CHEM_OX 141 or CHEM 150L or CHEM_OX 150L as a prerequisite and CHEM 202 or CHEM_OX 202 as a corequisite. title: Contemporary Europe and America
requirement_sentence: This course provides a critical survey of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of European and American art after World War II. Special attention will be given to crucial problems like the relation of art to politics; art's response to mass media and technologies, consumer culture, and globalization; and the redefinition of artistic means. More broadly, we will study fundamental tools for examining works of art formally, historically, and critically. The course is not intended as a comprehensive survey of art after 1945; rather, it will address the complex set of aesthetic, philosophical, and political motivations that shaped the artistic production of select figures and movements, including Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Minimalism, Institution Critique, and Performance Art. Art History major/minor: Division III

title: English for ETSI Students
requirement_sentence: This is an English Language Learner (ELL) course. Contact Jane O'Connor (jcoconn@emory.edu) for permission to enroll. This three-credit hour class is to be repeated over four semesters for the two-year duration that you attend Emory. The class is designed specifically to support you in developing your academic and informal/social English language proficiency through authentic materials. You will develop and practice your English language skills by reading, listening to, and interpreting diverse texts, engaging in discussions and performing various other activities both inside and outside of the classroom. In addition, it will introduce you to life in America and American culture, history, and traditions through expert guest speakers. Each of you will also be paired with a writing center tutor and conversation partner for extra practice outside of the classroom.

title: Directed Research
requirement_sentence: Pre-requisite: PSYC 495A. Permission is required for enrollment.

title: Advanced Reactivity
requirement_sentence: CHEM 202 or CHEM_OX 202 or CHEM 202Z or CHEM 221 or CHEM_OX 221 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This course is NOT intended for students who took Chem 202Z in fall 2024; those students should take Chem 203Z.

title: Visual Culture
requirement_sentence: We live in a culture that is saturated by visual images. It is vital to understand what forces shape visual culture and how it shapes our thinking about a myriad of topics such as politics, race, religion, class, and gender. In this class we will explore the ways visual culture is produced, circulated, and consumed. We will examine visual culture in multiple mediums including art, architecture, photography, comics, digital media, advertising, and television. We will begin by studying the major theories behind visual culture. We will consider how issues of authority, power, and positionality shape the creation and interpretation of visual images. Students will become adept at "reading" visual images in the same way they read other texts, and the discussion-based course will give students ample opportunity to hone this skill.

title: Francophone Studies
professor: Johanna Montlouis Gabriel johanna.montlouis-gabriel@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: FREN 310 or FREN_OX 310 and FREN 314 or FREN_OX 314 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (Same as AFS 389 5) FREN 391R: Interdisciplinary Arts as Healing Practice (Prof. Montlouis-Gabriel / Tuesdays/Thursdays 10:00-11:15AM). Content: As Fabienne Kanor reflects in an interview: "J'ai mal à mon histoire et la réécrire est le seul moyen que j'ai trouvé pour guérir un peu" ("My history hurts me, and rewriting it is the only way I have found to heal a little"). This course takes up Kanor's insight as its guiding principle, exploring how artistic creation becomes a pathway to healing from historical trauma. How do artists transform pain into power? How can creativity help us heal from historical trauma and imagine new possibilities? This course invites you to explore how predominantly Black women artists and artists featuring Black women characters across the francophone world (from Senegal to Martinique, France to Vietnam, Cameroon to Reunion Island) use film, literature, poetry, performance, and visual arts as tools for healing and resistance. Through hands-on creative projects and rigorous literary and cultural analysis, you'll develop your own practice while learning concepts like "cartographies of memory" and "aquatic metaphors" as ways to understand healing journeys across the diasporas. You'll collaborate with visiting artist TIE on her project "Odyssey in Black Utero," exploring how art creates healing pathways between past and future. Your final project? Create your own "map to elsewhere" a creative work that visualizes connections between historical memory and imagined futures. No prior art experience necessary: just curiosity and openness to creative exploration. Texts may include: Fabienne Kanor, Humus (excerpts) Léonora Miano, La saison de lOmbre Nadia Chonville, Mon coeur bat vite Maryse Condé, Moi, Tituba sorcière de Salem (excerpts) Alice Diop, Saint-Omer (film) Mati Diop, Atlantics (film) Alain Gomis, Félicité (film) Jean-Pierre Bekolo, Les Saignantes (film) Eva Doumbia, Autophagies (Theater) TIE, Odyssey in Black Utero (collaborative project)

title: Perspectives on Non-Western Art Topics: Art, Data, and Museums
professor: Susan Elizabeth Gagliardi susan.e.gagliardi@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 270W 1) We will think carefully about art, data, and their intersections. We will reflect on what data are, and we will also examine how data about art are often captured, parsed, and presented in museums, on maps, and in other places and formats. We will consider how space and place shape data as well as how data shape human experiences of space and place. In addition, we will think about how artists and other makers center data in their creative processes. Our studies of art and data will draw on specific examples linked to Africa and other geographies at different moments in time. Yet, the relevance of our investigations transcends any single geography or time period. And as a course in the humanities, we will also reflect on what it means for any person, whether from here and now or another place and time, to be human; to embrace our shared humanity; and to engage with digital technologies. The course is designed for curious students eager to reflect on what art and data can teach us about past and present human experiences and the world. The course features creative assignments. It also relies on students' deep reading, close looking, attentive listening, engaged discussion, and mutual respect; it is not a lecture course. Attention to wellbeing constitutes another aspect of the course design. No prior knowledge of Africa, art, art history, data, or design is necessary; all you need is a drive to learn and commitment to completing coursework.

title: Public Science Communication
requirement_sentence: We will explore some key genres and styles of social science writing for the public. Through a series of small, multimodal writing and communication assignments, we will focus on matters of style: citation, perspective, verbs, conciseness and clarity, translation of academic research into lay language, etc. Short assignments will vary, e.g., informal, in-class freewriting; formal email; interviews and interview notes, etc. Students will not be conducting firsthand research but will be researching secondary literature, interviewing experts and perhaps community members or stakeholders, & translating these voices into finished assignments suitable for lay audiences. The course will have two major assignments on the same topic of scientific research: a live presentation and a written or recorded version of a project. Students will be encouraged to choose a topic of scientific research that relates to a community of which they are a part, and a topic, moreover, that has not been communicated clearly to the publics who have a stake in this scientific knowledge. Students will write with a particular audience in mind and though not a requirement possible venues for publication, and may be encouraged to pursue this goal beyond the end of the course. The class will conclude with students' self-reflection on their writing, in terms of three course outcomes: critical thinking, writing for a particular audience & purpose, & development of writing process.

title: Introduction to American Studies
requirement_sentence: Through an interdisciplinary exploration combining social sciences, sciences, and humanities disciplines and methodologies, we will engage in creative and intellectually rigorous conversation about the human experience, while writing our own stories in the process. This course will progress through separate topical units centered around three core questions: -How do we understand ourselves? Why is it difficult to define what is human? Why do we need to think of humanity as a problem? -Human compared to what? Here we seek to further illustrate what makes humanity distinct through a comparative lens. What is a human compared to an animal, a robot, or even, considering our strange relationship to the nation-state, a citizen? In doing this, we will think deeply about how humanity defines itself through and against its own narratives of power and dominance. -Where are we going? In addressing this question, we will attempt to work through some of the largest existential threats to humankind and determine two things: How do different disciplines tackle these issues? And can these disciplines work together to solve them?

title: Topics in French: Hauntings
requirement_sentence: FREN 310, FREN 314 and two 300 level FREN courses, or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. FREN 488. Hauntings: Literature, Psychoanalysis, Film Prof. Claire Nouvet / Mondays and Wednesdays, 1:00-2:15PM. Content: With the study of hysteria, Freud discovered the process of repression and elaborated the concept of the unconscious. The unconscious, however, does not rest quietly. It returns to haunt the present through various disruptions that conscious thought does not know how to explain to itself: slips of the tongue, dreams, phobias, anxieties, delusions. If we learn from psychoanalysis that a past that has been repressed can return to disrupt the present, literature, for its part, has its own way of staging these uncanny returns. What comes back under the figures of the ghosts, vampires, and witches that haunt the literary stage? How do traumatic histories haunt the next generations? And what happens to those who incarnate past histories that the present prefers to forget? These are some of the questions that we will address at the juncture of literature, psychoanalysis and film. Special attention will be given to the way psychoanalysis addresses the issue of trauma not only at the individual level but also at the collective level: transgenerational transmission of historical traumas. Texts may include: Freud: Introductory Lectures [selections] Studies in Hysteria [selections] Delusion and Dream in Wilhelm Jensen's Gradiva Balzac: Adieu Jules Barbey d'Aurevilly: Diaboliques Duras: Hiroshima, mon amour [film] Gauthier: Arria Marcella Michelet: La Sorcière Davoine and Gaudillard: History Beyond Trauma [selections]

title: Special Topics in Philosophy: Critical Black Thought
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 385 2) (What is black existence? Can we imagine black existence without reason, the transparent subject, formalized schemes of knowledge, and being? How has anti-blackness (de)structured our relationship to time, space, and thinking? Is it time to abandon the human as an organizing concept for liberation and freedom? Using black psychoanalysis, black feminist poethics, ecological studies, Afro-pessimism, semiotics, black humanism, and black theology, we will address these concerns. Ultimately, we will sketch the infrastructure of black thought and evaluate the efficacy of various methodologies and noetic practices. This course will celebrate (and critically evaluate) the beauty of black thinking, its innovation, and development. The reading is primarily philosophical and theoretical (with artistic and cinematic engagements).

title: East Asian Art & Culture
requirement_sentence: (Same as EAS 292 1) (This course introduces the arts of East Asia through focused case studies. We will explore tombs in which creative imaginations of afterlives were materialized, paintings and calligraphies that embodied kinesthetic energy, religious monuments that witnessed dynamic cross-cultural exchanges, and modern and contemporary artworks that captured the lived experiences of different communities in East Asia. The objects and sites under consideration both highlight cultural communications and address the distinctive identities of each tradition. Students will also explore East Asian artworks from local museum collections.) (Art History major/minor: Division II or IV)

title: Writing Amid Disinformation
requirement_sentence: Writing Amid Mis/DisInformation Doom scrolling might feel passive, but it demands constantly sorting through arguments of dubious credibility. Data-driven algorithms serve us information based on assumptions about associations that shape our points of view. Comments draw trolls who parrot talking points, equivocate, and gleefully misidentify fallacies increasingly, they're not even real people. Where are we to turn, as readers and writers, when faced with such erosions of trust and community? This course considers the usefulness of confronting mis/disinformation with rhetoric, which beyond persuasion, studies how language affects action. We will apply frameworks for evaluating arguments and information critically yet generously, while identifying rhetorical tactics and analyzing the role of sources, facts, and expertise. Readings and discussions will introduce representational ethics and reflect on when debate is worthwhile, given good/bad faith, alongside alternatives to agonism like listening and mutual vulnerability. Students will practice narrative and analytical writing assignments attentive to differences of perspective, evidentiary logics, and multiple affected communities.

title: Intro.Interdisciplinary Topics: Ecological Visions Spec.Fic.
requirement_sentence: Ecological Visions in Speculative Fiction (Same as FILM 286 1) This interdisciplinary course explores the intersections of ecology and speculative fiction across film, literature, and television. Students will examine how speculative narratives imagine the future of the planet, human-nature relationships, ecological justice, and the consequences of environmental degradation. With a particular focus on science fiction, the course also draws from climate fiction (cli-fi), Afrofuturism, and eco-horror, the course invites students to analyze how speculative storytelling critiques dominant environmental ideologies and proposes alternative ecological futures. We will investigate the narrative strategies used to render environmental crisis visible and consider the cultural and philosophical implications of these imagined worlds.

title: Spec Stud:Ancient Egyptian Art: Egypt. Art Crossroad of Cult.
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 329 1) "Egyptian Art in the Greek and Roman Periods: Crossroads of Cultures"This course examines ancient Egyptian art produced between approximately 332 BCE and the end of the fourth century CE, a period when Egypt was governed by Greek and Roman rulers. Although often overshadowed by the artistic achievements of earlier times, the visual culture of Greek and Roman Egypt offers vital insights into how art functions as a medium for expressing identity, negotiating power, and navigating cultural boundaries. Far from being a time of decline, these periods witnessed the construction of great temples, the creation of new works that fused indigenous Egyptian forms with the styles and mediums of Greek and Roman art, and the production more mummies than any other time in Egyptian history. Through close analysis of sculpture, architecture, painting, and funerary art, this course will explore the resilience and dynamism of Egyptian cultural identity in a cosmopolitan world.

title: Technical Writing
requirement_sentence: (Same as DATASCI 302W 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Juniors and seniors with declared majors or minors offered by the Department of Data and Decision Sciences or the Writing (RWID) Program will receive permission codes for this course prior to the pre-registration period. DATASCI and RWID students must use the provided code to enroll during their assigned registration period. Enrollment will be on a first-come, first-served basis, and once the enrollment cap is reached, the waitlist will be activated automatically. For enrollment in ENGRD 302W 1 only: Non-RWID students may contact ahackne@emory.edu for a permission code after November 15, 2025. Technical Writing for Data Science prepares students to analyze complex information and produce clear, ethical, and reader-centered documents across professional contexts. Through hands-on projects and collaborative practice, students will learn to analyze writing contexts, manage the communication life cycle, and adapt style and format to diverse audiences and global contexts. Assignments across multiple genres such as an archival observation report, an interview transcript, and a formal cover letter will help students develop their written, oral, electronic, and visual communication strategies.

title: Special Topics in Philosophy: Ethics
professor: Sara L McClintock slmccli@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 354RW 1) (Topic: Buddhist Ethics) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Tradition-Buddhism, Theme.) (This writing-intensive seminar takes a broadly philosophical approach to the study of Buddhist understandings of the nature of goodness and how goodness can be recognized and cultivated. Materials for the course will range from Buddhist scriptures, to philosophical treatises, to narratives, to poetry, and to films. The intention of the course is to engage seriously with Buddhist understandings of the nature of the human condition as infused with suffering, and how humans can nevertheless develop goodness and resilience within this fleeting and unstable world. Topics include the extent and limits of generosity, the proper objects of loving-kindness and compassion, the moral consequences of truths and falsehoods, and mind-training techniques for taking obstacles as the path.) (Writing assignments will be weekly and will emphasize engagement with the course materials. There will be a final written project that builds on the work done during the semester.)

title: Special Topics: Anthropology: Humans as Drivers Evol. Change
professor: Laura van Holstein laura.agatha.van.holstein@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as BIOL 385W 1) Topic: Humans as Drivers of Evolutionary Change This course offers an in-depth exploration of the role humans' and human ancestors, hominins' have played as drivers of evolution in their own lineage and that of other species. Topics discussed include competition between hominin species throughout the 7 million years of hominin evolution, Plio-Pleistocene megafaunal extinctions, hominin-pathogen coevolution, (self-)domestication, evolution in cities and other anthropogenic ecosystems, and the role of humans in the current biodiversity crisis.

title: Freshman Seminar:Creative Writing: Poetry & Practice of Attention
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) (Complete Topic: Poetry & the Practice of Attention) In this first-year seminar, we will focus on what writing and reading poetry can teach us about attention. We will progress through several themes, including memory, presence, description, distraction, and control/freedom. Students will have weekly notebook writing assignments/exercises derived from assigned readings and will also compose 5 complete poems. Feedback on those compositions from peers and the professor will be provided in workshop discussions, and students will use these comments to revise poems for an end-of-semester portfolio. Attendance at Creative Writing events is required, as is attendance at all class meetings. Absolutely no use of AI is permitted for any element of the course.

title: Botanical Medicine & Health
requirement_sentence: (Same as HLTH 440 1 and BIOL 442 1) (Mankind has long recognized that plants are extremely useful as a source of medicine. Medical traditions based on botanical drug sources can be found in all human cultures and date back to prehistory. In this course, both ancient and modern day botanical traditions across many cultures will be discussed as they pertain to medicine. The pathways through which natural drugs are made by plants and how they affect humans will be the focus of this class. Some examples include botanical drugs for infectious disease, cancer, cardiovascular health, dental health, central nervous system function, and much more. By the end of this course, you will have a solid understanding of the major botanical drugs, including their sources, applications, and cultural relevance.)

title: Theater Workshop in Spanish
requirement_sentence: (Same as SPAN 330 1) The objective of this course is the development of linguistic and cultural understanding in the context of theatrical performance. The course is both critical and experiential. Through close readings of texts, script analysis, memorization, development of character, writing assignments, and theatrical performance, students will develop a deeper understanding of Spanish language and Hispanic cultures through the perspectives of both disciplines, Hispanism and Theater Studies. This critical/interpretive dimension will be enriched at all stages of the course by the experiential dimension: the physical and vocal embodiment/performance of the target language and texts. Course taught in Spanish. Texts: readings will be made available on Canvas. Particulars: Class exercises will involve physical and vocal warm-ups and improvisation; assignments, including writing essays and reading plays, will include individual activities as well as activities requiring outside class preparation with partners. Prerequisite: SPAN 212 Interested students must contact Prof. Elva Gonzalez at egonza3@emory.edu or Prof. Mary Lynn Owen at mowen3@emory.edu.

title: Neurobiology Data Lab
ger: Science, Nature and Technology with Lab
professor: Samuel J Sober samuel.j.sober@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: [(BIOL 142 and BIOl 142L) or BIOL_OX142] and (BIOL 360 or NBB 301) or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. (Same as BIOL 360L 1) (Topic: Neural Data Simulation & Analysis Lab). Students who were on the BIOL 360L/NBB 301 wait list in Fall 2025 AND Spring 2026 graduating senior Biology majors who need to fulfill their upper-level lab requirement have priority for this class. Contact Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu for permission. Through this course, you will learn basic computational and programming skills and apply them to the simulation and analysis of neural data. Course instructors will provide introductory lessons on basic coding in Python, which will be used throughout the course through collaborative, group-based lab tutorials. The focus of this course will be to use these in-lab tutorials to understand how neuroscience data is structured, analyzed, simulated, and interpreted. The course will be divided into 2 portions: (1) coding, running, and interpreting simulations of neural activity, and (2) understanding the analysis of neural data. The course consists of lectures, group lab tutorials, and individual homework assignments for each module. This course originates in the Biology Department, and it will count as an elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the Biology major. (This course does NOT COUNT as elective credit for the NBB major; the catalog description is incorrect.) Prerequisites: Biology 142/142L and Chemistry 202; pre- or co-requisite: Biology 360/NBB 301).

title: Introduction to Fiction Writing
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. PLEASE NOTE: Students will need to purchase Blue Books and writing instruments to use in class. Devices will not be permitted. Making People: Empathy and Expertise This is an introductory course on the art of fiction writing. We will focus on elements of craft such as character development, narrative control, dialogue, scene development, setting, structure, openings and endings. We will engage with fiction writing as always about creating human beings with histories, bodies, and social realities; as always about creating a world anew for an audience; and as always a form of communication with an ongoing humanity -- be it dead writers, current beloveds, future anonymous readers or one's own self. Students will come to understand the fiction workshop as a place to face fears, biases and the limitations of the imagination all via practice and hard work. Students will come to see fiction as a place to communicate as writers and critics. Students come to see fiction writing and critical reading as a place to engage bravely and vulnerably with grief, joy and the full range of human emotions between.

Making People: Empathy and Expertise This is an introductory course on the art of fiction writing. We will focus on elements of craft such as character development, narrative control, dialogue, scene development, setting, structure, openings and endings. We will engage with fiction writing as always about creating human beings with histories, bodies, and social realities; as always about creating a world anew for an audience; and as always a form of communication with an ongoing humanity -- be it dead writers, current beloveds, future anonymous readers or one's own self. Students will come to understand the fiction workshop as a place to face fears, biases and the limitations of the imagination all via practice and hard work. Students will come to see fiction as a place to communicate as writers and critics. Students come to see fiction writing and critical reading as a place to engage bravely and vulnerably with grief, joy and the full range of human emotions between.

title: Capstone Seminar: Why Anthropology Matters
requirement_sentence: ANT 202 or ANTH_OX 202 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This Senior Seminar explores the craft, significance, and responsibility of anthropology in the contemporary world. It will include reflections on the field, practice, and ethics of anthropology as well as direct engagement with diverse approaches to doing, writing, and representing anthropological research. Course questions include: How do contemporary anthropologists develop projects that are responsive, collaborative, and ethically engaged? How do contemporary anthropologists produce and disseminate "stories that matter? "What is public-facing anthropology and how is it produced, disseminated, and evaluated? How do anthropologists work in a range of sectors, including: urban planning, community research, public health, medicine, design & architecture, museums, applied linguistics, information technology, cultural resource management, natural resource management, consumer research, education, journalism, creative writing, government, and diplomacy? Students will develop independent projects focused on sociocultural anthropology's relevance in the 21st century and will present their ongoing research in various formats during the semester, including: work-in-progress workshops, social media posts, a research poster, and a final paper.

title: Child Development
requirement_sentence: (Prior completion of Psyc 110, 111, or AP/IB credit in psychology.) (The ways individuals interact with the world and with each other change dramatically from birth to adolescence. The first goal of Child Development is to trace changes during infancy, the preschool years, middle childhood, and adolescence in the domains of cognition, language, social behavior, and self concept. The second goal of the course is to examine the factors that influence the course of development, including heredity and the social, cultural, family, and physical environment.)

title: Creative Writing: Advanced Fiction
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. Our course will serve as a workshop into the form and structure of fiction writing for the advanced student. We will be working in a round-table workshop format. We will learn by doing. Topics covered will include: scene work, POV, plot vs. narrative, beginning near the end, characterization, dramatic action, etc. Copying Costs: Each author will be responsible for printing out a copy of the work discussed each week in class. All work must be double-spaced, legibly printed, page-numbered consecutively with the title and author's name on the first page. We will be doing some in-class writing. Bring the tools for this: pens, paper, etc.

Creative Writing: Advanced Poetry
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. This course is intended for students with a serious commitment to poetry, and a strong belief in their ability to learn among a community of people whose work will both overlap with and differ from their own. Students will strive for excellence and excitement in the regular composition and revision of new poems, as well as an ever-broadening sense of the possibilities of our art. In addition to posting poems for workshop, students will provide context for their creative work, sharing influential texts and ideas, in order to deepen the class's collective ability to understand where their poems are coming from, and where they might be headed. Readings will include full-length poetry collections and essays on craft. Each student will be responsible for guiding discussion of one book (with a partner), and attendance at all Creative Writing Reading Series events is required.

title: Adult Psychopathology
requirement_sentence: (Prior completion of Psyc 110, or Psyc 111, or AP/IB credit in psychology) (Coverage of all major adult psychological disorders in terms of their etiology, diagnosis, and treatment. Particular emphasis will be placed on: (1) exposing students to the major theoretical and conceptual models of abnormal behavior, and (2) providing students with the skills to become more critical consumers of the burgeoning literature on psychopathology.)

title: Creative Writing: Advanced Drama
requirement_sentence: (Same as THEA 375R 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) (Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html) Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. This is an intensive workshop in which you will conceptualize, generate, and workshop long one-act or full-length plays (minimum 60 pages). This is NOT a place to expand or revise an already-existing script. We are collectively starting at the beginning (a very good place to start). Adaptations are not allowed; riffs might be (let's talk about it). The assumption is that you already know how to write a play by gaining entry into this course. Our goal this semester is to push that knowledge further and expand the scope of your work.

title: Childhood Psychopathology
requirement_sentence: (Prior completion of PSYC 110, or PSYC 111, or AP/IB credit in Psychology.) (The aim of this course is to provide a comprehensive understanding of the etiology and treatment of childhood psychopathology based on scientific study and investigation. This course will include 1) An overview of paradigms and research in abnormal child psychology 2) Attention to the context of development, and the role of development in assessing childhood psychopathology and 3) treatment strategies in abnormal psychology, and their application to specific childhood psychological disorders with attention to cross cultural influences.)

title: Fresh Sem: Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies: Gender, Sex, & Science Fiction
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) Gender, Sex, and Science Fiction: How can science fiction help us understand the limitations and possibilities of sex and gender? When we dream of different futures, what forms does gender take in those futures? Reading science fiction, African and Afro futurism, and speculative fiction, and viewing some television and film selections, our course explores the ways in which science fiction can reveal how we understand gender and society. Introducing concepts from feminist science studies, we will examine the intertwining of gender, sex, race, and technology.

title: Drugs & Behavior
professor: Prof. Rohan Palmer rohan.palmer@emory.edu Primary Instructor
schedule_location: M 1pm-2:15pm in White Hall 101 W 1pm-2:15pm in ONLINE
requirement_sentence: (This class is hybrid. It meets in-person on Mondays, 1:00-2:15, AND synchronous zoom meeting on Wednesdays, 1:00-2:15.) (Prior completion of Psyc 110. First year students CANNOT take this class.) (This course is a survey of the neurobehavioral effects of the various classes of psychoactive drugs, (e.g., stimulants, depressants, etc.), as well as their clinical implications. Although human experience is taken as the starting point of each drug covered, multiple biological and environmental factors shape the progression of initial exposure to addiction and the success of treatment. A fundamental underpinning of this course is that individual differences in drug response can be explained by understanding the brain mechanisms through which psychoactive drugs exert their effects and the behavioral and sociocultural factors that shape our expectations and experiences.)

title: Creative Writing Special Topics: Journalism in the Movies
requirement_sentence: (Same as FILM 385 2) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. No pre-requisite. This class is NOT open to first-year students. If journalism has historically been considered a pure and ethically-driven form of nonfiction; if, pardon the cliché, it is the first rough draft of history; if its principle motivator in this nation's history has been the pursuit of truth, justice and the American way (you did know Superman/Clark Kent was a newspaper reporter, right?); and if it is the most zealous guardian of not just any amendment to the U.S. Constitution but the First Amendment, then why is the profession of journalism historically misrepresented as crude and corrupt when Hollywood tries to tell its story? Or is the profession's purity just an old former newspaperman's misguided fantasy that confuses vice and virtue in a vocation that consumed him and his conscience for more than 35 years? Newsrooms have long been filled with quiet creative geniuses and loudmouth miscreants, the brilliant and the boorish, the talented and the tawdry, and yet there are few if any professions as tethered to, and as cognizant of, a code of ethics. What does that get you? Good fodder for screenwriters and filmmakers of feature films and documentaries at home and abroad. We'll dive into this history and have some lively assignments and discussions.

title: Creative Writing: Spec. Topics: Inside/Outside:Archival/Eco
requirement_sentence: (Complete Topic - Inside/Outside: Writing and Reading Archival Poetics & Eco-Poetics) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. Inside/Outside: Writing and Reading Archival Poetics & Eco-Poetics Pre-requisite: NONE In this course we will go inside, into artifacts and archives, to write poetry that arises from what other humans create and leave behind. We will also go out into nature to write poetry that comes out of the natural world. We will consider grass and rain as works of art worthy of poetic response. We will consider human "stuff" as materiality worthy of poetic examination. We will experiment with poetic forms, as they may be relevant or inspirational.

title: Intro Study in Sexualities
requirement_sentence: WGS205W Introduction to Studies in Sexualities This course is an introduction to the interdisciplinary field of sexuality studies. It will explore the diversity of contemporary sexual experience, sexual behavior and sexual identity, and put into question what we take to be natural, normal or liberatory about these experiences, behaviors and identities. This exploration will be guided initially by the influential work of Michel Foucault. What is the relation between sexuality and repression? What is the relation between sexuality and power? We will be particularly interested in the status of homosexuality in contemporary theories of sexuality. Beginning with pre-Stonewall homophile politics in the US and moving through the radical era of the 1970s, the course will investigate the foundations of current queer theory and activism. In the last part of the course, we will explore four key contemporary debates in sexuality: adolescent sexuality; queer cinema; pornography; queer comics.
