title: Freshman Seminar:Biology: Perception
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) (Complete Topic - Perception: Experiencing the World) We will study what has been learned about our sensory systems and how they work. Each sense is unique and the systems that process each type of sensation is distinct. "Sensation and Perception, 5th Edition" (Oxford University Press) will serve as our text as we explore this fascinating field. As with any significant question of nature, it is important to go beyond the borders of any specific field of study to develop a complete understanding. In our course, we will focus on the neurobiology supporting subjective experience, but also consider concepts from cognitive science and philosophy of mind. This will be an interesting and exciting study of one of the most important natural science questions of our time.

title: Developmental Biology
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. This course will introduce you to the broad field of Developmental Biology. The fertilized egg, a single cell, gives rise to many cells that form complex multicellular organisms with many different cell types, tissues, and organs. The overall goal of developmental biology is to elucidate the cellular and molecular processes that control this amazing achievement. The study of development spans molecular biology, cell biology, genetics, embryology, and importantly, evolution. These perspectives will be used to explore general principals and fundamental mechanisms that are shared between many diverse organisms, focusing on invertebrate and vertebrate animals. This includes consideration of human development with examples of medically relevant disorders and social and ethical questions related to the field. This course fulfills the Column A requirement (or elective credit) for the Biology major. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L.

Evolutionary Biology
requirement_sentence: BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L, or BIOL_OX 142 or BIOL_OX 142X, or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This course is a study of factors that cause genetic change and of the evolutionary consequences of such changes. Topics include population genetics, adaptation and natural selection, evolution of genes, proteins, and genomes, sexual selection, kin selection, speciation, and diversification of taxa. Emphasis will be on molecular, genetic, ecological, and evolutionary factors related to variation and adaptation to environment, and constraints on adaptation. Students must also register for a BIOL 241-1 Discussion Section. Prerequisites: Biology 142 and Biology 142L. This course fulfills the Column C requirement (or elective credit) for the biology major.

title: Special Topics: Putin & Putinism: A History
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 385 2) (This class covers not simply the rule of Putin but the Russia he was born into, the nature of his Late Soviet society, his political career in the unstable period following the collapse of the Soviet Union and his reigns as prime minister and president. The class will cover topics as diverse as illiberal democracy, wars of conquest, the creation of a petrostate, the taming of the oligarchs, the alliance with religious conservatives, as well as such issues as cultural control and sexual politics. Students will write weekly short reflections, an end-of-term video reflection, a historiographic essay on a topic of their choosing and take a final oral exam. Putin has shocked the world with his invasion of Ukraine, find out not only what makes him tick but also how the Soviet Union shaped him and how he shaped Russia. We will be reading portions of Alexievich's Second-Hand Time, Short's Putin, Lacqueur's Putinism, and additional readings that will be provided to students.)

title: Islam in Russia
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 423W 1) (This course will concentrate on the broad experience of Muslims within various Russian states. Russia has been Europe's largest Muslim minority state since the 16th century and Muslims still make up about 14% of the Russian Federation's population, making them a major contributor to Russian history. Muslims were variously persecuted, wooed, assimilated, tolerated, forcibly converted, protected, "ignored," "modernized," socialized and granted independence and autonomy by various incarnations of the Russian state. Topics such as the conquest of Kazan and the steppe, the establishment of state-controlled Islam, the colonization of the North Caucasus and Central Asia, the shock of war and revolution, forced secularization, the late Soviet rise of a political Islam, and post-Soviet political Islam will all be discussed. Students will be required to make an oral presentation, write a book review of a class book and write a final research paper.)

title: Special Topics: MESAS-100 Level: Yoga:Hindu, Jaina and Buddhist
schedule_location: MW 1pm-2:15pm in Emerson Chemistry Bldg. E363
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 170 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Region, Theme.)( (Complete Topic: Yoga: Practices of Mind and Body in Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism) (This course will survey the terrain of mental and physical culture in the South Asian traditions of Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism. We will read from primary sources, root texts and commentaries as well as modern scholarship on the vast diversity of practices that are united in their self-characterization as `yoga,' irrespective (as well as cognizant of) their religious and sectarian differences. We will study the chronological development of the concept and practices associated of yoga, its distinct uses and applications in the three religious traditions in play, as well as its transformation and applications in the modern global marketplace of self-culture.) (The course will foreground lenses of gender, race, caste and colonialism to evaluate how their interplay has determined the reception, definition and practice of yoga in modernity. The course will also attend to the inter-relations of mental and physical practices in these three religions with Sikh and Sufi traditions in South Asia. Lastly, it will emphasize both the theory and practice of yoga as intertwined and mutually shaping each other.)

title: Interdisciplinary Studies Seminar
professor: Deepa Das Acevedo dasacevedo@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: This course will introduce special topics in the law and policy of India. Indian jurisprudence has long been recognized for its innovation and flexibility. At the same time, India's judicial system has been increasingly burdened by multiple stressors and its central government has implemented sweeping legislative changes. This course explores these themes and others through a wide selection of topics and an interdisciplinary set of materials. Students will develop a basic familiarity with the architecture of India's judicial system, with key features of the Indian Constitution, with selected issues in scholarship and practice, and with the ability to evaluate Indian and American legal systems in comparative context. Most of our materials will be primary source (case law, statutory law, constitutional law). Some will be secondary analysis.

title: Introduction to Religion: The Quest for Meaning
requirement_sentence: This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Theme. Complete Topic: Religion and the Quest for Meaning. How should we live? What and whom should we care about? What are the commitments and projects that bring purpose to our lives? These are among the most enduring and important questions humans have wrestled with, questions demanded of anyone aspiring to live a meaningful life instead of sleepwalking through it. In this course, we explore the human quest for meaning through a survey of the world's religious traditions. Religions have always been among the most reliable sources of moral ideals, and among the most successful at inculcating those ideals through the practices, communities, and narratives they provision. Yet the centrality of religion for moral formation stands in tension with the secular and pluralistic character of the world we now inhabit. In this course, we attend to the difficulties as well as the possibilities of forging connections, communities, and commitments when traditional religious outlooks are no longer widely shared or taken for granted. We also query the limits of the category of "meaning" by considering aspects of religion that go beyond discursive coherence, that tap into the irreducibility of human experience.

title: Elementary Greek II
professor: Niall W Slater nslater@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Content: A continuation of Elementary Greek I (GRK 101 at Emory or the equivalent is a prerequisite). This course continues the introduction of the basic grammar and syntax of classical Greek within its larger cultural context. The course aims to move students into reading selections from major classical authors as quickly as possible. In the second semester, we will be reading adapted selections from Plato, Aristophanes, historians, and the orators, chosen to illuminate the history and culture of ancient Greece at its zenith. Texts: (students enrolled for the first semester will already have these texts). JACT, Reading Greek: Text & Vocabulary (Cambridge UP) ISBN: 978-0521698511 JACT, Reading Greek: Grammar & Exercises (Cambridge UP) ISBN: 978-0521698528 Particulars: Quizzes, three or four tests, and a final examination. Classwork and homework are important components of the final grade.

title: The Greeks
requirement_sentence: How did ancient Greeks go to war, hold a festival, build a city, define their culture? This course explores the world of the people who spoke Greek, knew Zeus, and sailed from one end of the Mediterranean to the other. Our geographical range will reach from the coasts of modern Turkey to Greek cities in Sicily; our chronological span begins with the first appearance of human beings in the Greek islands, and ends with the world created by Alexander the Great. Our readings are primary sources, including archaeological sites, artwork, ceramics, architecture and human remains; theatrical performances, athletic competition, rhetorical and philosophical schools; literary selections from epic, lyric, drama and history, as well as the archaeologies of war and violence, cultural identity, colonization, and mobility. Grades are based on in-class exercises, midterms, and a final exam.

title: Introduction to Ancient Mediterranean Societies
professor: William K Gilders wgilder@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANCMED 101 1 and JS 180 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Region.) (Topic: People and Their Gods) (This course provides a survey introduction to the study of the distinctive and interrelated cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the Bronze Age until the Christianization of the Roman Empire (ca. 3300 BCE to ca. 400 CE). Under the subtitle, "People and Their Gods," the course gives special attention to cultural phenomena identified with the category of "religion." Drawing on a range of evidence, both material and literary, we will explore how ancient Mediterranean people understood and interpreted stories about gods and other powerful beings ("myths"); polytheism and monotheism; veneration of images ("idolatry"); tradition and innovation in religious beliefs and practices; the sexualities of gods and human beings; the significance of sacrifice (including human sacrifice); how Jews and Christians viewed so-called "pagans" and how "pagans" viewed Jews and Christians; the ancient Mediterranean roots and sources of present-day religious traditions.)

title: Middle East Empires to Nations
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 200 1)

title: Art & Architecture of Ancient Rome
requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 222 1) Roman civilization, from the Republican through the Imperial periods, transformed the art and architecture of the ancient Mediterranean. Innovations in engineering and technique, the introduction of new materials (like concrete), and the Roman genius for cultural assimilation all combined to create an art which was exciting as well as eclectic. Indeed, Roman art has often been characterized as the first truly modern art. The course will investigate the ways in which major achievements in sculpture, painting, numismatic and glyptic art, as well as architecture often reflected contemporary developments in Roman politics, society and religion. In addition the course will explore the relationship of works of art and architecture erected in the city of Rome to those in the provinces, the interaction of public and official art to domestic art, as well as the impact of art commissioned by imperial and elite patrons on that commissioned by non-elite patrons. Art History major/minor: Division I Architectural Studies minor: elective

title: Vergil and Dante
professor: Niall W Slater nslater@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: The Aeneid and The Divine Comedy are both central texts in the western literary canon, closely linked by the literary genre of epic and even more by the profound influence of Vergil on Dante's conception of his poem. Yet they are strikingly different too: Virgil's epic of national origins places the cataclysmic events of his own lifetime in a scheme of fate and historical causation reaching back to Rome's mythic origins, while Dante's poem, though also deeply ingrained in history, explores the place of the Christian soul in the great drama of sin and redemption. Vergil and Dante both became national poets in retrospect, and both conceived their great works under the profound influence of previous epic poetry. For Vergil that previous influence was primarily Homer, for Dante Vergil. Our primary goal is a close reading of both poems in their contexts, but we shall also consider how literary canons are formed, how works are re-read in later times, and what the definition of a classic is. Both works will be read in English translation, but students with knowledge of Latin or Italian or both will be invited to contribute their perspectives based on reading in the originals as well.

title: Fresh Sem: Religion: Buddhism and Human Flourishing
professor: Sara L McClintock slmccli@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as PHIL 190 3) (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Tradition-Buddhism.) (Suffering is a universal feature of human life. No one who lives does not also suffer. This insight is the starting point for the Buddha's teachings on the nature of the human condition and the possibility of human flourishing. Although suffering is universal, diverse causes of suffering can be identified. Once identified, these causes can be ameliorated so that the suffering they produce is either less harmful or even eliminated. Humans can learn how to live with suffering and to transform it into something beautiful, just as a gardener uses manure to nourish beautiful flowers. To turn suffering into a path of well-being, however, requires many skills. We need to learn how to look deeply to see the complex causes of suffering. Then we need to learn to see how these causes can be ameliorated or even undone. We also need to train in the methods for ameliorating and undoing the causes of suffering. These methods require work at the personal as well as the communal levels, at the surface as well as the deeper levels of our embodied minds. This course is an introduction to traditional and contemporary Buddhist theories of well-being, happiness, and flourishing, along with some of the methods designed to bring these about.)

title: Spec Stud in Classical Culture: Egypt. Art Crossroad of Cult.
requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 319R 1) "Egyptian Art in the Greek and Roman Periods: Crossroads of Cultures"This course examines ancient Egyptian art produced between approximately 332 BCE and the end of the fourth century CE, a period when Egypt was governed by Greek and Roman rulers. Although often overshadowed by the artistic achievements of earlier times, the visual culture of Greek and Roman Egypt offers vital insights into how art functions as a medium for expressing identity, negotiating power, and navigating cultural boundaries. Far from being a time of decline, these periods witnessed the construction of great temples, the creation of new works that fused indigenous Egyptian forms with the styles and mediums of Greek and Roman art, and the production more mummies than any other time in Egyptian history. Through close analysis of sculpture, architecture, painting, and funerary art, this course will explore the resilience and dynamism of Egyptian cultural identity in a cosmopolitan world.

title: Anthropology of the Jews
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 258 1, ANT 258 1) This is a fascinating time to be - or just learn about - Judaism and Jewishness. We are less than a century out from the genocidal devastation of the Holocaust, the birth of the State of Israel as the first independent Jewish commonwealth in almost two millennia, unprecedented freedom for Jews in many (but not all) parts of the world, and vast migrations by almost every historical Jewish community to a different part of the world than it lived in a century ago. Surely, these are features of the modern Jewish condition we will need to discuss anthropologically. We also live in an age of unprecedented technology and shifts in worldview. Can a genetic profile "prove" Jewishness? In what special ways are some women using assisted reproductive technology or "reproductive tourism" to fulfill Jewish kinship or social and religious expectations? Some of the most interesting anthropological research on Jewish communities today centers on these issues. This class takes place at a moment of increasing political polarization, including confrontations with legacies of (and contested definitions of) race, gender, and antisemitism. Do the new discussions of race and gender, as well as the politics of "diversity, equity and inclusion" make it harder or easier to identify and respond to key elements of the modern Jewish condition, individually or collectively? Has it grown easier or harder to answer the old question whether "Jewishness" is primarily a religious, ethnic, racial or national designation [spoiler: these are not the only options]? Does it matter? To whom? What is actually at stake in these conversations? Finally, we may be at something of a crossroads for the history of anthropology as a research discipline. Along with reading about the sheer diversity of ways of being, thinking, or living Jewishly, we will acknowledge the fraught Jewish history of the anthropological discipline, and ask some critical questions about its future. Is anthropology today capable, given the tools at its disposal, of rendering an adequate account of modern Jewish life? Why, for the most part, has it failed to do so (ok, that's another spoiler alert)? How has the modern Jewish condition impacted the anthropological project from its beginnings, and how might clearer thinking about Jews, Jewishness and Judaism contribute to new forms of anthropological thought? How can we read current ethnographies of Jews and Judaism critically to better understand what they tell us about the Jewish world, how they do it, and what they can learn to do better?

title: Special Topics in Religion: God, Sex, and Crime
professor: Javier Villa Flores javier.villa-flores@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 285 1, HIST 296 1, and LACS 270 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (Throughout history, crimes have tested and measured the social and cultural values that hold human beings together. In a society such as New Spain (Mexico) articulated around the defense and propagation of Catholic religion, religious crimes constituted a threatening subversion of the colonial discourse that justified the Spanish presence in Mexico, and a contradictory expression of the social tensions lived in the Spanish colony. This course will look at colonial society through the lens of crime by analyzing some of the main transgressions prosecuted by the Mexican Inquisition between 1520 and 1820, and the specific historical circumstances in which the trials took place. Our goal will be not only to analyze the reasons for inquisitorial repression, but also to disentangle the tensions lived in the social fabric of the colony in light of the classic divides of race, class, and gender.)

title: Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
ger: Humanities and Arts with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 268 1, HIST 268 1, POLS 268 1) The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Political Struggles, Personal Histories gives students an overview of Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the 1880s on through today. It introduces students to early Zionist debates and the late Ottoman context before moving on to discuss violence during the British Mandate period, the rise of the State of Israel, and the reappearance of the Palestinian cause on the world stage after the 1967 war. The course will include sessions that examine previous bouts of armed conflict as well as various attempts at peace, but war and politics will not be the course's only foci; the lived experiences of Palestinians and Israelis will also receive significant attention, from historical times through the present day. These voices include a young Jewish female spy who helped the British defeat the Ottoman Empire; an Islamist rebel whose death inspired the Great Arab Revolt of the 1930s; a Holocaust survivor who fought in the 1948 war before becoming Israel's leading poet; girls whose families fled from Jerusalem and Libya, and grew up amidst poverty and war; a U.S.-trained heart surgeon-turned-PLO militant who was assassinated in his quest for peace, and many others.

title: Survey of Jewish History
schedule_location: MW 1pm-2:15pm in Math & Science Center - E208
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 270 1, HIST 270 1) This course is a survey of Jewish history from antiquity to the present. It presumes no prior knowledge of Jewish history, religion or culture. We will examine how Jews have defined themselves socially and politically in a number of historical and geographical settings, how Jewish theology and religious practice have been shaped and transformed, and how Jews have interacted with and responded to the societies in which they have lived. A central question during the ancient period will be, what was "Judaism" and how did it emerge out of the diverse religious landscape of antiquity? The medieval period will focus on the interface between Jewish communities and the states or empires in which they lived. Particular attention will be paid to the interactions between Jews, Christians, and Muslim peoples and cultures. In the modern period, we will analyze the processes by which governments, politicians and some segments of Jews attempted to incorporate the Jews and Judaism into European society and the various problems and reactions engendered by the quest for Jewish emancipation and social integration.

title: Interpreting Religion
requirement_sentence: This course, while open to all undergraduates, is a required course for undergraduate students at Emory majoring in Religion. The aim of the course is to introduce students to the study of religion as an academic field so that they may better situate their own research and writing within the larger landscape of modern scholarship in this area. Students will become familiar with major sociological, anthropological and hermeneutic approaches which pursue questions about the function, origin, comparison and language of religion. We will explore key terms in the contemporary study of religion such as culture, body, performance, rationality. Throughout, we will be concerned with the ways in which the category of religion has been and continues to be constructed by those who study it. This class is designed to increase students' methodological self-awareness as scholars of religion.

title: African American Religion: Psych.of the Black Church Exp.
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 320R 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (In this exciting new course called Psychology of the Black Church Experience, we will explore the intersection of Black psychology and African American Christianity through the lens of the Black Church. From a critical psychological approach, we will examine how the Black Church functions as a social, spiritual, and psychological support system in historical and contemporary racial experiences for Black people in America. Aspects of the Black Church experience that this course will examine include its historical relevance in America, racial identity and empowerment, gender socialization, spiritual experiences, the Black family, and mental health and healing. We will delve into topics like communal identity, leadership dynamics, coping mechanisms, and the Black Church's role in social activism, community development, and mental health within Black communities.)

In addition to continuing work on grammar and focusing on writing, listening, and speaking, students will engage with authentic texts, explore topics in Italian culture, literature, and media, and develop both linguistic and analytical-critical skills, as well as cross-cultural competency.

title: Business Italian
requirement_sentence: ITAL 202 or ITAL_OX 202 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. ITAL 320W. Business Italian (Prof. Simona Muratore / Mondays/Wednesdays 2:30-3:45pm) Content: This advanced-level course, taught entirely in Italian, focuses on developing practical workforce skills and global competencies for engaging with Italian-speaking businesses and prospective employers. Students will explore Italian business culture, practices, and etiquette while expanding business-related vocabulary and strengthening professional communication skills. Through authentic materials, electronic exchanges, guest speakers, and panel discussions, students will practice collaborative, presentational, oral, and written communication in real-world contexts. The course culminates in the organization of Italian Business Night, a community-engaged event that connects students with Italian entrepreneurs and professionals, offering valuable networking opportunities and preparation for future international career paths. Assessment: Weekly assignments, reflections papers, oral presentations and final paper, Italian Business night organization.

title: Special Topics in Philosophy: Ethics
professor: Sara L McClintock slmccli@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as PHIL 385W 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Tradition-Buddhism, Theme.) (This writing-intensive seminar takes a broadly philosophical approach to the study of Buddhist understandings of the nature of goodness and how goodness can be recognized and cultivated. Materials for the course will range from Buddhist scriptures, to philosophical treatises, to narratives, to poetry, and to films. The intention of the course is to engage seriously with Buddhist understandings of the nature of the human condition as infused with suffering, and how humans can nevertheless develop goodness and resilience within this fleeting and unstable world. Topics include the extent and limits of generosity, the proper objects of loving-kindness and compassion, the moral consequences of truths and falsehoods, and mind-training techniques for taking obstacles as the path.) (Writing assignments will be weekly and will emphasize engagement with the course materials. There will be a final written project that builds on the work done during the semester.)

title: Tops in Ital Lit in Trans: Italian American Experience
requirement_sentence: (Same as AMST 385W 1) ITAL 375W The Italian American Experience cross-listed with AMST 385W (Prof. Stefano Maranzana / Mondays and Wedesdays, 2:30-3:45PM) Content: Do you want to know more about the Mafia and the Godfather? This is an offer you can't refuse. Touching on witchcraft, the evil eye, and life in Little Italy, you will learn whether Alfredo Sauce is authentically Italian and what it meant to be an Italian immigrant at the turn of the 20th century. Several millions of Italian immigrants came to the United States to work for the industrial development of the county's economy at the end of the 19th century. This course aims at introducing you to the fascinating study of the Italian American presence in the United States and its impact. Through movies, articles and primary sources we will look at the historical, political, literary and artistic achievements of Italian immigrants in the United States to understand what it means to be an American of Italian descent in the 21st century. This course is taught in English and does not require any knowledge of Italian. It fulfills Continuing Communication and Race & Ethnicity Requirements) Text: Connell, W. J., & Pugliese, S. G. (Eds.). (2017). The Routledge History of Italian Americans. Routledge.

title: Religion and Healing: Sacred Bioethics:Reprod.Tech.
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 385 7, HLTH 385 13, and JS 370 1) (Complete Topic: Sacred Bioethics: Ethnography, Religion and Assisted Reproductive Technology.) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Theme.) (We live in a world of increasing biotechnology. Surrogacy, IVF and the potential for cloning are just a few of the technologies that have raised important questions about how human beings reproduce as well as the costs and responsibilities associated with any creation of new life. Who should be considered the mother of a child born through gestational surrogacy? Is reproductive cloning a potentially exciting new technology or a nightmarish assault on what it means to be human? What, if any, limits should be placed on "reproductive tourism" in which women from poor countries bear children for women from rich ones? These are not simple questions.) (We also live in a world of deep religious and cultural diversity, in which biotechnology is used, interpreted and developed with the needs, concerns or values of different communities in mind. Though often portrayed as value-neutral, the science of reproduction cannot help but raise questions of value that cannot, by their nature, be adjudicated by science or medicine alone.) This seminar explores the ways in which different religious and cultural traditions have grappled with the ethical implications of new reproductive technologies. Students are expected to gain comparative knowledge of two kinds: 1. Understanding some of the varying ways in which different religious traditions (such as Judaism, Christianity, Islam or Hinduism) have defined and evaluated bioethical dilemmas. 2. Understanding how different scholarly disciplines (such as anthropology, theology or comparative religion) can contribute to better understanding of bioethical dilemmas and the people who face them.

title: Topics in Italian Literature
requirement_sentence: ITAL 470 Italian Cinema. Neorealism to the present Prof. Achille Castaldo / Tuesdays and Thursdays 1:00-2:15PM Content: A history of Italian cinema from the mid-20th century to the present day (with some forays into contemporary Italian TV series). This class will explore both major and lesser-known movements, directors, and genres, with a particular focus on neorealist films and aesthetics in the light of their international resonance. We will focus on historical topics, including fascism, youth culture, terrorism, mafia, migration, and film aesthetics (such as the construction of pathos, landscape, memory, and charisma). Authors will include well-known personalities such as Roberto Rossellini, Michelangelo Antonioni, Pierpaolo Pasolini, Lina Wertmüller, Liliana Cavani, and contemporary filmmakers who are revitalizing Italian film aesthetics, like Alice Rohrwacher and Pietro Marcello. Class discussion will be in Italian, but subtitles in English will be available for all films.

title: Senior Symposium:Critique of Religion
requirement_sentence: This senior symposium for Religion majors asks: "What's the point of a Religion major in 2026?" It looks to pull together some threads of previous coursework in religious studies as a capstone, and it also serves as a steppingstone to look beyond graduation into how the study of religion might contribute to one's life. As a capstone to their academic work, students will develop a research paper on a topic of their choice. As a steppingstone, students will examine how religious studies might relate to future careers and engagements with diverse communities. Throughout the course, we will invite past Religion majors and people using religious studies in their careers into the classroom. We will also venture out to religious sites in and around Atlanta.

title: Nutrition and Performing Arts
requirement_sentence: HLTH 220 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Performing artists & performers in training, including musicians, singers, actors, & dancers, have unique energy & nutritional demands, yet little attention has been given to their nutritional needs, making them subject to nutrition myths that are likely to be counterproductive. Whether it is a dancer managing the last of a hundred pirouettes in a ballet, or a jazz trumpeter motivating people to tap their feet in the last set of a long evening, it takes power, concentration, & endurance to bring all the elements of a successful performance together. Performing artists must manage the dynamic interaction between energy/nutrient utilization & provision to help assure a long, healthful, & successful career. This course will cover the nutritional elements that will help students understand the basic science behind nutritional recommendations, & strategies that can help performing artists achieve the desired body profile, optimal hydration, endurance, & health. Special attention will be given to artists of different age and sex, the nutritional stresses associated with travel, performing in hot & humid environments, & optimal eating strategies that can help artists prepare for performances at different times of day and night. Students can still enroll without the HLTH 220 prerequisite. Please complete this permission request form starting 11/20/25 https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/CSHH5261OPR and reach out to Ms. Addy (shiyra.sadoff@emory.edu) for questions.

title: Global Macroeconomic Perspectives

title: Core Issues in Global Health: Under the Weather?
requirement_sentence: HLTH 250 or HLTH_OX 250 or ANT 205 or ANTH_OX 205 or SOC 250 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This course will provide an overview of climate change science and the public health impacts, with an emphasis on the cultural and social dimension of impacts, vulnerability and adaptation. We will begin with a review of the evidence on climate change and variability and explore a number of topics related to climate change of interest to the anthropological and global health community, such as: Disparate Impacts: The Global North vs the Global South; Food security: Climate change impacts on food quality and quantity; Climate change and biodiversity loss; Environmental Justice as a policy frame; Arctic and Circumpolar health issues; Indigenous perceptions of climate change; Impacts on oceans; Climate Refugees: Migration and population displacement. (Prerequisite: HLTH 250)

title: Introduction to Ancient Mediterranean Societies
professor: William K Gilders wgilder@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 110 1 and JS 180 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Region.) (Topic: People and Their Gods) (This course provides a survey introduction to the study of the distinctive and interrelated cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the Bronze Age until the Christianization of the Roman Empire (ca. 3300 BCE to ca. 400 CE). Under the subtitle, "People and Their Gods," the course gives special attention to cultural phenomena identified with the category of "religion." Drawing on a range of evidence, both material and literary, we will explore how ancient Mediterranean people understood and interpreted stories about gods and other powerful beings ("myths"); polytheism and monotheism; veneration of images ("idolatry"); tradition and innovation in religious beliefs and practices; the sexualities of gods and human beings; the significance of sacrifice (including human sacrifice); how Jews and Christians viewed so-called "pagans" and how "pagans" viewed Jews and Christians; the ancient Mediterranean roots and sources of present-day religious traditions.)

title: Poetry
requirement_sentence: Across pre-history and history and in all languages, poems score sound and breath. Today most poems take shapes on pages, but poems' diction, punctuation, syntax, and lineation still play bodies like instruments, orchestrating tongues, teeth, lips, lungs, and diaphragms. This Introduction to Poetry emphasizes complex somatic and affective experiences poets exert themselves to induce, even as it prizes the development of fluency with analytic tools and a precise vocabulary used to explore poems' meanings. The first half of the course grapples with Nims and Mason's Western Wind. The second half of the course takes up four books of poems by important poets and one book about a very non-Western kind of poetry. Students will memorize three poems and perform each in public. The best of these performances will be sophisticated interpretations, not rote recitations.

title: Topics in Literature: Major Authors: Louise Erdrich
professor: Mandy Suhr Sytsma mandy.sue.suhr-sytsma@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Louise Erdrich, a citizen of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa, is among the most prolific and highly acclaimed authors of our time. This course focuses on her fiction, especially her novels Tracks, The Round House, and The Night Watchman, along with her children's novel The Birchbark House. We will also engage some of Erdrich's poetry and non-fiction prose, interviews with her, and scholarship about her work. Erdrich depicts Indigenous people's experiences with boarding schools, sexual violence, land theft, anti-colonial resistance, Indigenous feminisms, and Anishinaabe teachings. We will discuss these topics and consider how Erdrich's craft contributes to her portrayal. We will also explore the impact of Erdrich's work for law, politics, pop culture, and education.

title: Health Policy
professor: David H Howard dhhowar@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Introduction to issues in health policy and fundamental for all majors and minors. This course will cover major topics in health policy, with a focus on the United States. We will address the following questions: Why is health care spending going up and should we care? How is health care financed? In what respects does the market for health insurance differ from markets for other types of products? How do Medicare and Medicaid operate? How do doctors and hospitals get paid? How does the organization of US health care inhibit or contribute to value? Is it possible to measure the quality of care?

title: Special Topics: Human Health: Concepts of Care
requirement_sentence: Understanding, providing, and advocating for care is paramount in today's complex and interconnected world. This course delves into the multi-faceted nature of care, examining it through various lenses and contexts. Whether you aspire to work in healthcare, social services, or education or want to enhance your understanding of human relationships and well-being, this course equips you with the knowledge and skills to become a more compassionate and effective caregiver. This course will give students a comprehensive understanding of the concepts of care and their practical applications. Students will be better prepared to engage in compassionate caregiving as healthcare professionals, educators, community advocates, or individuals dedicated to creating a more caring and empathetic world. Join us in exploring the profound art and science of care today. Special Note: HLTH 385 courses count differently within the majors/minors; they are not all equivalent. Please pay close attention to the exact course title and categories that specific title counts in, which you can find on our requirements sheets and course summary sheets. If you have any questions, please reach out to CSHH administration.

title: Literature and the Arts
requirement_sentence: Black artists often turn to speculative and fantastic genres to illustrate the strange qualities of Black life informed by racism and oppression but also resilience and strength in the face of these structural challenges. In this course, we will read, watch and play through Black speculative fiction narratives to better understand how Black artists have imagined alternatives to the status quo and what these alternative worlds signify about our own. The material for this class will be composed of novels, short stories, films, and video games. As we engage with the works of Black artists, this course will encourage us to compare forms of media and analyze the specific a¿ordances of each one. By taking this course, students can expect to gain an understanding of Black speculative fiction as a genre with a unique history that transcends individual media, reflect on Black speculative fiction as a microcosm of American culture at large, and analyze the various intersections of race, gender and sexuality which inform many of the narratives we will encounter. In response to the multi-modal nature of our course, students can expect to produce work in multiple genres and modes, including written essays, visual presentations, and interactive experiences. Diverse Perspectives I Theories and Methods

title: Indigenous Literature Since 1850
professor: Mandy Suhr Sytsma mandy.sue.suhr-sytsma@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: In this course, we will pursue a historically grounded study of Indigenous American fiction, non-fiction, and poetry produced between the mid-nineteenth century and the present. We will read texts written during the periods of history they represent as well as more recent texts depicting the US Dakota war, the Navajo Long Walk, the Wounded Knee massacre, Indian boarding schools, allotment, reorganization, termination/relocation, Red Power movements, the Native American renaissance, and the AIDS epidemic. We will also read recent literary texts that portray current and future work related to cultural/political resurgence, LGBTQ2+ empowerment, language revitalization, and environmental restoration. Throughout the course, we will draw connections between these literary texts/contexts and current issues of concern for Indigenous nations. All students are expected to complete reading and writing assignments as scheduled and participate in discussions and assessments.

title: Intro.to Asian Am.Lit.Culture
requirement_sentence: This course provides a general introduction to the study of Asian American literature and culture through the politics of fantasy and from a global framework. Instead of taking "Asian America" as a given, we will explore its construction by tracing how "Asia" and "America" have been imagined separately and together. Placing these fantasies in relation to histories of immigration, imperialism, militarism, and globalization, we will investigate how Asian American writers and artists engage with and intervene in the imagining of Asian America. Throughout, we will pay special attention to the racial fantasies that adhere to everyday objects, including food, fashion, toys, media, and other forms of popular culture. Texts will range from the classic to the contemporary and encompass fiction, poetry, nonfiction, comics, and other media. Topics to be discussed will include: Orientalism and the yellow peril; the model minority; stereotyping and microaggressions; media representation; racial fetishism; drag and racial performance; interracial romance; refugee politics; intergenerational memory; techno-Orientalism; globalization and soft power; kawaii culture; weebs and fandoms. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives I & II

title: Topics in Literary History: Literature and Medicine
schedule_location: MW 4pm-5:15pm in Math & Science Center - W307C
requirement_sentence: Why do sick people tell stories? Whom or what do illness narratives serve? What do illness narratives help ill people (re)construct? What are the distinctions between healing and curing? What are the individual and collective facets of illness? These are some of the questions we will contemplate in this course alongside others pursuing answers to similar inquiries. We will read a variety of illness and healing narratives in a myriad of forms (novels, poems, plays, short stories, essays) by considering such cultural expressions in relation to the development of an interdisciplinary field of literary criticism and the founding of an accompanying journal (Literature and Medicine, founded in 1982). The stories we read in this class will also help us consider other matters e.g., conceptions of hope, dignity, death, pain, and meaning in the midst of chronic and/or debilitating illness and terminal illness. Diverse Perspectives I & II Theories and Methods

title: Old English Language & Literature
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 363W 1) Pre-1700 One semester of intensive language study will result in a proficient reading knowledge of the West Saxon dialect (standard Old English) such that we can explore the culture of the Anglo-Saxons and better understand the language we speak today. Selections from heroic and religious poetry and prose will begin with the first known poem in the English language and will also include the Wanderer and Seafarer, the Battle of Maldon, the Dream of the Rood, Ælfric's preface to Genesis, and King Alfred's lament over the faded glory of English learning. Classes consist of prepared translation, short lectures, and discussion. The standard lexicographic and bibliographic tools in Old English will be covered. Some previous foreign language study is desirable but not required; students should be prepared to use a glossary. We will also read Beowulf in translation, as well as selected passages in Old English.

title: Freshman Seminar:Anthropology: Animals Through the Ages
Chaucer
requirement_sentence: This course covers the full range of Geoffrey Chaucer's poetry, including his dream visions, Troilus and Criseyde, and selected Canterbury Tales. Chaucer creates in English the stories and forms found in classical (e.g. Ovid's Metamorphoses and Virgil's Aeneid), vernacular (e.g. those by Dante, Boccaccio, and Guillaume de Lorris) and biblical traditions. Chaucer is at his best when overturning the conventions of epic, romance, fabliau, Breton lay, saint's life, and exemplum. We shall explore at least three of the great mysteries of Chaucer's life and work: how such a prolific poet could also be a soldier, diplomat, and court official; how his poetic persona consistently veils and deprecates his genius; and how his relationships with people from different social classes and sexes finds poetic expression. A class project will involve work with manuscript facsimiles in Emory's Rose Library.

title: Distressed Investing

title: Advanced Seminar: Plato's Republic
requirement_sentence: The single most famous work of philosophy in history is a work of political philosophy: Plato¿s Republic. The Republic contains a dramatic depiction of a late night conversation between Socrates and a group of youths, in which they design the imaginary ¿best regime.¿ Their conversation takes place in the shadow of a coming oligarchic suppression of Athenian democracy. Their purpose is to refute, if they can, the powerful claim that a life of injustice is the best life. Do they succeed? The dialogue contains many of Plato¿s best known passages: the cave analogy, the community of women and children, the philosopher kings, the idea of the Good, and many more. The Republic is a book every Emory undergraduate should read. This course is cross listed as POLS 490 and PHIL 400.

title: Concepts And Methods in Biol Anth
requirement_sentence: The overall goal of this course is to build an understanding of (1) the processes that led to modern human biocultural variation and (2) how we know what we know. Like other anthropological fields, we will attempt to answer the question: what does it mean to be human? Our focus is on biological and evolutionary processes, but that includes behavior and culture because these are impacted by, and have impacts on, our biology. This class begins with an overview of genetics and evolutionary theory, providing a foundation for the rest of the course. Then we use this knowledge to explore examples of adaptation and microevolution among modern humans and to address misconceptions about human variation. Next, we will turn to macroevolution of our species, Homo sapiens, using comparative and paleoanthropological approaches. With the comparative approach, we focus on anatomy and behavior of living non-human primates to identify traits we share with them and traits that are uniquely human. Paleoanthropology combines our knowledge of living primates with observations from the fossil record to trace the evolution of primates and hominins (humans and their ancestors) over millions of years. Therefore, we will gain insight into our own evolutionary past and attempt to identify where, when, why, and how our biological and cultural traits emerged. Permission request form: https://forms.office.com/r/hehCBknHK0

title: Special Topics: Tech.&Innovation Real Estate
requirement_sentence: FIN 220 or FIN 320 or SPECSTUBUS students or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This section is reserved for students in the BBA program. This course explores the dynamic intersection of real estate and technology, focusing on how digital innovations reshape the industry. Students will comprehensively understand the real estate lifecycle, key players, and emerging technologies transforming traditional practices. The course will examine pain points, inefficiencies, and opportunities for innovation in the real estate sector while also analyzing the challenges faced by new technologies in gaining widespread adoption. Through lectures, case discussions, guest speakers, and a field study, students will explore existing and emerging PropTech solutions across various areas, including marketplaces, new asset classes, major functions, data analytics, and AI applications. Engagement with executives from PropTech startups and established real estate firms will provide real-world insights into the practical applications and challenges of implementing innovative solutions.

title: Studies In Shakespeare
requirement_sentence: This course will combine discussion and viewing of Shakespearean drama in conjunction with the growing body of plays written to provide material about what might happen before, during, and after the action presented in Shakespeare's plays. The class will also consider some of the many recent plays intertwining Shakespearean narratives with autobiographical material. The texts will be determined, but are likely to include drama by Emory alum Lauren Gunderson (often the most produced playwright in North America); Zinnie Harris, David Grieg, Tom Stoppard, Stefan Wolfert, Paula Vogel, and Ted Lange. The class will include regular writing and discussion and will offer opportunities for students to devise their own responses to Shakespeare's plays (if they are so inclined).

title: Applied Topics in Data Science: Introduction to AI
requirement_sentence: This course offers a non-technical introduction to artificial intelligence and its effects on institutions, work and everyday life. The course is practical: students will learn how modern systems are designed and how to ask the right questions about data, reliability and harms. The course combines short demonstrations (no programming experience required), case studies, and project work. It is suitable for undergraduate students from any faculty who want a grounded understanding of what AI can and cannot do.

title: Black Music
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 303 1) (Music and Performance in the African Diaspora is an interdisciplinary course exploring critical perspectives on Black music, dance, and culture in the US and abroad. We will build a critique of cultural production emphasizing an intersectional framework and critique of oppression via black studies, black feminisms, and sound studies. This class will bring together various media, social science, film, and art as we discuss legacies of blues, jazz, funk, hip hop, and techno. We will work toward a broad definition of black music to consider its history and global circulation.)

title: Renaissance Literature: 1603-1660
requirement_sentence: This course will introduce students to major works of British literature (including poetry, drama, and prose) dating roughly from the death of Elizabeth I in 1603 to the restoration of the monarchy in 1660. We will adopt a broadly historicist approach, devoting special attention to the relation between the period's literature and the politics of the English Civil War (1642-1651). This approach, however, will not be at the expense of attention to the formal and thematic qualities of individual works. The course will be divided into six units: 1) Metaphysical and Cavalier Poetry, 2) Jacobean Drama, 3) Gender Relations in the Seventeenth Century, 4) Empiricism and Experience, 5) The Literature of the Civil War, and 6) Milton's Paradise Lost. Pre-1700

title: Jazz, Spirituality, & Religion
professor: Dwight D Andrews dwightandrews@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 305 1) This course examines the intriguing relationships between religion, spirituality, and jazz. It considers the common roots of the spirituals, blues, and jazz, and surveys the historical, cultural, social, and denominational factors that have helped to shape our perspective on the spiritual capacity of jazz. Any exploration of this type must include an interrogation of the intersection of race, racism, and ethnicity. Notions of the sacred/secular as well as the origins of the stigmas associated with jazz as the devil's music will be examined in detail. This course will focus on the sacred works, biographies, and implicit theological positions of six jazz masters: Mary Lou Williams, Dave Brubeck, Duke Ellington, John Coltrane, Sun Ra, and Yusef Lateef. Each of these masters elected a distinct and different path in the musical expression of their spirituality. Significant Buddhist (Herbie Hancock) and Baha'i (Dizzy Gillespie) jazz communities will also be considered.

title: Milton
requirement_sentence: This course will provide a comprehensive overview of the writings of the seventeenth-century English poet John Milton, including his early lyric poetry, prose writings, and late major works. Much of the course will be devoted to a complete reading of Milton's masterpiece, the Biblical epic Paradise Lost. We will address his writing within its historical context, paying special attention to Milton's role in the English Civil War during which he served as Latin secretary for the revolutionary Commonwealth government and was among the chief advocates of Puritan and republican values and his relation to the changing gender roles of his time. We will also consider the major philosophical and religious themes of his writing, such as free will and the nature of divine providence. Pre-1700

title: The Early English Novel
requirement_sentence: This course will offer a survey of some of the most exciting, innovative, and intellectually provocative novels published in eighteenth-century Britain. A touchstone for our discussions will be the philosopher John Locke's reinvention of the human mind, in his 1690 Essay Concerning Human Understanding: "Let us then suppose the mind to be, white paper, void of all characters, without any ideas; how comes it to be furnished?" Locke's answer to this question, "experience," had an enormous impact on the intellectual landscape of the century that followed. On the one hand, Locke's argument that our ideas are derived from the senses suggested that individuals are the products of their own experience, and thus have, in some measure, the power to shape their own lives. On the other hand, the shaping power that Locke attributed to experience conjured up the danger that our minds and our lives are always at the mercy of various external forces: including family and friends, enemies and competitors, as well as an array of social, cultural, and political settings, institutions, and ideologies. More than any other form of literary expression in the eighteenth century, the novel took up the challenge of imagining and embodying, even at times resisting, the power of experience. We will study the novels of Daniel Defoe, Samuel Richardson, and Jane Austen, among others. Written work will include 3 essays, weekly Canvas postings, and a take-home final exam. of exams and essays

title: Foundations of Linguistics
requirement_sentence: What do you know when you know a language? How did you come to learn this information so quickly? How do the world's languages differ? How do linguists study language? This course explores the complex nature of human language and introduces students to the scientific study of human language. As we unpack our knowledge of language, we will explore speech sounds (phonetics), sound systems of language (phonology), word and sentence formation (morphology and syntax), how language expresses meaning (semantics), and how context influences the interpretation of meaning (pragmatics). We will also study language in a broader human context, investigating the role of language in defining human society. Additional topics include historical linguistics, language typology, sociolinguistics, and language acquisition.

title: Poetry
professor: Nathan Suhr Sytsma nathan.e.suhr-sytsma@emory.edu Primary Instructor
schedule_location: TTh 2:30pm-3:45pm in Math & Science Center - N302
requirement_sentence: This course will explore the overlay of language and politics on an island where even what you call a place is it the North of Ireland or Northern Ireland? implies a political stance. You will learn how writers of fiction, plays, and poetry have not only imagined but contributed to cultural and political phenomena from the Irish Revival and the Easter Rising through the Troubles and the peace process. Focusing on Irish literature in English, you will also read some Irish-language literature in translation. Writers are likely to include, among others, Lady Gregory, W. B. Yeats, James Joyce, Seamus Heaney, Nuala Ní Dhomhnaill, and Anna Burns. Expect to read attentively, engage in class discussion, complete a brief in-class reading response or reading quiz each week, practice close reading in essay form, and develop a final project based in the splendid archives and manuscript collections of the Rose Library. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II

title: Foundations of Global Health
requirement_sentence: (Same as HLTH 250 1 and SOC 250 1) (This interdisciplinary course explores the complex causes of serious health problems in both low-income and rich countries throughout the world, as well as strategies of health programs aimed at their solution. Global Health refers not only to the health problems of "others" living in far corners of the world but also to our own health problems as citizens of a very rich nation; most importantly it is about how those health problems are the result of global, social, economic and political interactions.)

title: Future Health
requirement_sentence: HLTH 210 & HLTH 230 & HLTH 250 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. During their final Spring semester, students are required to develop a response to a problem presented in the capstone course. This project will require a problem-solving approach that integrates concepts from across the curriculum. The project and its presentation must demonstrate that the student has mastered the core competencies of the human health major. The topic and format of the final project may vary from year to year. title: Topics in Postcolonial Literature: Methods of Lit.Interpretation
requirement_sentence: (Same as CPLT 301W 1 and MESAS 370W 1) (Topic - Global Rhymes: Poetry and/as World Literature) (What happens when a sonnet travels across centuries and continents? How does a ghazal resonate in a new language, or an elegy mourn across cultures? From ancient epics to TikTok poetry, what makes poetry travel? And what does it carry with it? While world literature courses often revolve around the novel as the form closely associated with modernity, nationhood, and global circulation, poetry predates the novel, has long and rich histories in many languages and cultures, and continues to shape global consciousness in ways both intimate and political.)

title: Technical Writing
requirement_sentence: (Same as ENGRD 302W) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) (Juniors and seniors with declared majors or minors offered by the Department of Data and Decision Sciences will receive permission codes for this course prior to the pre-registration period. Students must use the provided code to enroll during their assigned registration period. Enrollment will be on a first-come, first-served basis, and once the enrollment cap is reached, the waitlist will be activated automatically). Technical Writing for Data Science - Technical Writing prepares students to analyze complex information and produce clear, ethical, and reader-centered documents across professional contexts. Through hands-on projects and collaborative practice, students will learn to analyze writing contexts, manage the communication life cycle, and adapt style and format to diverse audiences and global contexts. Assignments across multiple genres such as an archival observation report, an interview transcript, and a formal cover letter will help students develop their written, oral, electronic, and visual communication strategies.

title: Mythbusters: Nutrition Facts and Fiction
professor: Myra Woodworth Hobbs mewoodw@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: HLTH 220 and (BIOL 141 or BIOL_OX 141 or CHEM 141 or CHEM_OX 141 or CHEM 151 or CHEM_OX 151) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Nutrition is at the center of a cultural dialogue about health, though the line between cultural ideology and scientific knowledge is increasingly unclear. In this course, students will learn and use evidence-based nutrition knowledge to critically analyze health-related information, fads, and myths in popular media and translate the scientific evidence to the greater community. (Prerequisite: HLTH 220)

title: Contemporary Literature
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 385W 4) Black British literature has been around roughly as long as African American literature, thanks to the letters and essays of early Black British abolitionists such as Olaudah Equiano and Ignatius Sancho. Unfortunately, it has not enjoyed the same levels of attention and acknowledgement, and even today there are British literary critics unaware that there is in fact a Black British literary tradition that stretches all the way back to the 18th century. It is also as varied, especially in the postwar era as writers from former British colonies in Africa and the Anglophone Caribbean migrated at the government's behest to fill the void left by the loss of English soldiers in World War II. In Britain, there are many ways to be Black, and these novels lay out an array of visions. In this course we'll take a deep dive into the postwar British novel, beginning with Samuel Selvon's iconic The Lonely Londoners, which looks at the experience of the first men who were part of the Windrush generation, and finishing with Bernadine Evaristo's prize-winning epic Girl. Woman. Other., which details some 200 years of Black British women, non-binary folk and trans folk fighting to be recognized for who they are. About halfway through our novels, we'll take a break with some dub poetry and other subversions of the famous stiff upper lip. Diverse Perspectives I & II Theories and Methods

title: Anthropology of the Jews
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 258 1, REL 258 1) This is a fascinating time to be - or just learn about - Judaism and Jewishness. We are less than a century out from the genocidal devastation of the Holocaust, the birth of the State of Israel as the first independent Jewish commonwealth in almost two millennia, unprecedented freedom for Jews in many (but not all) parts of the world, and vast migrations by almost every historical Jewish community to a different part of the world than it lived in a century ago. Surely, these are features of the modern Jewish condition we will need to discuss anthropologically. We also live in an age of unprecedented technology and shifts in worldview. Can a genetic profile "prove" Jewishness? In what special ways are some women using assisted reproductive technology or "reproductive tourism" to fulfill Jewish kinship or social and religious expectations? Some of the most interesting anthropological research on Jewish communities today centers on these issues. This class takes place at a moment of increasing political polarization, including confrontations with legacies of (and contested definitions of) race, gender, and antisemitism. Do the new discussions of race and gender, as well as the politics of "diversity, equity and inclusion" make it harder or easier to identify and respond to key elements of the modern Jewish condition, individually or collectively? Has it grown easier or harder to answer the old question whether "Jewishness" is primarily a religious, ethnic, racial or national designation [spoiler: these are not the only options]? Does it matter? To whom? What is actually at stake in these conversations? Finally, we may be at something of a crossroads for the history of anthropology as a research discipline. Along with reading about the sheer diversity of ways of being, thinking, or living Jewishly, we will acknowledge the fraught Jewish history of the anthropological discipline, and ask some critical questions about its future. Is anthropology today capable, given the tools at its disposal, of rendering an adequate account of modern Jewish life? Why, for the most part, has it failed to do so (ok, that's another spoiler alert)? How has the modern Jewish condition impacted the anthropological project from its beginnings, and how might clearer thinking about Jews, Jewishness and Judaism contribute to new forms of anthropological thought? How can we read current ethnographies of Jews and Judaism critically to better understand what they tell us about the Jewish world, how they do it, and what they can learn to do better?

title: Botanical Medicine & Health
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 440 1 and BIOL 442 1) (Mankind has long recognized that plants are extremely useful as a source of medicine. Medical traditions based on botanical drug sources can be found in all human cultures and date back to prehistory. In this course, both ancient and modern day botanical traditions across many cultures will be discussed as they pertain to medicine. The pathways through which natural drugs are made by plants and how they affect humans will be the focus of this class. Some examples include botanical drugs for infectious disease, cancer, cardiovascular health, dental health, central nervous system function, and much more. By the end of this course, you will have a solid understanding of the major botanical drugs, including their sources, applications, and cultural relevance.)

title: 19th Century American Novel
requirement_sentence: Nineteenth-century American novels are full of fakes: forged documents, phony testimonials, hucksters, impersonators, con-men, and plenty of people who assume false identities to survive. Over the course of the century, the American public became increasingly concerned with the knowability of biological categories we now understand as identities such as race, gender, sexuality, and disability. In what Ellen Samuels has called fantasies of identification, nineteenth-century novels consider the place of truth and authenticity in a nation where nothing was as it seemed. In this class, we will examine the development of the novel in nineteenth century America with a particular focus on identity formation and falsification. Through the work of writers such as Charles Brockden Brown, Catherine Maria Sedgwick, Julia Ward Howe, Hannah Crafts, Herman Melville, Pauline Hopkins, and Henry James, students will become familiar with the movements and traditions of American literature, including early American work, the historical romance, novels of enslavement, the gothic, and naturalism. Course assignments will include weekly preparatory writing, group discussion leadership, and a midterm and final exam. 1700-1900 Diverse Perspectives I & II

title: Special Topics in Latin American and Caribbean Studies: History of Puerto Rico
requirement_sentence: This course is an interdisciplinary overview of the history of Puerto Rico. Particular emphasis will be placed on the last 30 years of US colonial rule in Puerto Rico and resistance movements. Hierarchies of race, gender, sexuality, the urban/rural and class will ground our explorations of: colonization & racio-colonial capitalism, sovereignty, nationhood, migration & diaspora, debt, disaster, mutual aid, tourism, and various forms of protest and resistance. Recent scholarly work by Jorell Meléndez Badillo, Yomaira Figueroa, Marisol Lebrón, Yarimar Bonilla, Hilda Lloréns, Petra Rivera-Rideau, Vanessa Diaz, Michelle Rosario, Jose Atiles and others will be featured. Weekly assignments will include readings, podcasts and analyzing artistic productions. Students will work on a longer form written piece as well as a multimedia presentation over the course of the semester. Knowledge of Spanish is not required.

title: Brazil: Country of the Future
requirement_sentence: (Same as PORT 385 2) Brazil is one of the world's largest, most diverse, and most unequal countries. Its history interweaves the experiences of Indigenous peoples, enslaved Africans, and immigrants from across the globe. This course explores Brazil's multiethnic society from the period before European arrival to the present. Students will analyze how different groups navigated and challenged political systems sustained by slavery, and how abolition, immigration, industrialization, and urbanization reshaped the nation. The course will consider Brazil both as a unique case study and within broader global patterns of colonization, development, and modernization. This course demands active student participation. Weekly readings and discussions will connect past and present, examining how historical patterns continue to shape contemporary Brazilian society. Students will approach historical questions using a range of methodologies and sources, including primary documents, visual materials, and oral histories, to construct evidence-based historical arguments. In addition to weekly writing, students will produce three papers, including one based on off-campus research. The reading load, which includes a textbook, articles, and primary documents, will often exceed 100 pages a week.

title: European Intellectual History/1880
requirement_sentence: What is the place of human beings in the modern world? In examining the social, political, technological, and aesthetic changes that characterize modernity, and various reactions to them, this discussion-driven course will survey many of the most important intellectual and cultural trends of the past 150 years. Beginning with the promise and threat of both science triumphant and Nietzsche's attacks on false certainties, it will move on to explore decadence, vitalism, the cult of violence, modernism, Communism and fascism, existentialism, feminism, the cultural effects of the two world wars, and the many and varied consequences of the turn to language and representation as the fundamental philosophical problem: structuralism, post-structuralism, deconstructionism, and postmodernity generally. Assessments include one short essay (4-5 pp.), two short analysis papers (2 pp. each), and EITHER a final research paper (9-10 pp.) OR a final exam, plus attendance and active participation.

title: Big/Small Data and Visualization
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 446W 1 & DATASCI 446W 1) The course deals with new tools of analysis and visualization of text data. It is a 4-credits course, fulfilling the writing requirement with extensive weekly writing. The course does NOT require any prerequisites or prior knowledge of computational tools. Freshmen are not allowed to register. Text corpora will be assigned for analysis but students are welcome to use their own texts (e,g., newspaper articles, books, blogs). The course is based on a set of specialized Natural Language Processing tools (NLP), written in Python, designed for the analysis of small/large corpora of text. The tools come with an easy-to-use Graphical User Interface (GUI). From sentence splitter, to tokenizer, lemmatizer, parser with its Part-of-Speech tags (POSTAG), Dependency Relations (DEPREL), Named Entity Recognition (NER), semantic trees, sentence complexity and text readability, noun and verb analysis, n-grams viewer, sentiment analysis, topic modelling, extraction of SVOs (Subject-Verb-Object), and shape of stories, word embeddings (Word2Vec) you will learn the language of Natural Language Processing (NLP). The course also embeds tools of data visualization as word clouds, Excel-type charts, network graphs, and Geographic Information System (GIS) maps. The course uses freeware software exclusively. The course has no required books.

title: Emory College Freshman Seminar
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) ATTENTION!: Reading, Focusing, & Expanding Your Mind Everyone wants your attention: advertisers, social media influencers, politicians, college professors. But what will you pay attention to? Do you get to choose? Should you even try to control your attention? In this seminar we will explore how our views on attention relate to big questions in life: what to concentrate on, what to filter out, and how to open yourself to new ideas and experiences. We will be guided by transformative texts from a range of cultures, time periods, and disciplines that pull us into different kinds of attentive states toward our surroundings, literature and the arts, our inner lives, and the lives of others. Readings include works of literature, psychology, spirituality, and science by authors such as Sophocles, Virginia Woolf, Rabindranath Tagore, and Sigmund Freud. You will be part of a project designed by faculty from thirteen different departments that will change the way Emory students experience the life of the mind and find intellectual community. Sections of this course will join together for activities outside of class in which you will pay attention to campus and its surroundings, as well as to your classmates' perspectives.

title: Spec Topics: History: Women & Law, 1200-1800
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 371 1 and WGS 385 2) What forms did the relationship between gender and law take between 1200 and 1800? In this class, students explore this and related questions, assessing Christian and Jewish women¿s access to the law, their agency within legal processes, and their marginalization. Students engage with historical sources and draw on gender and legal studies, alongside various fields of history, to examine these questions as a lens into power relations and broader legal, religious, and social developments during this diverse period. We will also probe societies and communities and their evolution over time, tracing continuity and change in women¿s legal standing, and reflecting on women and the law in modern and contemporary societies. Some of the questions we will ask include: What is the relationship between law and lived legal experiences? What strategies did women develop to navigate legal situations that affected themselves, their families, and their communities? How did they engage with marriage and divorce laws, as well as matters related to family law and inheritance? Were women involved in crime, and were there particular crimes associated with women? Did the law hinder women¿s roles in business? While this class primarily focuses on Europe, we will also examine the diverse legal standings and lived experiences of Muslim women, drawing comparisons between Europe and the Middle East, including the Ottoman Empire.

title: Moon Bound in the 60s
professor: Tracy L Scott tscott@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Any one SOC course as prerequisite or equivalent transfer credit. Seminar on sociological aspects of Apollo space era (1961-1972), focusing on social and cultural aspects of four new realities: "Spaceflight," "Astronaut," "Astronaut Family," and "NASA." Students use primary source material from the Stuart A. Rose Library and the Apollo 15 Learning Hub to create final projects. Class Notes Only 12 humans have walked on the Moon; only 24 have orbited the Moon. No human has been beyond Earth's orbit since the last Apollo lunar mission in 1972. The Apollo missions were extraordinary scientific achievements; they were also historical events located in particular social contexts. This seminar course takes a sociological approach to explore the Apollo era (1961-1972), focusing on four main areas: "Spaceflight" "Astronaut," "Astronaut Family," and "NASA." We will begin with brief background on the political, technological, and broader social contexts of the time. Then we will delve deeper into various social and cultural aspects of these four new realities: "Spaceflight" (e.g., media constructions and projections), "Astronaut" (e.g., links to test pilot culture; gendered construction of a new occupation), "Astronaut Family" (e.g., relationship with the press; the unpaid work roles of wives; creating new NASA communities) and "NASA" (e.g., PR efforts and image constructions; early organizational culture). Students will work with primary source material from the Stuart A. Rose Manuscript and Rare Book Library, the Emory Center for Digital Scholarship's Apollo 15 Learning Hub as well as other digital archival material (from data collected by Professor Scott) to create their own projects on one of the main topic areas. Requirements: Three short research assignments that will build into a final project, in the form of an op-ed article. Drafts of the final project will be peer reviewed and discussed in class. Class attendance and discussion are integral to this course. Prerequisite: one Sociology course.
