title: Islam in Russia
requirement_sentence: (Same as REES 423W 1) (This course will concentrate on the broad experience of Muslims within various Russian states. Russia has been Europe's largest Muslim minority state since the 16th century and Muslims still make up about 14% of the Russian Federation's population, making them a major contributor to Russian history. Muslims were variously persecuted, wooed, assimilated, tolerated, forcibly converted, protected, "ignored," "modernized," socialized and granted independence and autonomy by various incarnations of the Russian state. Topics such as the conquest of Kazan and the steppe, the establishment of state-controlled Islam, the colonization of the North Caucasus and Central Asia, the shock of war and revolution, forced secularization, the late Soviet rise of a political Islam, and post-Soviet political Islam will all be discussed. Students will be required to make an oral presentation, write a book review of a class book and write a final research paper.)

title: Professions in U.S. History
requirement_sentence: What is a profession? What is professionalism? Who are professionals? Combining attention to theoretical issues and case studies, drawing on secondary materials and primary sources (including fiction), and leaving room for independent research by students, History 438 seeks to answer these questions in the context of American history from the Revolution to the present. But at a deeper level the course seeks to explore the nature of professional authority and the meaning of expertise as these have evolved in America. The course thus seeks to examine how and why a key form of non-elected power and influence developed in a nation supposedly dedicated to democracy. And it seeks to examine how and why certain individuals known as professionals came to have that power and influence. No examinations. Grading is based on research essay and class participation.

title: Special Topics Crosslisted: Ecological Visions Spec. Fic.
requirement_sentence: (Same as IDS 285 1) This interdisciplinary course explores the intersections of ecology and speculative fiction across literature, film, and television. Students will examine how speculative narratives imagine the future of the planet, human-nature relationships, ecological justice, and the consequences of environmental degradation. With a particular focus on science fiction, the course also draws from climate fiction (cli-fi), Afrofuturism, and eco-horror, the course invites students to analyze how speculative storytelling critiques dominant environmental ideologies and proposes alternative ecological futures. We will investigate the narrative strategies used to render environmental crisis visible and consider the cultural and philosophical implications of these imagined worlds.

title: Research Workshop: Topics
requirement_sentence: (FILM 101 or FILM_OX 101) and (FILM 102 or FILM_OX 102) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites. In this workshop, students will learn about the instructor's research and also develop their own research topics. This semester, Dr. Tanine Allison will share her ongoing research in progress about computer-generated imagery (CGI) and visual effects sequences in movies. The class will discuss these technologies in relation to issues of performance and identity, especially race and gender. Students will learn how to research topics like performance capture, deepfake/AI imagery, and the visual effects (VFX) industry. They will explore their own research projects in relation to this topic and participate in various kinds of writing and creative scholarship, such as video essays or podcasts.

title: Elementary Spanish II
schedule_location: TTh 8:30am-9:45am in Candler Library 122 F 8:30am-9:20am in ONLINE
requirement_sentence: SPAN 101 or SPAN_OX 101 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Spanish 102 is the second course in a beginning-level language sequence and is an integrated skills course designed to promote communication with Hispanic communities and to heighten cultural awareness. Students participate in paired, small-group, and whole-class conversation/listening activities that focus on meaningful communication as well as reading and writing. As such, the goals of this course include the following: 1. learning to use Spanish to communicate, primarily in speaking and listening, but also in reading and writing; 2. learning of and about the tools of communication: basic linguistic units (words, idioms, verb forms, sounds) and grammar (rules which permit you to combine the units meaningfully); 3. and studying Hispanic cultures to begin to understand how culture affects language use. Prerequisite: successful completion of Spanish 101 at Emory, at Emory at Oxford, transfer credit for Span 101 from another institution, or permission of the Director of Placement

title: Special Topics: Cross-listed: European Jews, 1492-1800
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 471W 1) How did an ethnic and religious minority in Europe experience the tumultuous years between 1492 and 1800, known as the early modern period? In this research seminar, students will take a deep dive into the history of European Jews, their relationships and interactions with majority societies, and the profound cultural, geopolitical, legal, religious, and scientific transformations that shaped this remarkable era in European and global history. We will therefore also use Jewish history to illuminate the histories of majority Christian societies. Students will explore themes such as expulsions, mass conversions, persecution, the print and scientific revolutions, the development of Jewish legal systems and Jewish engagement with non-Jewish law, conceptions of self and communal identity, messianism, the Reformations and the Thirty Years' War, mercantilism, and Jewish encounters with the Americas. The course compares Ashkenazi and Sephardi histories while rethinking the complex questions of minority belonging and exclusion. Students will strengthen their ability to analyze a variety of historical sources, including those produced by Jews as well as Christian sources that discuss Jewish life and culture. Students will apply their skills to write a 15-20-page research paper.

title: Intensive Spanish
professor: Maria Jose Velez maria.jose.velez@emory.edu Primary Instructor
schedule_location: MW 10am-11:15am in North Decatur Bldg 112 F 10am-10:50am in ONLINE
requirement_sentence: Spanish 111 is an accelerated beginning-level language course designed to advance students towards a higher level of proficiency in both communication in the Spanish language and cultural knowledge of Hispanic communities. The course is intended for students with previous education in Spanish who need additional review and practice before advancing to the intermediate level. The goals of this course include the following: 1. Further improving communicative ability through speaking, listening, reading and writing skills; 2. Developing a more complex understanding of the tools of communication: basic linguistic units (words, idioms, verb forms, sounds) and grammar (rules which permit you to combine the units meaningfully); 3. Facilitating advancement from a primarily receptive to a productive use of the language; 4. Expanding cultural awareness, familiarity with and understanding of Hispanic cultures. and understanding of the relationship of culture to language. Prerequisite: Official Spanish Placement into Span 111 is required to remain in the course. (Take the Spanish placement exam online at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html)

title: Freshman Seminar: Spanish: Jewish Voices of Latin America
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 190 1) (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) Description: When and why did Jews immigrate to Latin America? What kinds of challenges did they face in their new societies? What about Latinx Jews: how do they fit into the so-called "American story"? This course will introduce students to the history and cultures of Jews in Latin America as well as Latinx Jews in our own country. Issues we will address include acculturation and assimilation; language preservation and acquisition; ethnic and racial identities; the role of religion; family life, among others. Texts will include memoirs, novels and short stories, documentary and fiction films, poetry, journalism, music, cookbooks, and scholarly essays. The seminar will also feature guest speakers. No prior knowledge of Jewish culture or religious traditions is required or assumed. Course readings and discussions are conducted in English. Evaluation: Active participation in seminar discussions; weekly postings on Canvas; 2 short essays (~5 pp.); final project.

title: Anthro. Perspectives: Heroes,Martyrs-Cults Lat.Amer.
professor: Javier Villa Flores javier.villa-flores@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 270 4, HIST 296 3, LACS 270 2, and SOC 289 3) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (Complete Topic: Heroes, Martyrs, and their Cults in Latin America.) (Throughout Latin American history, heroes and martyrs have played a crucial role in the creation of unifiying national narratives. At the same time, they have often become the source of discord, as different groups disagreed over what and who should be remembered as heroic and exemplary. This course will explore some of these debates by focusing on the representation of exemplary lives in the region through a variety of means, including photography, monuments, museums, archives, ceremonials, and rituals. Among the topics to be addressed are: modernity, nation building, social rebellion, and accountability.)

title: Studies in African American Literature: 1900 to Present: Black Arts Movement
requirement_sentence: In this class, we will engage with politically-engaged literature, music, and art by Black American cultural workers from the 1960s-1980s. Through these works, we will discuss the way art can, in the words of writer Toni Cade Bambara, make revolution irresistible. Potential topics include: antiwar movements, the birth of Black feminism, Third World solidarity, vernacular poetry, independent presses, and Black autonomous spaces. This class will include multiple visits to Atlanta-area archives and a community engagement component. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives I

title: Anthropology; Special Topics: God, Sex, and Crime
professor: Javier Villa Flores javier.villa-flores@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 270 1, HIST 296 1, and LACS 270 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (Throughout history, crimes have tested and measured the social and cultural values that hold human beings together. In a society such as New Spain (Mexico) articulated around the defense and propagation of Catholic religion, religious crimes constituted a threatening subversion of the colonial discourse that justified the Spanish presence in Mexico, and a contradictory expression of the social tensions lived in the Spanish colony. This course will look at colonial society through the lens of crime by analyzing some of the main transgressions prosecuted by the Mexican Inquisition between 1520 and 1820, and the specific historical circumstances in which the trials took place. Our goal will be not only to analyze the reasons for inquisitorial repression, but also to disentangle the tensions lived in the social fabric of the colony in light of the classic divides of race, class, and gender.)

title: Variable Topics in Human Health: Community Hlth.Educ.Strategies
requirement_sentence: Complete Topic: Community Health Education Strategies. This course builds upon foundational health courses offered through CSHH and the Health 123 program by allowing students to translate knowledge gained in the classroom to novel settings. Students will identify & analyze various techniques, media & approaches used in community health education. Students will be introduced to concepts of program planning by participating in the development of currently functioning health education programs at Emory and within the Atlanta community. Completion of the Health 300 course is preferred but not required. This is a permission only course, please email Dr. Logan Edwards at logan.edwards@emory.edu for permission to enroll. Special Note: HLTH 485 courses count differently within the majors/minors; they are not all equivalent. Please pay close attention to the exact course title and categories that specific title counts in, which you can find on our requirements sheets and course summary sheets. If you have any questions, please reach out to CSHH administration.

title: Literature & Cultural Studies: Literary Approaches to AI
requirement_sentence: It is an understatement to say that generative AI has transformed the way that writing, art, and discourse are practiced and conceived in the world today. In this so-called era of artificial intelligence, key literary problems around creativity, humanity, and agency resonate in new and powerful ways. At the same time, AI has rapidly become a site to coalesce collective fears around increasing economic inequality, racist and sexist representations, embodiment, and environmental decay. The field of Critical AI studies examines these concerns, critiques big tech and AI development, and offers reparative alternatives for being in the age of AI. In this course, we will read literary fiction to contextualize current debates in the field of Critical AI: from data collection and surveillance to capitalism and machine bias. The semester will culminate by reading literature by writers experimenting with generative AI. Together, we will contextualize our current moment with literature and explore ongoing questions around the ethics of AI development and use. What literary methods and tools can the field of Critical AI borrow as analytic frameworks? And what does literature offer in the face of technology and automation? Post 1900

title: Human Evolution
professor: Laura van Holstein laura.agatha.van.holstein@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as BIOL 385 2) This course covers the evolution of the hominin lineage - humans and fossil apes more closely related to us than to chimpanzees and bonobos. Hominin evolution is documented by an exceptionally rich - and ever-expanding! - fossil record, which provides evidence of remarkably diverse adaptive strategies within our lineage, as well as the evolutionary drivers of this diversity. The course is structured chronologically: we begin with the earliest putative hominins dated to 7-4 million years ago, and then examine diversity within the well-known Australopithecus genus and the enigmatic Kenyanthropus clade. Next, we consider the alternative responses to climate change evidenced by two sister groups - Homo and Paranthropus - and then continue with an in-depth exploration of the drivers of evolution and dispersals within the genus Homo. At the end of the course, students will have a strong understanding of the hominin fossil record and the state-of-the-art methods and frameworks used to understand it, but also be able to critically engage with important open questions about the evolution of our lineage. No textbook.

title: Data Science Computing
requirement_sentence: (QTM 150 and QTM 151) or CS 170 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Special Topics in Data Science
requirement_sentence: This course offers a rigorous introduction to social choice theory, the formal study of how individual preferences, values, and judgments can be aggregated into collective decisions. The course begins with the necessary logical and mathematical foundations, covering propositional and predicate logic, basic set theory, and binary relations. We then develop the theory of individual choice and rationality, examining orderings, preference relations, maximality, acyclicity, and rational choice functions, along with Sen's conditions ( and ß) and Houthakker's Weak Axiom of Revealed Preference. Building on this foundation, the course turns to social aggregation mechanisms, including classical voting rules, their axiomatic characterizations (e.g., May's Theorem, Black's Theorem), and the challenges posed by Arrow's axioms and his celebrated impossibility theorem. We also study issues of manipulation, strategy-proofness, and the Gibbard-Satterthwaite theorem. The course concludes with broader normative debates, including Sen's impossibility of a Paretian liberal and Gibbard's theory of alienable rights. Throughout, students will engage both with formal proofs and with the philosophical and institutional implications of the results, making the course suitable for students in political science, philosophy, and economics who are interested in the logic and limits of collective decision-making. Prerequisites: Some prior exposure to formal methods (logic, mathematics, or microeconomic theory) is recommended.

requirement_sentence: This course offers a rigorous introduction to social choice theory, the formal study of how individual preferences, values, and judgments can be aggregated into collective decisions. The course begins with the necessary logical and mathematical foundations, covering propositional and predicate logic, basic set theory, and binary relations. We then develop the theory of individual choice and rationality, examining orderings, preference relations, maximality, acyclicity, and rational choice functions, along with Sen's conditions ( and ß) and Houthakker's Weak Axiom of Revealed Preference. Building on this foundation, the course turns to social aggregation mechanisms, including classical voting rules, their axiomatic characterizations (e.g., May's Theorem, Black's Theorem), and the challenges posed by Arrow's axioms and his celebrated impossibility theorem. We also study issues of manipulation, strategy-proofness, and the Gibbard-Satterthwaite theorem. The course concludes with broader normative debates, including Sen's impossibility of a Paretian liberal and Gibbard's theory of alienable rights. Throughout, students will engage both with formal proofs and with the philosophical and institutional implications of the results, making the course suitable for students in political science, philosophy, and economics who are interested in the logic and limits of collective decision-making. Prerequisites: Some prior exposure to formal methods (logic, mathematics, or microeconomic theory) is recommended.

title: Human Skeletal Biology
requirement_sentence: This course examines the human skeleton as both a living biological system and the product of our evolutionary history. We will investigate skeletal form and function from head to toe through the combined perspectives of comparative anatomy, growth and development, and evolutionary biology. By comparing humans to our primate cousins, the course highlights how the skeleton is reflects specializations for locomotion, diet, and aspects of life history. On the way we will explore topics like how skeletons can adapt to environmental conditions during development, and why some parts of the body can more easily evolve than others. We will trace how evolutionary tinkering with the ancestral primate body plan gave rise to the human form, where our bodies still bear signs of this shared ancestry, and how these evolutionary legacies can underlie modern health challenges. The course balances lectures with laboratory sessions. In the lab, you will gain hands-on experience with human and non-human primate skeletal material, learning to identify anatomical features, interpret functional differences, and connect them to evolutionary processes. By the end of the course, you will have developed a deep understanding of human skeletal biology and its broader links to evolution, behavior, and health.

title: Topics Asian Am.Lit.& Culture: The Chinese in America
ger: Continuing Comm.& Writing with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: This course will examine the history of the Chinese presence in the United States, especially as it has been expressed in literature and popular culture. Our historical range will include the importance of Chinese trade and Chinese goods in the American Revolutionary War, the Gold Rush and the construction of the transcontinental railway, the exclusion era, and the resurgence of Chinese immigration in the late twentieth century and continuing to the present day. We will study works of social and cultural history, memoirs, fiction, poetry, and film by and about Chinese Americans. The emphasis will be on understanding the connection between the historical context of these works and the particular concerns and shape of those works.

title: Freshman Seminar:English: Dual Dystopias
professor: Martine W Brownley mbrownl@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Dystopian novels have been so prominent in recent fiction that critics have described our time as a golden age for the genre. The result has been that, as one writer puts it, "there's a book for every type of modern dread." Particularly notable in this current dystopic outpouring has been the influence of women writers. This course juxtaposes the most famous dystopia written in English, George Orwell's 1984, with novels by contemporary women writers (Ling Ma, Octavia Butler, Margaret Atwood, and one TBA) to explore how their works are reshaping the genre. The imaginative societies envisioned by these writers pose crucial questions about where the real dangers lie for our future and our present through their groundbreaking dystopic novels. Requirements are active & informed class participation; occasional response paragraphs; 2 short papers, one potentially optional. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II Prose

title: Methods for Literary Research
requirement_sentence: Thinking about writing an honors thesis? Whether you are a yes or a maybe, you probably aren't sure how to get started, and like many students you may be feeling intimidated or uncertain about identifying a topic, doing independent research, or getting the help you need. Seniors consistently say writing a thesis was the most rewarding experience of their undergraduate education, yet many well-qualified students miss the opportunity or give up because they started too late. If you are an honors-curious junior or sophomore in the humanities or qualitative social sciences, this class is for you! Taught in a workshop/seminar format that will create a supportive, interdisciplinary intellectual community, this class is designed to facilitate your individual exploration process and help you get a head start on your project in conversation with peers and mentors. As you identify and begin to develop your research project, you will formulate or refine your topic and methods, explore what our library has to offer, enhance your oral communication skills, and work with faculty mentors to develop a plan for success. Starting early will also enable you to identify and apply for opportunities (such as funds for travel to archives and senior research seminars) that will enhance your project and provide invaluable experience. This workshop will support you in getting started on your honors thesis and help you put together the pieces that will lead to a successful outcome in your senior year.

title: Elementary Portuguese II
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: PORT 102 is a beginning-level integrated skills language course. This courses helps students develop a basic ability to communicate in Portuguese. Class time is dedicated to interactive activities that allow students to acquire skills in speaking, listening, reading and writing. Through music, videos, and readings of authentic materials, students are also introduced to many aspects of Lusophone culture. Class meets four times per week and is conducted in Portuguese in order to maximize exposure to the language. PARTICULARS: Evaluation is based on daily and active participation, homework, quizzes, writing activities, exams, final presentation, and Portuguese program activities. PREREQUISITES: PORT 101 or equivalent (including courses taken during a Study Abroad Program).

title: African American Language
requirement_sentence: (Same LING 347 1, AAS 347 1) African American Language (AAL) is by far the most researched, the most publicly recognized, and most controversial language variety in the United States. AAL has long been a central object of study in North American sociolinguistics, where researchers have investigated its structure, its origins, and its current trajectories of change relative to Mainstream American English, and have simultaneously sought to combat misunderstandings about AAL (and all language differences) held by the public and the press. This course will be broken into four major sections: 1) Present-Day Features of AAL, with a focus on its vocabulary (lexicon), pronunciation features (phonetics and phonology) and grammar (morphology and syntax); 2) The History of AAL and its ongoing trajectory of change, focusing on earlier examples of AAL, its possible origins and whether or not AAL is diverging from Mainstream American English (MAE) and other varieties of English; 3) AAL as a Living Art will discuss AAL as it is employed as an expression of art by writers, musicians, as well as its use in African American speech events, and avenues for outreach; 4) AAL, Education and Society will examine issues related to AAL and education, the justice system, linguistic profiling and discrimination in other areas of society such as housing and employment.

title: Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
requirement_sentence: CONTENT: PORT 110 is an intensive course for students with little or no preparation in the language, but are Spanish speakers (or of another Romance Language). It stresses the fundamental language skills of understanding, speaking, reading and also writing. Aspects of Lusophone culture will also be presented. Classes will be taught mostly in Portuguese in order to expose the students to the language. It is also a goal of the course to create a positive interaction among the students. Group work will be frequent, as well as the use of the students' different background and experience with the language. It covers the equivalent of two semesters (PORT 101 and PORT 102). PARTICULARS: Evaluation is based on daily and active participation, homework, quizzes, writing activities, exams, and Portuguese program activities. PREREQUISITES: No preparation in the language is required but the course is designed specifically for speakers of another Romance Language. Students who have taken the Spanish Placement exam and have been placed at the 300 level or above are encouraged to take Port 110. Students who place in SPAN 212 should contact ana.teixeira@emory.edu for placement information. PORT 110 may be combined with PORT 201 or with SPAN 212 or a Spanish Foundational Course (300-318) to satisfy the HAL or Intercultural Communication requirement.

title: Special Topics: Literature: Black Renaissances
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 378 1) (This course examines 2 of the most significant African American cultural movements of the 20th century - the New Negro Renaissance (aka the Harlem Renaissance, c. 1912-1932) and the Black Arts Movement (c. 1965-1979). While placing a primary emphasis on literary arts and authors, we will approach both movements as complex interdisciplinary, multi-generic phenomena concerned with Black freedom struggles. As we "map" the histories of these two major movements, we will consider the ways artists and critics alike have constructed these movements, the relationships of these movements to each other and to Black Studies, and the processes and politics that shape notions of literary history, race, gender, sexuality, and culture in American society.)

Advanced Practice in Portuguese
requirement_sentence: Portuguese 212 aims to further develop communication skills in Portuguese and explore issues related to power and social struggle in the contemporary Portuguese speaking world. We will discuss and analyze fictional works, films, music and primary sources, in order to understand and learn how Portuguese speakers have faced challenges such as dictatorships, immigration and emigration, as well as racial, gender and social inequality issues that have been historically present in Lusophone countries. Students will learn to recognize aesthetic constructs, the representation of genre differences and similarities, ideological trends, and historical contexts, as well as formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing. Students will be required to compose creative and analytical responses to the course materials and will revise their compositions with feedback from their peers and instructor. We will review Portuguese grammar with an emphasis on verbs and their complements (prepositions), pronouns and the nuances of the Portuguese language structure. All classes will be conducted in Portuguese. PREREQUISITES: Port 201 or equivalent (including courses taken during a study abroad program).

title: Topics: Luso-Afro-Braz Studies: Lusophone Narrative
professor: Leonardo Velloso Lyons leonardo.velloso.lyons@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (Same as AFS 389 6) Title: Lusophone Narrative - Literature and History in the Portuguese Speaking World How do literary works present historical events? How do they shed light on moments of deep change in society? How do they uphold, unveil or even challenge long settled structures of inequality brought about by Portugal's maritime expansion begun in the 1400s? This course invites students to reflect on the relationship between literature and history by examining fictional narratives and historical documents from the Lusophone world (Portugal, Brazil, Angola, Mozambique). In addition to practicing their advanced Portuguese, students will engage with some of the most foundational and interdisciplinary questions in literary studies, that is the relationship between literary (fictional) discourse and the historical past. Students will acquire familiarity with some of the most important literary genres from the time of Portugal's colonial expansion, and then examine the various legacies of the early modern period in contemporary novels written in Brazil, Angola and Mozambique. Students will also think through the proposed questions by analyzing documents about important events in Portugal's and Brazil's history, namely the Battle of Alcácer Quibir and the biggest maroon kingdom, the Quilombo dos Palmares. Readings from the early modern period (16th century) include Bernardim Ribeiro, Luis de Camões, Fernão Mendes Pinto, and from the modern period (20th and 21st centuries) Ana Maria Gonçalves, José Eduardo Agualusa, Mia Couto, Paulina Chiziane. Readings in Portuguese, course taught in Portuguese.

title: Topics in Applied Research: The Ekphrastic Problem
requirement_sentence: This seminar dwells at the intersection of aesthetics and ethics. We will read a quite varied body of poems which are addressed to paintings, sculptures, and photographs and monuments. We will proceed via close examination of these test cases. Meetings will demand real-time co-exploration and a willingness to risk saying what we see. We will gain fluency in both the mainstream of ekphrastic verse practices and in several approaches that are not widely used. We will follow our passions and instincts as we explore the possibility of art about art and its associated discourses. We will define and develop and disagree about a set of complex claims regarding one or more of the questions raised by ekphrastic verse, which include: --is the poem accurate in a valuable way, and if it is inaccurate, is its divergence from its object coherent or powerfully imagined? --is the poem obstructive? Not unhelpful? Insightful? Necessary? for what, and for whom? --is the poem a work of art in its own right, and how do we know, and how does that matter? --is the artwork addressed instrumentalized by the poem in any way? En route to a final seminar paper, participants will make two in-class workshop presentations that explore the grounds for their argument(s) as well as the motive(s) deployed in casting of their theses.

title: Voice & Diction
requirement_sentence: Voice and Diction will provide actors with various tools and techniques required to speak on stage with supported projection, diction, and endurance. We will explore breath support, articulation, range, and text analysis all while learning to stay vocally healthy. Through individual and group exercises we will examine classical texts, radio plays, and recorded narration.

title: Advanced Topics in Linguistics: Emory Voices
requirement_sentence: This course will equip and enable you to contribute to the Emory Voices Project-- a large-scale linguistics project that aims to collect and analyze the speech of Emory undergraduates. We intend to study Emory's linguistic community by interviewing undergraduates at the beginning and end of their time in college. In these interviews, we will target specific linguistic characteristics, inquire about language attitudes, and elicit natural speech. You will learn about the sociolinguistic interview process, develop skills working with linguistic corpora, and study other relevant topics within linguistics to inform your work on the project. This course will also allow students to formulate and address a research question of their choosing. Course is open to students of all years and skill levels. Prior completion of at least one Linguistics course is recommended. Students seeking course enrollment permission, please fill out this brief form: https://forms.gle/qfyY1RUwaurxswKx9. For any questions, reach out alex.martinez@emory.edu.

title: Asian Religious Traditions
schedule_location: TTh 1pm-2:15pm in Emerson Chemistry Bldg. E102
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 212 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Region, Tradition-Buddhism.) (Topic: China and Japan) (This is an introduction to the major religious traditions (Confucianism, Daoism, and Buddhism) in China and Japan. The course will contextualize the religions in the larger frame of popular religious practices. We will also examine the patterns of interactions among these traditions in different historical periods. Our themes will include: the invisible world of gods and spirits, worldly benefits, religion and state, and the lives of shrines, temples, and monasteries.) (Throughout the learning process, students will not only get familiar with the major religious traditions in East Asia, but also increase awareness of the different perspectives in understanding the role of religions in ancient and modern society. They should also develop interpretative and critical skills in reading primary sources and secondary sources.)

title: Ecology of the Tropics
requirement_sentence: ENVS 120 or ENVS 130 or ENVS 131 or ENVS_OX 131 or ENVS 140 or (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (Same as BIOL 371 1) (Same as ENVS 371 1) This 2-credit hour lecture course will explore the diverse biomes of the tropics. The focus will be on tropical forests and grasslands, with an emphasis on ecological processes, biodiversity, human impact on the tropics, indigenous peoples, and ethnobotany. Prerequisites: Biology 142 and Biology 142L (for Biology 371). This course is taught by Dr. Larry Wilson (adjunct faculty), is SHARED by the Biology and Environmental Science Departments, and may be taken as elective credit for the biology major. There is also an optional field course/lab associated with this course that travels to Peru during Spring Break (see BIOL 372/ENVS 372).]

title: Special Topics in East Asian Studies: Queer Asian American Studies
requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 385W 1) (Studies of queer Asian America span an immense diversity of histories and lived experiences and reflect the vast interdisciplinarity of their practitioners. They often combine political, artistic, and/or cultural work with more conventional modes of academic production. This course will engage a broad range of genres that shape, express, and analyze queer life in Asian America (including drag, poetry, ethnography, film, and theory). It will also consider how transnational lives involve processes of translation and layered identification that complicate queerness itself, questioning the adequacy of globalized terms for genders and sexualities.)

title: Ecology of the Tropics Field Course
requirement_sentence: This course requires ENVS 371 or BIOL 371 as a prerequisite OR permission of instructor. (Same as BIOL 372 1) This 2-credit hour field course is part of the Office of International and Summer Programs (OISP) and will be taught during Spring Break week (March 6-15, 2026) in the Amazon River lowland rainforests of southern Peru (Tambopata Research Station), famous for its huge flocks of colorful Macaws. This field course will give the student a real hands-on rainforest experience, complete with bromeliads, toucans, sloths, and the sounds of the night. Graduating Seniors and students who have previously completed BIOL 371/ENVS 371 have priority for this course. Cost for the trip is approximately $3200 (depending on airfare prices). Permission of instructor is required. This course is taught by Dr. Lawrence Wilson (lwilso3@emory.edu; adjunct faculty), is SHARED by the Biology and Environmental Science Departments, and may be taken as elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the biology major. Biology majors may submit an application to Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu (and Leah Thomas in ENVS at leah.thomas@emory.edu for ENVS 372). Selected students will be notified and will have additional requirements by OISP. See the OISP website for additional information. Financial Aid scholarships from the Biology Department are available to eligible Biology majors who submit an application for the aid.

title: Special Topics: Troublemakers
professor: Victoria Alexan Bergbauer victoria.bergbauer@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Troublemakers: Framing Outsiders in Modern European History - (Same as ARTHIST 385W 1) This course is designed to give students an understanding of modern European history, in approaching it through its people and forms of architectures. As we follow individuals, their trajectories, and constructions that sought to frame and control them, students with interest in the nineteenth century and from wide-ranging fields--history, art history, architecture, comparative literature, gender and sexuality--will interact with the materials in an interdisciplinary manner. Reflecting on history from the margins matters. It crystallizes practices of exclusion and sheds light on the workings of power structures. These are processes that are central to modern European history and continue to mark societies today.

title: Topics: Art of Class Antiquity: Elements of Greek Arch.
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 329 2) "Elements of Greek Architecture" "Elements of Greek Architecture"More than two thousand years ago, ancient Greeks constructed temples that reveal a sophisticated command of planning, engineering, optical design, and mathematics. How did they achieve that? But also, are such temples their only architectural achievements worth studying? This course offers a broad introduction to Greek architecture, from monumental sanctuaries and civic structures to domestic houses and everyday spaces. The course covers the essentials: architectural orders and styles, building materials, construction techniques, and the roles of architects and workshops. At the same time, it addresses broader questions, such as: How did architecture shape ritual and social life? How did thresholds, lighting, and access structure bodily encounters with the sacred? How did houses and civic buildings reflect cultural values and community identity? In collaboration with Emory's Center for Digital Scholarship, students gain experience with digital tools used to reconstruct and visualize ancient buildings not only to see how they once looked, but also to explore how design affected movement, perception, and interaction, both with the divine and among mortals. Greek architecture, approached through architectural history, classics, anthropology, and digital humanities, emerges not only as a technical achievement but also as a cultural system that structured ancient lives, shaping notions of space, community, and the sacred. Art History major/minor: Division I Architectural Studies Minor: elective

title: Rhetorics of Resistance
requirement_sentence: Writing Movements This course introduces a range of social movement writing and education practices, including literacy campaigns, freedom schools, student movements, community publications, and insurgent arts. Through a variety of guest speakers, we will learn how people use writing, research, and a variety of communicative strategies in justice-oriented work across Atlanta and the larger Southeast. Students will create multimodal projects including narratives, presentations, and writing workshop curricula.

title: Language Diversity in the US
requirement_sentence: This course presents a linguistic view of the history, society, and culture of the United States. It discusses the many languages and forms of language that have been used in this country over its history, including standard and nonstandard forms of English, different social and geographical dialects, African American English, creoles, Native American languages, and immigrant languages from Asia and Europe. Students examine the inherent diversity of these communicative systems both as a form of cultural enrichment and as the basis for socio-political conflict, and also investigate possible solutions to these problems through class discussion and debate. In addition, students study the universal phenomenon of language change and explore how it affects understanding of language behavior.

title: Fresh Sem: Linguistics: Slang!
requirement_sentence: Ling 190: Slang! In this course, we will examine and analyze SLANG as a specific subset of language. Using theories and methods from structural linguistics, sociolinguistics, corpus linguistics, and the history of English, students will not only be immersed in previous research but will create their own projects and collect and analyze their own data. Students who decide to take this course agree to have civil, objective, and (mostly) mature discussions about a range of topics. Please note that, due to the nature of this course's topic, a lot of the language that we will be discussing is considered taboo by some. If you are easily offended by so-called coarse language or topics such as sex, bodily functions, or body parts, this may not be the course for you.

title: Special Topics: Chinese Buddhist Art & Monum
requirement_sentence: "Chinese Buddhist Art and Monument"Brought to ancient China by travelling merchants and monks, Buddhism was once a foreign religion. Yet not long after the initial introduction, Buddhist art and monuments flourished and gradually became a part of Chinese visual culture. At times, Buddhist art helped to build a cosmopolitan society that encouraged foreign trade. In other times, painting Buddhist subjects and visiting ancient Buddhist sites were high-minded pursuits of educated Chinese elites. Women from different social classes also found motivations to participate in the making and collecting of Buddhist art and materials. This course explores grandiose sculptures, mural paintings, cliff-carved cave-shrines, paintings, prints, and textiles in Chinese Buddhist visual culture. We will address how issues of politics, patronage, gender, and economy shaped the production and reception of Chinese Buddhist art. Art History major/minor: Division II or IV

title: Race, Gender, and Media-Making
ger: Continuing Comm.& Writing with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: Race, Gender, and Media-Making: "The US Black Press at (Almost) 200!"In 1827, Freedom's Journal became the first newspaper owned, edited, and published by Black Americans in the United States. In spring of 2026, we will anticipate an important 200th anniversary for Black print culture by exploring the history and development of newspapers, magazines, and other print genres created by and for Black people across North America. We'll read literary magazines, abolitionist newspapers, fiction from periodicals, and more! across almost a century of print culture. Assignments include Hoax/SciFi article, "News in the News" presentation, and a long-term Wikimedia project contributing metadata and original Wikipedia articles about the US Black press.

title: Topic: Writing/ Rhetoric/Literacy
requirement_sentence: Attention Ecology: Social Media and Our Responses In this upper-level writing course, we will turn our attention both towards and away from the social media industry. By attending to the history and present of what Neil Postman named "media ecology" as well as the emergent discourse concerning the "attention economy," this class seeks to understand how various forms of social media shape how we think, speak, act, and exist in the world. From this study arises a particular question: can we do anything about it? Seeking to proffer alternatives how might we spend our time otherwise? what might we do instead? This class will also engage meaningfully with various rhetorically rich practices of making meaning and meaningfully making. "With ten thousand rituals," writes Jim Harrison, "I paint time and mortality, not only to make them endurable but to give them the dimension, splendor, resonance, perhaps beauty, that I sense they deserve." What will our (new) rituals be?

title: Foundations of Linguistics
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 203 1) What do you know when you know a language? How did you come to learn this information so quickly? How do the world's languages differ? How do linguists study language? This course explores the complex nature of human language and introduces students to the scientific study of human language. As we unpack our knowledge of language, we will explore speech sounds (phonetics), sound systems of language (phonology), word and sentence formation (morphology and syntax), how language expresses meaning (semantics), and how context influences the interpretation of meaning (pragmatics). We will also study language in a broader human context, investigating the role of language in defining human society. Additional topics include historical linguistics, language typology, sociolinguistics, and language acquisition.

title: Special Studies History of Art: Thinking Through Materials
requirement_sentence: "Thinking Through Materials" The organic warmth of wood, the uncanny plasticity of wax, the brute density of concrete, the immateriality of light. This innovative seminar, co-taught by an art historian and a practicing artist, will alternate between hands-on experimentation with materials (both traditional and unconventional) and theoretical-historical consideration of significant art historical uses of such materials in the 20th century. We will grapple with the economic, political, and cultural contexts that give meaning to artists' choice of materials and means of production. At the same time, we will ponder how materials might be thought to have agency in the artistic process. Art History major/minor: Division III Art History Visual Art Concentration: elective

title: Topics in Lit. & Environment
requirement_sentence: Literature & Environment: Nature Writing Labs: This seminar invites students to explore the environmental humanities and nature writing through a range of inquiry, observation, and research. Guided by activity labs from dissecting owl pellets to growing pollinators, students will engage in writing and revision as processes of wonder and discovery. Selected texts on ecological topics will span time, genres, modalities, and disciplines, and will guide students in composing their own critical and creative projects.

title: Meaning in Human Language
requirement_sentence: Before you enroll: Be advised that this class is NOT an introductory Linguistics course. It will be assumed that students are already familiar with the goals of linguistic inquiry and the methods of basic syntactic analysis (trees, categories, constituency tests). If you have not taken Foundations of Linguistics (LING-201/ANT-203), or an equivalent course, you will be required to do significant extra self-instructional work at the beginning of the semester. What we do in this course: Much of the language you hear over the course of a day consists of sentences you have never heard before, and yet you are able to understand them. How is this possible? The principle of compositionality states that the meaning of a sentence is determined by the meanings of its words and the way they are combined. In the first part of this course, students will learn a system for doing just this - combining phrase structure trees and computing the meanings that result, using the formal language of predicate logic to represent sentence meanings. Then, in the second part of the course, we'll focus on utterance meaning - aspects of meaning that go beyond what is shown in the predicate logic. For example, what enables us to understand a sentence like `There's ice cream on your shirt' as a simple informative description in some contexts, as an accusation in others, and as a warning in still others? We'll discuss speech acts, implicature, presupposition and other aspects of utterance meaning as we explore the close relationship between semantics and pragmatics. All required readings will be made available online.

title: Capstone in RWID
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) RWID Capstone This capstone course serves as the culmination of your studies in RWID. In this 1-credit seminar, you will return to and revise the web-based portfolio that you started building earlier in the program. Your goal will be to synthesize the work you've done as a writer and learner at Emory - within the minor, and beyond - by curating and showcasing what you consider your best work. As you grapple with how to portray a version of yourself and the commitments you've developed from your experiences, we will take a metadisciplinary and rhetorical approach to this representation. We will reflect on how you have learned to create meaning in your fields and communities, in terms of what you have been taught to value and come to value personally in your scholarship. Moreover, you will practice using writing and speech to show this approach to others who may or may not have the same backgrounds as you do. The course will culminate in an oral "defense" of your portfolio, where you will present what you've created to me, your peers, and others in the Writing Program.

title: Elementary German II
schedule_location: TTh 10am-11:15am in Modern Language 128 F 10am-10:50am in Modern Language 128
requirement_sentence: This is the second of the two-course sequence of elementary German that explores the roles and group affiliations that contribute to the identity formation of young adults in the United States and the German-speaking world. Specifically, students will examine the following three roles in 102, devoting 4-5 weeks to each: The young adult as (1) a consumer; (2) a traveler/tourist; and (3) a citizen. Students will use a textbook and supplemental materials to acquire the language necessary to communicate meaningfully about each topic. Through this process of examining identity formation, students in this course, together with its prerequisite, German 101, will develop a solid foundation in speaking, writing, reading, and understanding German and life in German-speaking countries.

title: Special Topics in Classics: Picturing Others
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 487W 1) "Picturing Others: Race, Ethnicity, and Representation between the Near East and Greece" What makes someone a foreigner? And what role do images play in shaping how societies portray, classify, and engage with those deemed alien, foreign, or other? Across the ancient Mediterranean, peoples of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece with their different languages, religions, skin colors, and traditions shared spaces, traded, exchanged ideas, and forged alliances, but also fought, invaded, and enslaved one another. How did these interactions, both peaceful and violent, influence the ways they depicted one another as foreigners, neighbors, defeated enemies, and racialized others? And how did such ideologically and culturally charged representations, in turn, shape lived encounters between different populations? This course draws on visual, material, and literary evidence from Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece (ca. 18004 00 BCE) to examine the role of ethnic and racial representation in constructing power dynamics and shaping human relations in the ancient world. Through lectures, discussions, readings, and direct engagement with the Greek, Mesopotamian, and Egyptian collections at the Carlos Museum, students will critically analyze how visual and textual sources depicted foreignness, difference, and otherness, and how these depictions structured broader patterns of cultural interaction, political authority, and social hierarchy. Art History major/minor: Division I

title: Scholarly Inquiry
requirement_sentence: NRSG 331 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Must seek permission from faculty. Student cannot self-register. Registration will be processed by the Office of Education.

title: Interdisciplinary Research Design
requirement_sentence: This course is designed to help IDS and American studies majors in the Institute for the Liberal Arts (ILA) to develop their senior thesis. During the course of the semester students will learn how to design a strong and compelling academic research project. Students will gather, read, and analyze academic sources related to their intellectual interests and use them to identify a research topic, develop a research question, think about relevant theories, and choose a research method to help answer their question. Students will design a well-organized plan of research, culminating in the submission of their thesis prospectus and the completion of a presentation at the ILA Spring Research Symposium. During the semester students will complete a variety of assignments to familiarize themselves with the research resources available on campus. They will also work on developing their research network, by meeting to discuss their ideas with faculty in the ILA and across campus. As a cohort, students will work together to build a strong community of researchers who support one another through the highs, plateaus, and lows of research.

title: Environmental Change and Health
professor: Gonzalo Vazquez Prokopec gmvazqu@emory.edu Primary Instructor
schedule_location: MW 8:30am-9:45am in Math & Science Center - E208

title: Freshman Seminar: Mountain Literature and Film
requirement_sentence: Research on the earth's fragile mountain regions has focused on the effects of climate change, biodiversity, and sustainable development. While such work is imminently important, this course looks at how humans have related to and interacted with mountains in literature and film. Beginning with climbing documentaries such as Free Solo, we discuss the increasing popularity of rock and gym climbing to investigate how previous mountaineers and inhabitants of mountain regions have depicted their forays. We conclude by looking at future challenges and opportunities of mountain sports. Through narratives and film, group projects and personal explorations of local places and communities, this course pursues the question of what are the promises of outdoor recreation and what are its pitfalls.

title: Phonetics: How Spanish Sounds
requirement_sentence: (Same as SPAN 303 1) In this course (taught in Spanish), we will explore how diverse pronunciations are produced and organized by Spanish-speakers (including native/heritage and second-language speakers). As part of this, we will compare typical pronunciations of Spanish with those of English, and we will examine how different communities assign different social meanings and values to different pronunciations (for instance, why and in what circumstances do people value positively or negatively pronunciations such as "ello están contento" as opposed to "ellos están contentos"). This semester, we will include a component focusing on how different pronunciations and intonation can contribute to the performance of literary, theatrical and other spoken-language texts/events. TEXT: Tuten, D. N., Tejedo-Herrero, L. F., R. Rao, & H. R. Clarke. 2022. Pronunciaciones del español (Routledge). PARTICULARS: This course is designed for a wide variety of students, including those for whom Spanish is a primary/native or heritage language as well as for those who are learning Spanish as a second language. This is an introductory course in Hispanic Linguistics and therefore no background in Linguistics is required. Span/Ling 303 is a core course for the Spanish and Linguistics Joint Major and a Foundational Course for the Spanish Major and Minor. It counts as an elective or HAL course for other Linguistics majors and minors. EVALUATION is based on attendance/participation, homework assignments, exams, and performance projects. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212 or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html. For more information on Foundational Courses, please go to www.spanport.emory.edu.

title: Directed Research
requirement_sentence: Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Psychology majors only. Credit is variable, 1.00 - 12.00 (For 3.00 hrs/week = 1.00 credit). Students must have consent of faculty member (inside or outside of the department) and agreement on a research, expectations and responsibilities in the lab. Students are required to complete a PSYC 498R/499R Contract with a faculty member or principal investigator detailing their research. Contract is available through Lorenza Houser (lhouser@emory.edu). Please e-mail Ms. Houser to obtain a copy of the contract to complete and sign along with your faculty supervisor and/or principal investigator inside or outside the department before returning it to her. Enrollment in PSYC 499R are done administratively; Ms. Houser will enroll you in directed research herself. For students conducting research outside of the Department of Psychology, the contract must be approved by Dr. Andrew Kazama (akazama@emory.edu) as the department's director of undergraduate research before submitting it to Ms. Houser.

title: Fresh Sem:Environmentl Studies: Earth 2.0 Geospacial Insights
schedule_location: TTh 2:30pm-3:45pm in Math & Science Center - N301
requirement_sentence: In this class, students embark on a transformative journey across the vast expanse of our digitally represented planet. This course bridges the gap between ancient cartographic traditions and today's cutting-edge geospatial technologies, providing students with a comprehensive introduction to the tools, techniques, and trends shaping the future of digital exploration. Through this course, you will acquire a foundational grasp of geospatial data principles, study the cutting-edge tech in modern cartography like GIS and satellite imagery, understand its diverse applications from urban planning to conservation, and engage in projects that hone critical thinking and creativity through real-world challenges.

title: Beginning Conversation
requirement_sentence: This one-credit conversation class is designed for beginning students who either want to keep up their exposure to German without taking a four-credit class or want additional German language practice outside of their regular German class. Taught by the German Studies Department's Fulbright Foreign Language Teaching Assistant, the course focuses primarily on spoken German, but all modalities (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) are covered. The topics for investigation and discussion are culturally significant aspects of the German-speaking world. Success in the course hinges on your active participation and engagement with the course materials and the other class participants. Prerequisite 192: This course will be conducted in German and is open to students who have completed at least one semester of college-level German or the equivalent.

title: Topics in Sociolinguistics: Discourse Analysis
requirement_sentence: This course examines written texts and spoken language in both informal and highly institutionalized settings. Some questions that we ask include: What makes conversation work and how do we know when a conversation has gone wrong? What are the different features of institutional talk such as interviews and political speeches? How are different "voices" used in spoken and written narratives? How do we display aspects of our identity in spoken and written texts? How do speakers exert institutional power over others in interactions? How do speaker belief systems shape discourse and how dos discourse reinforce belief systems? This course will introduce students to the ways that conversation, narrative, and language variation function in naturally occurring language data. Students will also learn the practical aspects of collecting and transcribing speech and we will review theoretical debates for how to relate the details of spoken and written "texts" to broader social categories such as power, identity, culture, and speaker roles.

title: Spec. Topics in German Studies: German Colloquy
requirement_sentence: This 2-hour capstone colloquy is designed for students who major or minor in German and have junior standing. You will engage in a thorough reflection on what it means to pursue German studies, which includes studying German as a foreign language, its literature, films, music, and other artistic or cultural works from German-speaking cultures. We will discuss specific learning outcomes and how your minors and majors can impact a successful career and a fulfilling personal life, whether you pursue further study of German, participate in public engagement, or undertake professional endeavors beyond Emory University.personal life, whether you pursue further study of German, participate in public engagement, or undertake professional endeavors beyond Emory University. Through various readings, discussions, media, and writing assignments, you will explore a range of topics related to your (future) experience and learning in German studies as majors or minors.

title: African American Language
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 347 1, ANT 347 1) African American Language (AAL) is by far the most researched, the most publicly recognized, and most controversial language variety in the United States. AAL has long been a central object of study in North American sociolinguistics, where researchers have investigated its structure, its origins, and its current trajectories of change relative to Mainstream American English, and have simultaneously sought to combat misunderstandings about AAL (and all language differences) held by the public and the press. This course will be broken into four major sections: 1) Present-Day Features of AAL, with a focus on its vocabulary (lexicon), pronunciation features (phonetics and phonology) and grammar (morphology and syntax); 2) The History of AAL and its ongoing trajectory of change, focusing on earlier examples of AAL, its possible origins and whether or not AAL is diverging from Mainstream American English (MAE) and other varieties of English; 3) AAL as a Living Art will discuss AAL as it is employed as an expression of art by writers, musicians, as well as its use in African American speech events, and avenues for outreach; 4) AAL, Education and Society will examine issues related to AAL and education, the justice system, linguistic profiling and discrimination in other areas of society such as housing and employment.

title: Quantum Mechanics in Chemistry
requirement_sentence: (CHEM 205 or CHEM_OX 205) and (PHYS 142 or PHYS_OX 142 or PHYS 152 or PHYS_OX 152) and (MATH 112 or MATH_OX 112 or MATH 210 or MATH_OX 210 or CHEM 270) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Old English Language & Literature
requirement_sentence: (Same as ENG 300W 1) Pre-1700 One semester of intensive language study will result in a proficient reading knowledge of the West Saxon dialect (standard Old English) such that we can explore the culture of the Anglo-Saxons and better understand the language we speak today. Selections from heroic and religious poetry and prose will begin with the first known poem in the English language and will also include the Wanderer and Seafarer, the Battle of Maldon, the Dream of the Rood, Ælfric's preface to Genesis, and King Alfred's lament over the faded glory of English learning. Classes consist of prepared translation, short lectures, and discussion. The standard lexicographic and bibliographic tools in Old English will be covered. Some previous foreign language study is desirable but not required; students should be prepared to use a glossary. We will also read Beowulf in translation, as well as selected passages in Old English.

title: Special Topics in Linguistics
requirement_sentence: (Complete Title: Teaching Methodology for English Language Learners) Students will discuss texts and teaching materials, as well as observe classes designated for English Language Learners (ELLs), to acquire knowledge about the English language learning process and associated pedagogy. Various teaching techniques will be modelled during class sessions. Objectives/Learning Outcomes: Through this directed study, the student will be able to: (1) Explain the first and second language acquisition process. (2) Develop knowledge of multiple instructional methods, techniques, styles, and strategies for teaching ELL students. (3) Understand and recognize ELL students in terms of their background, learning styles, and language competence.

title: German Conversation
requirement_sentence: This one-credit conversation class is designed for intermediate to advanced students who either want to keep up their exposure to German without taking a four-credit class or who want additional German language practice outside of their regular German class. Taught by the German Studies Department's Fulbright Foreign Language Teaching Assistant, the course focuses primarily on spoken German, but all modalities (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) are covered. The topics for investigation and discussion are culturally significant aspects of the German-speaking world. Success in the course hinges on your active participation and engagement with the course materials and the other class participants. Prerequisite 392: This course will be conducted in German and is open to students who have completed at least three semesters of college-level German or the equivalent.

title: Language, Mind & Society
requirement_sentence: Why is language structured the way it is? How and why is it limited in what it can express? Answers to questions such as these usually stem from two opposing views. One focuses on language and meaning as products of how the mind works. The other stresses language as a product of social interaction. In this course, we will consider a series of questions to better understand these two views. Topics will include what the sources of linguistic structure might be; whether (or how much of) language is innate in humans; how language reflects categories and helps us form categories; and to what extent language influences thought. The course is only available to graduating seniors who have declared the following majors or minors: Linguistics, Psych/Ling, Span/Ling, or QSS major w/ concentration in Linguistics. Permission number required to enroll, contact: dbolde2@emory.edu. Required Textbook(s): No textbook required; readings will be available on Canvas.

title: Spanish in the US
professor: Jose Luis Boigues Lopez jboigue@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as SPAN 413W 1) This course provides a descriptive and critical overview of the linguistic practices of different Spanish-speaking communities in the United States, as well as a methodology for the study of these practices. Students will learn about the linguistics characteristics of the different Spanish varieties spoken by these communities, including phonetic, morphological, syntactic and lexical aspects. Special attention is given to the relationship between language and society, particularly on topics such as ethnic and cultural identity, multilingualism and language policy. The course also presents a theoretical and practical approach to the ethnographic research method. Students will read and analyze studies carried out by different scholars and will design their own research project on the topic of their preference. Special attention is given to ethical principles, for this reason students will need to complete the web-based Collaborative IRB Training Initiative (CITI) Program in the Protection of Human Subjects in Research. Background on general Linguistics is recommended, such as the one provided in Span/Ling 303, Span/Ling 304 or Ling 201.This course meets the sociocultural requirement of the Linguistics Major and can be used as one of the required 400-level courses for the Joint Major in Spanish & Linguistics or for the Major/Minor in Spanish. TEXTS: - Escobar, Anna María and Kim Potowski. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. - Selection of articles available in Canvas. EVALUATION: Evaluation will be based in class participation, weekly assignments, one exam, one research project and five written practices. PRE-REQUISITES: One foundational course, preferably SPAN/LING 303 or SPAN/LING 304.

requirement_sentence: (SOC 101 is designed specifically for sophomores and first year students; enrollment does not open until those course registration times. Very occasionally a junior, but not a senior will find enrollment off the waitlist, which opens only after first year and soph enrollment. This course will provide students with an overview of the sociological approach. Major theoretical concepts and methodologies will be examined and illustrated with a wide variety of classic as well as recent empirical studies. Some of the topics we'll look at include: social structure and culture in everyday life; societal views of death; socialization to gender roles; causes and consequences of major systems of social inequality (gender; race and ethnicity; social class). Requirements: Weekly readings, two papers, and two exams.)

title: Survey of Jewish History
schedule_location: MW 1pm-2:15pm in Math & Science Center - E208
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 270 1, MESAS 275 1) This course is a survey of Jewish history from antiquity to the present. It presumes no prior knowledge of Jewish history, religion or culture. We will examine how Jews have defined themselves socially and politically in a number of historical and geographical settings, how Jewish theology and religious practice have been shaped and transformed, and how Jews have interacted with and responded to the societies in which they have lived. A central question during the ancient period will be, what was "Judaism" and how did it emerge out of the diverse religious landscape of antiquity? The medieval period will focus on the interface between Jewish communities and the states or empires in which they lived. Particular attention will be paid to the interactions between Jews, Christians, and Muslim peoples and cultures. In the modern period, we will analyze the processes by which governments, politicians and some segments of Jews attempted to incorporate the Jews and Judaism into European society and the various problems and reactions engendered by the quest for Jewish emancipation and social integration.

title: Special Topics in Biology: Model Hypotheses in Pop&Evol
requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. (FULL TITLE: Models for Generating Hypotheses in Population and Evolutionary Biology.) This 2-credit hour course will introduce Juniors, Seniors, and interested graduate students to mathematical and computer simulation modeling in biology. The focus will be on the role of models used in developing hypotheses and of designing the tests of these hypotheses with experiments. Empasis would be on using models in population biology, ecology, and evolutionary biology, with particular consideration of bacteria, bacteriophage, and antibiotic treatment, as well as the practical (medical and epidemiological) application of the concepts of population and evolutionary biology. Models about the age and distribution of cancer will also be looked at. Students in this course will learn how to prepare a manuscript and will submit the manuscript to a journal, as co-authors. The class will learn how to use the Berkely Madonna software for the numerical solution to differential equations and Monte Carlo simulations. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L and at least one course in Calculus, preferably Calculus for Biologists.

title: Racial & Ethnic Relations
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 247 1) For years we have understood that race is, biologically speaking, an exceedingly complex matter. Preconceived biases, much more than biology, govern the way people think about race. This course considers both the biological myth and social reality of race. We will focus on the social significance of race by examining the reality of racial stratification, the reality of the experience of racism, race, ethnicity, and nation, and the rationality of those who study racial dynamics and processes. The first portion of the course disentangles how race was leveraged to establish the sciences as an effective tool to understand and change society. The second portion of the course describes sociological theories of prejudice, privilege, and power to understand racism and racial stratification. The third portion of the course surveys empirical readings in Sociology that consider the state of ethnoracial inequality in the primary social institutions of society and everyday life opportunities. Throughout we consider how social change in social attitudes, classification systems, and policies shape the current global landscape of racism along the imperial projects of race, ethnicity, nation. The end product of the course increases competency in understanding the origins, dynamics, and state of racial and ethnic relations using the language and tools of Sociology through its scientific study of society.

title: Criminology
requirement_sentence: This course addresses major themes and questions in the sociological study of criminology. We will examine some of the most influential explanations for criminal behavior, including strain theory and social control theory among others. The course will focus on the ways in which social context shapes beliefs about crime. What are the causes of crime? How can crime be reduced? In what ways is criminal justice decision-making influenced by race, class, and gender biases? To develop a thorough understanding of the nature of crime, we will examine a range of empirical work and substantive issues but will focus on issues around mass incarceration, prison systems, and white collar crime.

requirement_sentence: (Same as HLTH 250 1 and ANT 205 1) (This interdisciplinary course explores the complex causes of serious health problems in both low-income and rich countries throughout the world, as well as strategies of health programs aimed at their solution. Global Health refers not only to the health problems of "others" living in far corners of the world but also to our own health problems as citizens of a very rich nation; most importantly it is about how those health problems are the result of global, social, economic and political interactions.)

title: Special Topics: Cross-listed: God, Sex, and Crime
professor: Javier Villa Flores javier.villa-flores@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 270 1, ANT 285 1, and LACS 270 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (Throughout history, crimes have tested and measured the social and cultural values that hold human beings together. In a society such as New Spain (Mexico) articulated around the defense and propagation of Catholic religion, religious crimes constituted a threatening subversion of the colonial discourse that justified the Spanish presence in Mexico, and a contradictory expression of the social tensions lived in the Spanish colony. This course will look at colonial society through the lens of crime by analyzing some of the main transgressions prosecuted by the Mexican Inquisition between 1520 and 1820, and the specific historical circumstances in which the trials took place. Our goal will be not only to analyze the reasons for inquisitorial repression, but also to disentangle the tensions lived in the social fabric of the colony in light of the classic divides of race, class, and gender.)

requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 270 1, ANT 285 1, and LACS 270 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (Throughout history, crimes have tested and measured the social and cultural values that hold human beings together. In a society such as New Spain (Mexico) articulated around the defense and propagation of Catholic religion, religious crimes constituted a threatening subversion of the colonial discourse that justified the Spanish presence in Mexico, and a contradictory expression of the social tensions lived in the Spanish colony. This course will look at colonial society through the lens of crime by analyzing some of the main transgressions prosecuted by the Mexican Inquisition between 1520 and 1820, and the specific historical circumstances in which the trials took place. Our goal will be not only to analyze the reasons for inquisitorial repression, but also to disentangle the tensions lived in the social fabric of the colony in light of the classic divides of race, class, and gender.)

title: Social Statistics
requirement_sentence: This course introduces students to statistical methods used in social research. It fulfills the sociology major requirement for a statistics course and a MQR general education requirement. Topics covered include descriptive and inferential statistics, levels of measurement, central tendency and variability, sampling distributions, interval estimation, and hypothesis testing for both categorical and continuous variables. By the end of the semester you should be able to (1) identify appropriate statistical methods for analyzing data, (2) critically assess basic statistical information from sources such as news articles and academic journals, and (3) use the program SPSS to conduct your own statistical research. Particulars: Take-home assignments and in-class quizzes Textbooks, Articles, and Resources
