title: Special Topics in Sociology: Black Culture and Capitalism
professor: Jessica Lynn Stewart jessica.lynn.stewart@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 285 1) (This course examines the theory of Black capitalism within a wide range of American contexts, varied by place and time. First, students are exposed to a tradition of radical scholarship that analyzes the intersections - or articulations - between racism and capitalism. We will explore some seminal texts by WEB DuBois, Manning Marable, and Cedrick Robinson, among others. Then students will also gain an understanding of how local economic development works to support or obstruct Black capitalism. Particular attention will be paid to how growth versus redistribution strategies impact Black communities. It will end by considering the intersection of race and class in struggles for economic and social justice - from Black celebrities to voters, to activists and politicians.)

title: Sociology of Education
requirement_sentence: The course is about the structure, roles, and the collective and individual functions of schooling. This sociology course is also ideal for those students interested in public policy, education processes, and social inequalities. It surveys the social, political, economic, and cultural influences on schooling and educational outcomes in contemporary U.S. and, to a degree, global society. It will focus especially on schooling inequalities according to racial, ethnic, immigrant, class, gender, and sexual status, as measured by educational achievement and attainment, and which are often inherent to the structures and processes of U.S. schooling. The course also examines the interconnection of schooling to important social institutions, such as families, and their contribution to schooling inequality. The course will consider classic and current theories in the sociology of education, and address controversies within existing educational policy, including current reform efforts and recent neoliberal developments such as school choice.

title: Introduction to Latinx Studies
ger: Humanities and Arts with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: As an introduction to the field of Latinx Studies, this course explores the diversity of Latinx experiences and lifeways in the US through an interdisciplinary lens. The course will focus on the historical and political contexts that impact Latinx racialization, and class formation,. Beginning with an interrogation of the term Latinx and the history of Latinx Studies as a discipline, topics to be explored include, race, indigeneity, racism and colorism, colonialism and imperialism, Latinx feminisms, queer Latinidades, migration, diaspora, language, citizenship and social movements. The course will be attentive to regional differences (Latinidad in LA, NYC, Atlanta, or rural Arkansas) and differences in communities of origin (Latinidad as experienced by Hondureños, Puerto Ricans, Tejanos, Cubans, Mexicans, Dominicans, etc.)

title: American Jewish History
professor: Eric L Goldstein egoldst@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 329 1) This course is a survey of the Jewish experience in America, examining the religious, cultural, political, and economic activities of American Jews from the colonial period to the present. Students will explore the ways Jewish tradition has adapted to America, how patterns of communal life have been transformed, what the relationship of American Jews has been to other Americans and to the international Jewish community, and how American Jewish identities have been created from Jews' dual impulses for integration and distinctiveness. We will also use the Jewish experience as a means of evaluating different definitions of American national identity.

title: Jews of Eastern Europe
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 338 1) (On the eve of the Holocaust, a majority of world Jewry lived in Eastern Europe, especially Poland and the USSR. This course explores the origins, dynamic growth, and near destruction of East European Jewry from the Middle Ages to the Holocaust and the challenges to Jewish life in this region in the post-WWII era. Many of the signature features of modern Jewish life - Hasidism, modern Jewish literature, Yiddish, Zionism, revolutionary socialism - derive from the centuries-long robust Jewish civilization in Eastern Europe.) (This course will make extensive use of primary documents - legal charters, memoirs, Hasidic tales, short stories, war reportage - to give us the tools to reconstruct this history together. We will also watch films and critically assess the recent Broadway versions of Fiddler on the Roof. As an add-on to this course, there is an optional 1-credit, twelve-day travel course to Poland, "Jews of Poland: History and Memory", which will be offered in May 2026.)

title: Era of the American Revolution
schedule_location: TTh 2:30pm-3:45pm in Math & Science Center - N306
requirement_sentence: We are about to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. This course, on the history of the American Revolutionary era, will consider it as a political, military, social, and economic event. We will study the most important American figures, including Washington, Jefferson, Franklin, Hamilton, and Madison, but also the most important British and French ones, including Lord North, King George III, General Cornwallis, Louis XVI, and the Count of Vergennes. The lives of ordinary American men and women, free and enslaved--will be compared with the lives of the powerful and we'll read a wide selection of works by soldiers, politicians, propagandists, mercenaries, and loyalists to explore the complexity of this dynamic historical period. There will be two papers, two midterms, and a final exam.

title: American Routes
requirement_sentence: (Same as AMST 321 1) American Routes explores "roots" (vernacular) music in the US in historical-geographical contexts. Where, when, and how do musical genres and styles emerge and spread? How does music express social history, cultural identities, ranges of feeling, "authenticity," displacement and mobility, and political commentary? Genres include: African American spirituals and gospel, the beginnings of jazz and blues, migrations of British ballads, Appalachian secular and sacred styles, Louisiana Cajun and Zydeco, country music, the origins of rock and roll, soul, Native influences, episodes of protest music, and the cultural contexts of klezmer, conjunto, salsa, rap, and recent "singer-songwriter styles." Listening and reading assignments are linked from the course syllabus and Emory electronic course reserves. Grading is based on attendance and participation, frequent quizzes, a midterm exam, and a short final paper developed in consultation with the professor.

title: ORDER Seminar: What Does it Mean to be Human?
requirement_sentence: Through an interdisciplinary exploration combining social sciences, sciences, and humanities disciplines and methodologies, we will engage in creative and intellectually rigorous conversation about the human experience, while writing our own stories in the process. This course will progress through separate topical units centered around three core questions: -How do we understand ourselves? Why is it difficult to define what is human? Why do we need to think of humanity as a problem? -Human compared to what? Here we seek to further illustrate what makes humanity distinct through a comparative lens. What is a human compared to an animal, a robot, or even, considering our strange relationship to the nation-state, a citizen? In doing this, we will think deeply about how humanity defines itself through and against its own narratives of power and dominance. -Where are we going? In addressing this question, we will attempt to work through some of the largest existential threats to humankind and determine two things: How do different disciplines tackle these issues? And can these disciplines work together to solve them?

title: Sem:Ancient Mediterr/Anatolian Art: Picturing Others
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 487W 1) "Picturing Others: Race, Ethnicity, and Representation between the Near East and Greece" What makes someone a foreigner? And what role do images play in shaping how societies portray, classify, and engage with those deemed alien, foreign, or other? Across the ancient Mediterranean, peoples of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece with their different languages, religions, skin colors, and traditions shared spaces, traded, exchanged ideas, and forged alliances, but also fought, invaded, and enslaved one another. How did these interactions, both peaceful and violent, influence the ways they depicted one another as foreigners, neighbors, defeated enemies, and racialized others? And how did such ideologically and culturally charged representations, in turn, shape lived encounters between different populations? This course draws on visual, material, and literary evidence from Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece (ca. 18004 00 BCE) to examine the role of ethnic and racial representation in constructing power dynamics and shaping human relations in the ancient world. Through lectures, discussions, readings, and direct engagement with the Greek, Mesopotamian, and Egyptian collections at the Carlos Museum, students will critically analyze how visual and textual sources depicted foreignness, difference, and otherness, and how these depictions structured broader patterns of cultural interaction, political authority, and social hierarchy. Art History major/minor: Division I

title: Creative Writing: Intermediate Poetry
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. FORMS In this intermediate course, you will find a community of poets serious about their craft, hoping to deepen their engagement with the art of poetry. Through the shared sense of trust and endeavor provided by the workshop community, we will closely read the work of published poets and that of our peers as we draft new poems ourselves. To structure our in-class discussions and the weekly creation of new work, we will look closely at prosody and the resurgence of traditional forms in the work of contemporary American poets. As we try out various forms ourselves, we will situate our own poetic experiments in a centuries-long conversation extending to our present moment.

title: Creative Writing: Intermediate Non-Fiction
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. Nonfiction Magazine and Long-form Writing. No pre-requisite. This class is NOT open to first-year students. This workshop is focused on long-form, nonfiction magazine and feature writing -- reading it, reporting it, writing it, and doing so in ways and by means that separate the exceptional from the pedestrian. This is nonfiction. Be prepared to be a reporter, to meet people face-to-face, to ask questions, to see and hear things with your own eyes and ears. My goal is to get your work published. We'll have visiting experts on hand as we discuss where great ideas come from, how to be strategic in your reporting, the art of the interview, and crafting stories, then stories within stories. We're looking mostly at print, but we will see beyond the dead tree media at the growing opportunities for magazine-style writing and long-form narratives online. Ultimately, the goal of the course is for you to become a considerably wiser and more effective nonfiction storyteller, for which the basis is sound reporting. Students should budget to purchase the textbook and for photocopying.

title: Screenwriting
requirement_sentence: ENGCW 270/270W or ENGCW_OX 270 or ENGCW 271/271W or ENGCW_OX 271 or ENGCW 272/272W or FILM 101 or FILM_OX 101 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (Same as FILM 378RW 2) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. YOU MUST ATTEND THE SECOND CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. WRITING THE SHORT FILM. Instructor will be incoming Screenwriting Fellow, Carolyn Kras. This course introduces students to dramatic writing for short motion pictures. The topics covered include visual writing, plot, story structure, character, and dialogue. Emphasis is placed on telling a story in cinematic terms. In addition to completing several writing assignments, students are expected to develop, pitch, outline, and write a short screenplay.

title: Seminar in Fiction:English: Virginia Woolf & Her Contemp.
requirement_sentence: In her essay "How Should One Read a Book?" Virginia Woolf suggests that the best way to experience fiction is to drop all preconceived notions of what a novel can be: "do not dictate to your author; try to become him. Be his fellow-worker and his accomplice." In this course we will become the accomplices of one of the most inventive writers of twentieth-century literature. Reading our way through some of Woolf's major novels as well as selected essays, stories, and autobiographical writing, we will think about Woolf as a critic, humorist, feminist, and literary innovator, with special consideration to the way Woolf reinvents representations of character and human consciousness. While we focus on Woolf's illuminations of the interior self, we will also explore the adventurous artistic and philosophical spirit of Bloomsbury and how her work reflects England's transformation in the first half of the twentieth century: world war and its aftermath, changing social and sexual mores, new conceptions of gender roles and women's rights, advances in human psychology, and contemporaneous developments in painting and design. Texts may include some of the following: Woolf, Night and Day, Mrs. Dalloway, To the Lighthouse, Orlando, Between the Acts; The Waves; A Room of One's Own; Forster, Maurice; Bowen, The House in Paris; Mansfield, stories; Watson, Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day. Expectations: lively participation; weekly short Canvas postings; midterm and final essays.

title: Creative Writing: Intermediate Fiction
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. Inventing Time in Short Fiction This course expands craft concepts introduced in introductory creative writing coursework with a special focus on the narrative possibilities of time. How might we maintain a short story's necessary "intensity of focus" within a timeframe that spans centuries? How might a short story that takes place over the course of an hour give every detail heightened significance? In addition to exploring the narrative pressures of different timeframes, we will look at stories that break linearity, gesturing toward the future and even using elements like time travel to negotiate the constraints of the short story form. Selections from contemporary short fiction authors like Venita Blackburn, Sean Vestal, Mariah Rigg, Jonathan Escoffery, Brenda Peynado, Steven Millhauser, Ted Chiang, and Sofia Samatar will be included in our studies.

title: Studies In Women's Fiction: Dystopias--Hers and His
professor: Martine W Brownley mbrownl@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Dystopian novels have been so prominent in recent fiction that critics have described our time as a golden age for the genre. The result has been that, as one writer puts it, "there's a book for every type of modern dread." Particularly notable in this current dystopic outpouring has been the influence of women writers. This course juxtaposes the most famous dystopia written in English, George Orwell's 1984, with novels by contemporary women writers (Ling Ma, Octavia Butler, Margaret Atwood, and one TBA) to explore how their works are reshaping the genre. The imaginative societies envisioned by these writers pose crucial questions about where the real dangers lie for our future and our present through their groundbreaking dystopic novels. Requirements are active & informed class participation; occasional response paragraphs; 2 short papers, one potentially optional. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II Prose

title: Sem:Med/Euro/Renais/Baroque Art: Medieval Bestiary
requirement_sentence: "Medieval Bestiary"Gargoyles, griffins, manticores, babewyns, dragons, snails, and even domestic cats inhabit all kinds of medieval art, jostling for attention with its religious subjects. The twelfth-century cleric Saint Bernard, whose detailed descriptions nonetheless betray a great attraction to the artistic creations, decried the "comely deformity and deformed comeliness" of the hybrid creatures carved in his cloister. Yet medieval writers also found profound moral and mystical implications in the lore of the natural world. This course will explore animal imagery in all media throughout the Middle Ages, but will focus on the bestiaries, the medieval illuminated books dedicated to animals. It is a literature greatly enhanced by scholarship associated with the Animal Turn, which seeks to recognize the massive interdependence of the human and animal realms. Major themes of the course include the importance of the ancient legacy and how it was adapted and transformed by medieval theologians and artists; the rising rates of literacy for which medieval bestiaries may have been instrumental; and the importance of contextualized study Art History major/minor: Division II

title: Modern Irish Literature
professor: Nathan Suhr Sytsma nathan.e.suhr-sytsma@emory.edu Primary Instructor
schedule_location: TTh 2:30pm-3:45pm in Math & Science Center - N302
requirement_sentence: This course will explore the overlay of language and politics on an island where even what you call a place is it the North of Ireland or Northern Ireland? implies a political stance. You will learn how writers of fiction, plays, and poetry have not only imagined but contributed to cultural and political phenomena from the Irish Revival and the Easter Rising through the Troubles and the peace process. Focusing on Irish literature in English, you will also read some Irish-language literature in translation. Writers are likely to include, among others, Lady Gregory, W. B. Yeats, James Joyce, Seamus Heaney, Nuala Ní Dhomhnaill, and Anna Burns. Expect to read attentively, engage in class discussion, complete a brief in-class reading response or reading quiz each week, practice close reading in essay form, and develop a final project based in the splendid archives and manuscript collections of the Rose Library. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II

title: Ethics: Buddhist Ethics
professor: Sara L McClintock slmccli@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: (Same as PHIL 385W 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Tradition-Buddhism, Theme.) (This writing-intensive seminar takes a broadly philosophical approach to the study of Buddhist understandings of the nature of goodness and how goodness can be recognized and cultivated. Materials for the course will range from Buddhist scriptures, to philosophical treatises, to narratives, to poetry, and to films. The intention of the course is to engage seriously with Buddhist understandings of the nature of the human condition as infused with suffering, and how humans can nevertheless develop goodness and resilience within this fleeting and unstable world. Topics include the extent and limits of generosity, the proper objects of loving-kindness and compassion, the moral consequences of truths and falsehoods, and mind-training techniques for taking obstacles as the path.) (Writing assignments will be weekly and will emphasize engagement with the course materials. There will be a final written project that builds on the work done during the semester.)

title: Advanced Writing Workshop
requirement_sentence: This is an English Language Learner (ELL) course. Contact Jane O'Connor (jcoconn@emory.edu) for permission to enroll. Language, Land, & Place This course offers an introduction to various nonfiction genres (including flash nonfiction, photo-essay, and personal essay) and approaches to writing that destabilize standard academic English (including Indigenous language reclamation, multilingualism, and translingualism). We will read and discuss a range of scholarship in Black, Indigenous, Asian/American, and Latinx/Latine rhetoric, writing, and literacy; ground ourselves in our shared contexts of Atlanta and the larger Southeast; and develop shared practices of land- and place-based writing.

title: Jr/Sr Colloquium: Europe: Medieval Lives
professor: Michelle Armstrong Partida marmstrongpartida@emory.edu Primary Instructor
requirement_sentence: Complete topic: Medieval Lives: Love, Loss, Vengeance & Hatred This course is a social history of the Middle Ages. It takes a thematic approach by focusing on the lives of the elite, city dwellers, the peasantry, and religious minorities (Jews and Muslims). Topics covered include miracles and saints, knightly training, travelers and merchant capitalists, university life, marriage, sex workers, medicine and the Black Death, gender identities, fashion and material culture.
